story:
Hello friends! 

 

I thought we'd try something a little different this time around. We always rent a soundsystem and lights for this party. The rental cost, transportation, and gas for the generator come party time is not cheap and in the past this money has come straight out of the organizers pockets (with many generous individuals pitching in come party time). This has always worked in the past, but I think if we try crowd funding the rental costs for this party we could rent much better sound and lights and it would be much more convenient for the organizers to have all this money in advance rather than hoping it gets partially reimbursed on the weekend of the party. In the past the rentals have been a few hundred bucks. I'm thinking this time we should step it up! Let's get a system that can knock the pine needles off the trees!

 

I've set the goal at 700. I don't really expect to get that much, but if we do, great. We'll be able to rent a totally killer sound and light setup that puts to shame anything we've had in the past. Any amount helps though! This website is not like kickstarter in that we get nothing if we don't reach our goal. All of the money you donate will go towards the rental fees for the sound and lights and gas for the generator. Even if we only get 100 bucks through this website we'll still receive it at the end of the campaign and it will help a lot in making this party great.

 

Every. Single. Dollar. you donate will go towards either sound, lights, or generator gas. I promise I won't buy whip its with any of it.

 

If, in the past, you were one of those awesome peeps that threw us some cash come party time, use this website instead and do it in advance! It'll help us out a lot.

 

The person who makes the single biggest contribution will be forever blessed by the noodly appendages of FSM.

 

I love you guys and can't wait to see you all again!

story:
The Briery Gap Cultural Centre is a 200 seater theatre situated in the heart of Macroom town.

Any town in Ireland would be proud to have a venue like it.

We have hosted performances from musicians such as Jimmy McCarthy, Sharon Shannon, Jack L, and Mick Flannery and comedians such as Des Bishop, Kevin McAleer, Brendan Grace and Pat Shortt. We run a dedicated ‘Arts in Education’ programme and schools from all over Ireland attend our annual ‘Transition Year Drama Festival’. However the surrounding community is our core lifeline and we stage up to 50 community led performances a year.

After 14 years running, The Briery Gap's facilities are wearing thin and it is in serious need of a large-scale refurbishment.

We have the support of Cork County Council and Macroom Town Council to upgrade our venue inside and outside, but we need to raise extra funds to see the project through.

So we are inviting our community at home and abroad to donate online and help us to turn the corner.

Our Goal:

Our goal is to raise €22,000 to go directly towards refurbishment works planned for this summer.

Every wall and stairway needs to be painted, the signage needs to be replaced, the seats need to be fully refurbished and the technical facilities (including our sound system) need to be upgraded.

Be a Part of it:

Every contribution no matter how big or small is equally important in helping us achieve our goal to upgrade the Briery Gap.

Everyone that contributes to our project will become an important part of it and an important part of our history as a cultural centre.

We look forward to bringing you on the journey with us.

So please spread the word and help us keep the Briery Gap magic alive!!

story:
How we came to this point

Twelfth Night is one of Shakespeare’s comedies. The reason why this brand new theatre company has decided to do Twelfth Night is because we fell in love with it during a stage reading. Last year Foundling’s Theatre put on No Sleep Shakespeare. A festival where we preformed Shakespeare for 24 hours on his birthday. And you guessed it, we didn’t sleep.

Twelfth Night goes right along with our mission statement. The show is completely about losing family, creating surrogate families, and of course reuniting families. Ever since we preformed it we have been hard at work creating concepts and planning out the show.

Where your money will go

All the money will go straight into putting up this show. We need things like space rental, a set, lights costumes, props, and so much more.  With your help this show can go up with out our actors having to be naked on stage.

The Company

We are so happy to have our entire company involved in this production along with adding some new faces to the city.(*indicates a new face from the city)


The Production Team:


David Servillo  Director

Alicia Lees*  Costume Designer

Rachel Himmel*  Stage Manger

Robert Francis Curtis  Dramaturg


The Cast Includes:


Alyssa Marie Thordarson  Viola

DJ Douglass  Sir Andrew

Harrison Happin  Malvolio

Joel Ison*  Feste

John Mobley  Sir Toby

Kayla Conrad  Fabian

Matt Duncan*  Sebastion

Megan Caccamo*  Understudy

Ryan Zimmer as Antonio

Sara Linker  Olivia

Stephen Bisinger  The Duke

Tara Grace Southard  Maria


Remember

Even if you cannot help us out financially that’s okay.  You help in a big way just by spreading the word about this show and this company with your friends. Also, if we have already made are goal, feel free to continue to give, and we promise that money will only be used to going into making Twelfth Night better.

story:
Who is writing this blog?

I am Thomas Fant; a twenty-one year old modern dancer from Norfolk, Virginia with the opportunity to spend four weeks this summer dancing in Rochester, NY and Manhattan, NY.

Currently I am a dancer with Todd Rosenlieb Dance, a local modern dance company performing an original repertoire of works by Todd Rosenlieb and Ricardo Melendez, Erick Hawkins, Bill Evans, Jon Lehrer, and Kathy Brenner, as well as classical and contemporary ballet repertoire. The company blends classical and modern forms, the "downtown" spirit, hints of pop culture, and a keen sense of musicality to present a style all its own. An ecclectic sensibility allows for the use of a diverse music palette that ranges from Brahms to Rufus Wainwright.

I believe expression through movement is the most basic and instinctive form of communication, without which beauty cannot be experienced ocularly. Dance is the tool to accomplish this. For some reason modern dance, unlike theater, classical music or literature, is often thought of as fleeting, ephemeral, disposable. But just like any art form, modern dance has a heritage that can, and should, be kept alive. José Limón believed this, and expressed these views through his company. I have been given the chance to learn from his successors, and from the knowledge I will have gained I will have the opportunity to share his dance technique, repertory, and philosophies with subsequent generations of dancers; not only through the preservation of his teachings, but also by incorporating his teachings into contemporary technique.

What's this campaign about?

For two weeks the José Limón Dance Foundation will host an intensive dance study at SUNY College at Brockport. Focusing on the individual, the summer residence offers Limón technique class every day, plus repertory workshop sessions including Limón repertory, ensemble works and solos, new repertory works, performance techniques, principals of the technique set forth by José Limón, composition, somatics, and many more. Special evening activities and individual coaching are also offered throughout the two weeks, and the residency concludes with an informal presentation of repertory and composition.

Toward the end of the summer, the José Limón Dance Foundation will host a two week teaching workshop at NYU Steinhardt examining the use of Humphrey/Limón principles in contemporary dance training. Over the two week workshop each participant will find an individual approach to Limon-based teaching. Classes will consist of daily technique classes, an exploration of the underlying principles, phrases from repertory (contemporary and classic) and the use of rhythm and music in Limon classes. Participants have opportunities to present class materials and contemporary dance phrase sequences based on Limón principles.

Where do you fall into play?

With the help of generous supporters I will be able to raise the funds to realize my goal of taking over the world dancing with this world-class company for the summer. As idealistic as this website makes the fund raising process seem, it isn't solely up to you (nor would I be so idealistic to think it would be), as I plan on raising money on my own, as well. But for those who participate in the fund raising process there are special "perks" I am willing to offer for different levels of contribution. Feel free to check the sidebar to the right to view all the different levels.

  • Currently I have raised $450 from teaching a musical theatre camp; I hope to raise more in the proceeding months!!

I will chronicle my time in residency in a special Dances with Lemons blog, chock-full of stories, photos, videos, songs, movement scores, and notes from the intensive workshops. I hope to interview Carla Maxwell (artistic director), Roxanne D'Orleans Juste (artistic associate), and outstanding members of the Limón Dance Company, as well as tell you all the behind-the-scenes happenings!! As project backers, you'll have a stake in my process, with opportunities to make requests of my documentation, learn about and even ask questions of The Limón Dance company and modern dance in general. You’ll also get regular updates about my month-long experience and receive personalized thank-you's featured in the blog. I will literally be taking you all to New York with me. I really need your contributions to get me there!!

How it all breaks down

The three-thousand dollar amount I am trying to raise will go toward multiple different causes to aid in realizing my goal:

  • $790 - Tuition for summer residency at SUNY Brockport
  • $790 - Tuition for teachers workshop at NYU Steinhardt
  • $630 - Housing & meals @ residency at SUNY Brockport
  • $660 - Total Transportation (trains, planes, automobiles)
  • $130 - Meals for teachers workshop at NYU Steinhardt

If there are any funds that take me past 3,000 dollars, I plan to put them toward the quality and production of my self-made video documentary and my self-made Limón technique and composition tutorial DVD.

I know three thousand dollars seems like a lot of money for four weeks of dance education, but take a look at the programs schedules:

East Coast (SUNY Brockport) Residency:
  • 09:00-09:50  Yoga / Ballet / Breath Work / Pilates
  • 10:00-11:45  Limón Technique Class
  • 13:00-14:30  Limón Repertory / Solo Voice
  • 14:45-16:15  Limón Repertory / Duets & Trios / New Repertory
  • 16:30-17:30  Principles of Limón Technique / Elements of Style
  • 19:00-20:30  Lecture on José Limón & Doris Humphrey / Film Showings
 
Teachers Workshop (NYU Steinhardt) Residency:
  • 10:00-12:00  Technique Class
  • 12:00-12:45  Principles Sessions
  • 12:45-13:30  Lunch and Journal Break
  • 13:30-15:00  Afternoon Workshop
  • 15:00-16:30  Afternoon Workshop
  • 18:00-19:30  Observation at Peridance 

Other Ways You Can Help

If a financial contribution is not in the cards (and believe me, I understand how difficult spending money can be in this current economy), you can still help!!

  • Make some noise. Spread the campaign on every social media site.
  • Follow my blog "Dances with Lemons" and share with everyone you know.
  • If you have friends in the Village who wouldn't mind hosting a dancer in residence at NYU Steinhardt for two weeks, that would be a support. I could help around the residence with chores, or running errands on my down time; anything to keep costs as low as possible.

Please help me realize my summertime journey dancing with and learning from the Limón Dance Company. I cannot do it without you!!

story:
SHORT SUMMARY

DETROIT! Get Ready!  The highly anticipated Diamond Girls stage play is here! The debut will be held on Saturday, November 3 at the Paul Robeson Theater in Detroit, MI. There will be 2 shows: 3:00pm Matinee and an 8:00pm main show.

Diamond Girls is an all new kind of stage play that has never been done before! It’s a dramatic stage play and documentary about:

  • the desperate choices women make when choosing to date drug dealers,
  • the superficial lifestyles they desire to live, and
  • the consequences they face as a result of their choices.    

The stage play will be a vehicle to promote the Diamond Girls full length documentary that will provide victimized women with a platform to tell their true triumphant stories of recovery, restoration & redemption.  This is a story that must be told and heard!  Help us to get the word out by lending your support today!

 

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

WE NEED YOUR HELP!!!

In order to make this project happen WE NEED YOU!!!! Yes, YOU!!!

The money you donate will go towards the production of the stage play, the documentary, and the soundtrack. We have already begun production of the documentary and the soundtrack but additional funding is needed to complete them. Some of our remaining expenses include:

  • Theater Rental
  • Rehearsal Venue Rental
  • Lighting and Sound Rental
  • Set Design and Construction
  • Cast and Crew Expenses
  • Video Crew Expenses (for the taping of the show)
  • Finishing Production of the Documentary
  • Finishing Production of the CD Soundtrack

In exchange for helping us with this worthy endeavor, we have several perks and benefits we’re offering, including play tickets, copies of the documentary and soundtrack, as well as several perks not open to the public, such as behind the scenes footage of the production and entrance to some of the invite only events such as the Soundtrack Listening Party. A detailed list of the perks can be found on the right side of this page.

 

THE IMPACT:  WHY THIS PROJECT IS BEING DONE!

Soul Food Entertainment’s desire for this project is not just to entertain, but to tell a story that hasn't been adequately told, and to deliver a message of hope that will help not only women, but also men, think about the choices they make and how it affects those around them.

The media paints such a glamorous and romantic picture of the street lifestyle when there's so much death and destruction attached to it.

Our goals are to

  • remove the mask of glamor attached to the street life
  • show the lifestyle for what it really is: a life full of pain, disappointment, death, and lost and stolen dreams...and
  • give people hope that it's never too late to change and turn things around for the better.

We believe that this project will touch many lives and cause many to soul search and rethink their decisions, as well as make them laugh and be entertained. Eventually, this play will tour around the country as well as be turned into an actual full length feature film. We even plan to start a Diamond Girls non-profit organization that will help young women turn their lives around!.

We must start somewhere and this play is simply a stepping stone for getting started! WITH YOUR HELP, WE CAN START SOMETHING THAT WILL BE MORE THAN JUST A PLAY, or a movie, or a soundtrack...we can start a Diamond Girls MOVEMENT!!!

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

We understand that whatever we raise is a blessing, however, if for some reason a donation isn’t in the budget at this time, we would certainly appreciate you spreading the word!!!

Please send out the link to this campaign to all your Facebook friends, Twitter followers, Linked In contacts, email contacts, etc. Indiegogo has made it easy to share the link...so even if you're not in a position to donate, please help us get the word out about this project!!!

Thank you and God Bless!

story:
Cool Stuff at Theatre Project

Since 1971, Theatre Project has been at the forefront of presenting what’s next in performance. New work in theatre, dance, music, poetry, puppetry, multi-media, performance art, and things that defy description have all debuted here. For the last several seasons, much of our focus has been concentrated on presenting new and exciting emerging artists from right here in the Greater Baltimore area.

But, we are also dedicated to connecting our audiences with a global community of performers. To that end we are always looking to expand our offerings from outside of Baltimore. In the coming months we have scheduled three different productions, in three different genres, from all over the map, including New York, Israel, and Southeast Asia (by way of Chicago.) We have created the ongoing Cool Stuff at Theatre Project campaign to help us bring these shows to Baltimore.

Part One: Room 17B

In May, New York based Parallel Exit, masters of physical comedy and visual theatre, are coming with their smash hit Room 17B.

It’s like your job ... but weirder.

In a vague, yet familiar office setting, a highly accomplished cast of four actors put on a delightful series of skits, blackouts, gags, and pranks. Room 17B is a comedy that celebrates the silent physical style of Charlie Chaplin and Buster Keaton with a dash of Monty Python and Tim & Eric. 9 to 5 will never be the same!

"65 minutes of outlandish incongruity ... charming ... amusing ... perfect" -  New York Times

“Room 17B is like an anthology of clown haikus - a series of self-contained routines, each one brief, elegant and perfectly balanced.” - The New York Post

"A charming 65 minutes of pure fun." - Theater Mania

"Four Stars" - Time Out New York

Room 17B has appeared at 59E59 Theaters in New York City, and has toured throughout the United States and Europe. It features an ensemble of four, blending physical comedy, dance, live music, and audience participation.

What do we need?

Bringing great shows to Theatre Project isn't cheap. We pay performance fees, transportation, meals and lodging. Fortunately, we have a wonderful partner working with us on Room 17B. Quest Visual Theatre, an organization dedicated to the presentation of inclusive theatre emanating from a visual base, is our co-presenter and is picking up some of the costs associated with the show. But we still need your help!

Theatre Project needs to raise $2,500 to cover our costs for bringing the show to you.

What do you get?

Other than our undying gratitude, we are offering a few perks to pique your interest. 

  • $25 gets you a program listing and two free drinks at Theatre Project
  • $50 gets you all of the above and a ticket to the show
  • $100 gets you a program listing, two free drinks, and two tickets
  • $250 gets you the above and an invitation for you and one other person to participate in a physical theatre workshop by members of Parallel Exit.

Spread the word!

So tell your friends ... tell your co-works ... tell complete strangers you happen to meet. "Like" it ... tweet it ... text it. Google it ... tumbl it ... pin it. Use whatever social tools you have at your disposal, or just shout about it at the top of your lungs. It is a really terrific show. Please help us make it happen.

What's next?

Cool Stuff at Theatre Project: Part Two will be coming soon!

Tiny puppets, live cinema, and vegetables collide in Puppet Cinema’s epic space odyssey, Planet Egg. When an outer-space Robot crash-lands on a mysterious planet, he encounters locals unlike anyone he’s ever known. Cultural misunderstandings, murder, romance, forgiveness, and revenge abound on this all-organic world as our Robot seeks a way home. Performed and filmed live with a full score of live Foley, Planet Egg creates both an intimacy with the puppets and a cinematic grandness worthy of a space odyssey. This unique theatrical experience is not to be missed.

Originally conceived by Israeli puppeteer Zvi Sahar at Haifa University, with the support of Cheryl Henson (Muppet creator Jim Henson’s daughter), Planet Egg has been performed in New York, Honolulu, and at last year’s D.C. Fringe Festival. It will be coming to Theatre Project in July!!!!

Thank You!
story_txt:
Cool Stuff at Theatre Project
Since 1971, Theatre Project has been at the forefront of presenting what’s next in performance. New work in theatre, dance, music, poetry, puppetry, multi-media, performance art, and things that defy description have all debuted here. For the last several seasons, much of our focus has been concentrated on presenting new and exciting emerging artists from right here in the Greater Baltimore area.
But, we are also dedicated to connecting our audiences with a global community of performers. To that end we are always looking to expand our offerings from outside of Baltimore. In the coming months we have scheduled three different productions, in three different genres, from all over the map, including New York, Israel, and Southeast Asia (by way of Chicago.) We have created the ongoing Cool Stuff at Theatre Project campaign to help us bring these shows to Baltimore.


Part One: Room 17B

In May, New York based Parallel Exit, masters of physical comedy and visual theatre, are coming with their smash hit Room 17B. 
It’s like your job ... but weirder.

story:
Summary:

Footprints - A new play by Molly Noonan

 

Hi folks! "Footprints" is a "queer romantic drama," and very near to my heart. It would mean everything to be able to fully produce it.

"What do you do when the footprints stop?"

Lost in a minefield, a deserting soldier looking for answers relives the pain of repressing his sexuality and love for a best friend and fellow soldier. 

"Footprints" will be touring the Vancouver Island Fringe Festivals in August 2013, and between entrance fees and production costs, we need all the help we can get!

What We Need & What You Get:

The bulk amount of fundraising will go to helping us get a rehearsal space. Having worked on productions that involve always scrounging for space in some unused classroom, I know that the effect of having a steady, work-oriented space all our own has an amazingly positive effect on a show.

Additionally, as "Footprints" is a WWII period piece, we need a budget for costumes, set and props. Though 100% period realism is unrealistic for us, to illustrate the danger of the same-sex relationship in the piece, the setting must be real enough to place our audience in the right state of mind. 

We will be recognizing and thanking everyone who donates in our show's program, and you will have our eternal love and gratitude!

For those who can afford to give in somewhat greater amounts, we'll be reserving spots for the first four high-bidders to have a mentioned character in the show named after them! How cool is that?! Additionally, anyone donating $100 or more will be happily granted two complimentary tickets. We wish we could do more comps for our donors, but we also rely heavily on our ticket sales to fund our entrance fees. 

The Impact

Your generous donations are helping to produce a piece of theatre that is ultimately about self-acceptance, the pain of repression, and how much two people can truly mean to one another. Each donation helps us construct the world of the show so we can get our message across with a clear, passionate voice.

Also, can you imagine how awesome the very first investors in a fledgling production of "Les Miserables" must feel about themselves today? That could be YOU!

Other Ways You Can Help

I realize that many of you aren't able to donate, but you too can help our cause! Please share this campaign with anyone who believes in the social and political power of storytelling!

And of course, you can help us get our audience! Talk us up, and of course bring all your friends to see us this summer in the Nanaimo and Victoria Fringe Festivals!

Thank you all so much!

 

-Molly Noonan

story:
SHIFT Theatre Society is a non-profit organization from Vancouver, BC.  


Run by Artistic Managing Director Nick Sartore and General Manager Kelsey Wood, SHIFT Theatre is an artistic collective of emerging artists who work collaboratively to create contemporary, relevant, and stimulating theatre. Our work is artistically accessible while providing opportunities to present new, unpublished theatre and non-traditional staging’s of published works.  

We need to raise $2,000 to support our upcoming shows Seascape with Sharks and Dancer by Don Nigro and our annual 1-Act Festival of short plays.

Here's why we need the money

Seascape with Shark and Dancer:

  • Production Fees: $500
  • Set Materials: $250
  • Wardrobe and makeup: $250

1-Act Festival 6:

  • Production Fees: $750

  • Administrative Expenses: $250

What you'll get

In exchange for your contributions we’ve developed some awesome perks for you to enjoy.  Each perk level is displayed on the side.  Donate before April 1, 2013 to be entered for a chance to win the early bird prize of (4) tickets to Seascape with Sharks and Dancer.


The Impact


SHIFT Theatre is an artistic collective of emerging artists who work collaboratively to create contemporary, relevant, and stimulating theatre.   As a small company we rely on ticket sales and contributions from people like you!  This year Nick, Kelsey, Christina and the Board of Directors are going full throttle to make this season (our biggest) be our most successful to-date. We need your help through donations to ease the financial costs of producing the shows.  

The Shows


Seascape with Sharks & Dancer by Don Nigro, directed by Nick Sartore
April 11-20, 2013 @ CBC Studio 700

    “On a solitary walk along the misty coast in the middle of the night, an aspiring novelist fishes a drowning young woman out of the surf. Soon, she finds herself trapped in his life and torn between her need to come to rest somewhere and her certainty that all human relationships turn eventually into nightmares. This dynamic work takes the audience inside this challenged, volatile, and often abusive relationship of these two young lovers.

    The struggle between his tolerant and gently ironic approach to life and her strategy of suspicion and attack becomes a kind of war about love and creation which neither can afford to lose.”

SHIFT 1-Act Festival 6– various artists.
June 13 - 15 @ The Cultch’s Vancity Culture lab – Vancouver, BC
June 20-22 @ Evergreen Cultural Centre – Coquitlam, BC

    “SHIFT’s annual festival of short plays returns for its sixth anniversary and features a selection of fresh, original shorts all under one hour from artists around Vancouver and the Tri-Cities. In 2012, the festival broke records, playing to sell-out crowds for its first presentation at The Cultch in Vancouver. This year, the festival returns to The Cultch and is introduced at its new home in Coquitlam in association with the Evergreen Cultural Centre.”


Past Projects

  • Nate and Troy: The Next Big Things, January 2013
  • Closer, November 2012
  • SHIFT 1-Act Festival 5, June 2012
  • The Closer Variations, April 2012
  • Surrealist Night, Port Moody Festival of the Arts, September 2011
  • SHIFT 1-Act Festival ‘11, June 2011
  • Purely Cabaret, November 2010


More About Us


SHIFT was founded in 2008 to provide emerging theatre artists with opportunities to stage unconventional, risk-taking productions of short theatre. The company is producers of the celebrated 1-Act Festival, a daring festival of original works and new staging’s taking place annually at Port Moody’s Inlet Theatre and successfully at The Cultch in June 2012.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the Word! Tell others about our project and our campaign. If you don't have the money to donate, tell others who might. You never know who might be supportive of the cause. Share this with friends and family using the “share” button. You can also support these shows by purchasing tickets to see them.

Not sure about donating online? Make a donation by cheque to the address below! You'll still get the perks!

Got stuff? We can always use in-kind donations for our set, costumes, and production expenses.

Got time? We're always looking for enthusiastic volunteers to join our team.

Got a business? Ask us about sponsorship and how to advertise in our program guides.

Want to know more? Join our mailing list! Find out about SHIFT events and help us broaden our audience base in the process.

Have questions before you support? Of course! Contact us at any time and we will be more than happy to talk with you about what we do...

info@shifttheatre.ca

170-422 Richards Street
Vancouver, BC
Canada V6B 2Z4

www.shifttheatre.ca

Follow us!  @SHIFTtheatre
Become a fan!  www.facebook.com/SHIFTtheatre
Learn more!  www.shifttheatre.ca

story:
Short Summary

Shalom! My name is Aaron M. Davidson and I’m a Chicago-based theater artist and musician, spending the past 10 years working professionally across the country as an AEA (Actors Equity Association) actor. 

My writing partner Reace Daniel and I wrote an original TYA (Theater for Young Audiences) musical and we are asking for your help to bring this project to its next step!

Reace and I met in the spring of 2017 as actors in a show in Colorado. After spending a lunch break talking about our passion for professional children's theater and our desire to write an original story for the next generation, Reace came back the next day with 20 pages. He exclaimed, "I don't know what the hell happened last night, but I couldn't stop writing and this came out!" The next day I wrote the first song and Watercolors was officially born.

After a year of writing, Watercolors is ready for workshopping- that’s where you come in!     

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $4,200 towards two very important steps in our process: 

  • Music Notation and Orchestration: $2,000-$2,500 

As a composer I can write the music and make the demos, but I don’t have the polished skill of creating fully notated sheet music/charts to give actors and musicians. I am working alongside a top orchestrator in Chicago to make this happen. They are a joy to work with and highly skilled, but they are not cheap! I'm talking a rate of $75/hour. 

  • Week-long Workshop Process/Performance: $2,000-$2,500

This is the really exciting step for me. This is where we get to hear and see the words and notes performed. This process allows Reace and I to watch and listen to what we have written, to learn what works and what doesn't. It will allow us to invite industry professionals as well as potential producers to view a well-executed presentation. Most importantly, we will have an additional presentation for a group of children to get their feedback, a step that other TYA seldom takes. 

This will entail...

  • Six actors
  • One director
  • One music director
  • One stage manager
  • Performace space
  • Rehearsal space
  • Printing capabilities

We are committed to paying respectable wages for all artists in this workshop. With the minimum pay for an AEA actor between $125-$225 (depending on the final schedule), you can see how it all adds up quickly. 

The Impact

We hope to affect the hearts of those that battle feeling left out and alone each day because of discrimination. The TYA community is one that can grow and flourish with new visions. Your support means championing the work of an emerging writing team, bringing our original voice to the stage with a unique sound. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't in a place to donate that is okay! Share this campaign on social media so we can get the word out. Get someone in your circle to donate!

If you actually took the time to make it all the way to the end of this, you are the greatest and thank you for your support!

story:
We are a group of artists known as The Team, and we are putting on a show October 16, 17 & 18. It will be an interactive, multi-sensory experience for a moving audience within a former cosmetic manufacturing building. 

Inspired by the history of working women, Please Wear Appropriate Attire is a contemporary dance performance about women, attire and the pressure to conform. For 5 nights in mid-October, an audience will witness a unique dance on each floor of the building: an imaginary ride through the world of female office workers, a raucous fashion show displaying fantastical attire, and a dance about the tension between skin and clothing. Between each act, the audience is invited to enjoy refreshments, discuss their own attire, and peruse photography and video installations.


The Team was founded by dancer/choreographers Michelle Marroquin, Marya Moylan and Katelyn Cramer. We collaborate with artists of any media to make original work that engages our community in dialogue about relevant social issues.

Other members of The Team include composer and local guitar artist Tony Silva,  and dancers Mayumi Doyama and Danica Arehart. Please Wear Appropriate Attire collaborators include: musicians Alisa Beaver (cello) and Liz Rose (viola), and sculptor Alicia Renadette who is designing costumes for the fashion show. Photographers Katja Fournier and Tracey Eller muse on the connection between clothes and identity, and video artist Sam Cramer interviews women about their clothing choices for work.

There are many expenses involved in running a show, including rental of equipment, costumes and so on. But we are intentionally keeping expenses low so that donations go to humans, not things. Your contribution will be used primarily to pay 5 hardworking dancers, 2 musicians, a composer, a videographer and a technical crew.

When you support this project you are saying Yes! to working artists, Yes! to  engaging, innovative art, and Yes! to activating our community. When you make a donation to this project you are propelling the artistic and cultural life of our small town in Massachusetts.

1. Submit a donation! Even small contributions make a difference. Click on the "Contribute Now" link at the top of this page.

2. Cut and Paste the following text onto your social media page:

Please Wear Appropriate Attire is a very cool, theatrical event happening October 16-18 in Easthampton, MA that needs our support. Please go to THIS LINK to find out more about it and consider making a donation! Thank you for supporting the arts! (Add an Image)

3. Email 3-5 people personally, send this link, and ask them to make a donation.

4. Volunteer!  We need ushers, coat checkers, light and sound techies, and a bartender. What would you like to do?

THANK YOU

We can't do this without your help. If everyone who receives this link makes a contribution we will make our goal. Thank you for your support!

But we are intentionally keeping expenses low so that donations go to humans, not things. Your contribution will be used primarily to pay 5 hardworking dancers, 2 musicians, a composer, a videographer and a technical crew.When you support this project you are saying Yes! to working artists, Yes! to  engaging, innovative art, and Yes! to activating our community. When you make a donation to this project you are propelling the artistic and cultural life of our small town in Massachusetts.

2. Cut and Paste the following text onto your social media page:
Please Wear Appropriate Attire is a very cool, theatrical event happening October 16-18 in Easthampton, MA that needs our support. Please go to THIS LINK to find out more about it and consider making a donation! Thank you for supporting the arts! (Add an Image)
3. Email 3-5 people personally, send this link, and ask them to make a donation.
4. Volunteer!  We need ushers, coat checkers, light and sound techies, and a bartender. What would you like to do?
THANK YOU
We can't do this without your help. If everyone who receives this link makes a contribution we will make our goal. Thank you for your support!

story:
Developing brain cells, heart strings & characters. . . nationwide.

WHAT WE DO

Capital City Theatre ("CCT") is Madison’s professional regional musical theatre company blending national and local talent.  Just this past summer, CCT produced a highly acclaimed production of GYPSY, starring Broadway’s Michele Ragusa at Overture Center.  However, what many don’t realize is that CCT’s Educational Program is the cornerstone of the company’s mission.  We offer courses ranging from on-stage performing to backstage technical emphasis. Students come from all over the country to study in these disciplines with CCT professionals in our beautiful home of Madison, Wisconsin. Many are considered in casting and perform in our productions as well,  right next to Broadway stars, nationally renowned directors, and some of the best in the business of stagecraft.  Musical theatre education has become increasingly more important as the number of students auditioning for college educational programs has quadrupled in the last six years!  CCT wants to fill that niche and help students learn skills that will make them stand out in the board room or on the stage. We are providing unique and comprehensive opportunities. We invite students from anywhere to join us. We are grooming future generations of musical theatre professionals, creative thinkers, disciplined achievers, good colleagues and ardent devotees.

ESTABLISHED PROGRAMS

Our success started five years ago with Find Your Light, this standout summer musical theatre intensive focused on the stage performer. Since then, this program has almost doubled in size each year with the age of its participants ranging from 13-40. There are now three levels of Find Your Light and over five weeks in the summer; these burgeoning musical theatre performers study everything from musical theatre history and proper vocal health to “acting the song” and finding audition material . CCT also offers the College Prep Course for those high school students who are preparing to audition for college programs in the next year or two. For both Find Your Light and the College Prep Course, industry professionals are brought in to work with the students and give them extra guidance.  In the past this has included such talented people as Telly Leung (Bway Performer), Jim Weitzer (Bway's Phantom of the Opera), Kaitlin Hopkins (Bway/TV performer and head of Texas State University musical theatre program), and mock audition adjudicators representing faculty from University of Wisconsin Steven's Point, Viterbo, and Chicago College of Performing Arts - Roosevelt University. Watch Kaitlin Hopkin's Ted Talk HERE.

In addition to musical theatre preparation courses, CCT also offers hands-on internships in various capacities.  These can be anything from being an assistant director or production assistant on a main stage production to working side by side with a lighting designer (or doing administration and publicity work in our office). These internships really immerse our students in the aspects of musical theatre that they are most passionate about. Watch this season’s star, Michele Ragusa give chills as she sings "Everything's Coming Up Roses!" Listen to our Gypsy director, Jeff Whiting give a TED Talk on Rising Beyond Limits with Open Jar Thinking. View our photo library of last season’s Violet and see two of our FYL students in Action with our stars of 2015.

NEW PROGRAMS

This year we proudly announce two additional upcoming exceptional programs!!

The CCT Stagecraft Studio is a four-hour workshop that focuses on the crucial “behind the scenes” components of a production. Local experts provide insight and HANDS ON experience in areas such as lighting, sound design, costumes, props, etc.

Our Young Musical Theatre Writers Competition is open to anyone aged 15-22. Each participant is asked to create a 10-15 minute musical on their own. Experienced guidance will be provided by professionals in the field in the form of feedback, workshops and seminars. The competition will be split into two divisions: High school and College. The winning entries will be produced by CCT and performed by local professionals in February of 2017. 

CAPITAL CITY THEATRE’S EDUCATIONAL MISSION

To be a mid-west leading musical theatre training program employing a holistic approach that encompasses the major disciplines of singing, acting, dancing and other stagecrafts resulting in a well-balanced artist who exudes confidence, creativity, and collaborative skills.

The future of Capital City Theatre is now! These exciting and customized programs will encourage and motivate young people to explore careers in the arts. Capital City Theatre plans to build upon these passionate minds and proudly help them thrive and flourish in a vibrant arts communities all over the world! We thank you for your continued support.


CAPITAL CITY THEATRE'S COMPANY MISSION

Capital City Theatre, Inc. produces professional and engaging live musical theatre performances, educates the next generation of musical theatre artists through workshops and intensives and inspires Madison area and visiting audiences by connecting them with talented performers from across the country. We hope to make Madison a destination for the Arts!

Andrew Abrams - Artistic Director
Gail Becker - Director of Education

story:
The Situation

I started dancing at 5, and haven't stopped since. In the passing years, my passion for the arts, as well as my desire to help people engage with the arts, has only strengthened. This is why I'm creating a space to help artists create and display new works. Here, artists can come together, find community, and create something great.

Georgetown has not been a destination for the performing arts, and that is what I would like to change with the creation of Yaw Theater. I would like to create an environment of collaboration and potential for artists, as well as keeping it accessible to anyone and everyone who would has a curiosity about the arts.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $6000. This will help Yaw by providing funds for-

  • Theater Lighting
  • Sprung Floor
  • Seating for Audiences
  • Mirrors
  • Performance Quality Sound System

We are offering a number of unique perks  for a variety of budgets, from high fives to personalized shows, event space to unique-to-you dance performances!

 

The Impact

Once Yaw Theater is up and running, local dancers and performers will have an easy and affordable space to rehearse and produce works and collaborate with the other artists found in the Equinox Industrial Arts Complex. Other benefits include-

  • An affordable space for local teachers to rent and hold class
  • An event space for groups to rent
  • A place for summer camps exploring a variety of arts disciplines 

 

Risks & Challenges

Opening a brand new space is not an easy task. There will be a variety of risks and challenges in this process, I am certain. But this is something I believe the city of Seattle needs, and something that will benefit the arts community greatly. Yaw Theater is a labor of love that I am prepared to put in the work to nurture the community I find remarkable and inspiring.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute today, don't worry! You can still help!

  • Share this campaign on your social media! Let people know you feel strongly about the arts!
  • Want to volunteer your time? Contact us and see what we have available!

story:
Feed the Kitchen 

ONLY THREE REMAINING SHOWS

Monday Nov 14th 8pm

Wednesday Nov 16th 8pm

Thursday Nov 17th 8pm

Chez Poulet 3359 Cesar Chavez St, San Francisco, CA 94110

 

Tickets are no longer available on this fundraiser but can be purchased at

www.brownpapertickets.com/event/2713854

 

From Rapid Descent’s artistic director Megan Finlay:

The show is an immersive and experiential piece inspired both by my desire for theatre that touches people in a more lasting and multi layered way, and the 20 plus years I have spent working as a chef to fund my life as an artist.

Feed the Kitchen has been created by its cast, writer Lisa Drostova, who has spent over 20 years working in the food service industry, and me.  It features Jenny Gamboa, chef and performer; Tess Middlebrook, chef, comedian and performer; Ian Greeb, performer, character fabricator and puppeteer; Cason MacBride, performer, clown and dancer; and Ronja Ver, performer and dancer..

This show is a crazy and ambitious project. I am blessed to have a super talented cast and crew to work with on it’s creation and we would love your support to help us make it happen, and your appetites to sample both the 4 course tasting menu and the show that we serve it to you in!

How much are tickets?

There are two tiers of ticket prices for Feed the Kitchen.

VIP ticket holders get finger food before the show, VIP wine and front row seats as well as being served a 4 course tasting menu. VIP tickets are $55.

Standard ticket holders are served a 4 course tasting menu. Standard tickets are $38

Let's get to the important part: What do you get to eat?

As part of the action and story of Feed the Kitchen you, the audience, will be fed a 4 course tasting menu as follows:

Rustic Seasonal Vegetable Tart with roast parsnip, leeks, carrot, Brussels sprouts, ricotta, parmesan and gruyère

Roast Butternut Squash Soup with pumpkin seed pistou and coconut cream

Cinque Pazzi Meat Balls with celeriac and Yukon gold mash, marinara sauce and fried sage

or

Amaranth and smoky black bean balls with celeriac and Yukon gold mash, marinara sauce and fried sage

Dark Chocolate Mousse with red wine cherries, whipped cream and chocolate swirl shortbread

*vegetarian, vegan, gluten free and dairy free options available

story:
Short Summary

I'm Rick Reischman and I've been an actor since High School.  Beyond Therapy is my favorite play, and Bruce has always been a dream role for me, so that's why I'm putting it on for Long Beach Playhouse's Collaborative Season.  The Collaborative Season is a way for independent companies like mine to put on shows using the upstairs studio stage, but we have to provide all of our own funding.  I'm trying to raise some money to cover the cost of the production to put on the best show that we can.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $2,000.00 to cover the basics for this campaign.  Your contribution will help us with:

  • Building the set including furniture and set dressing
  • Provide scripts for the cast 
  • Costumes
  • Props
  • Rights for the show
  • Theater Rental Space
  • Advertising materials such as posters, flyers and postcards
  • Programs for the audience

We are an amateur theater company, which means we can't offer pay.  However if we raise enough money, we may be able to offer compensation for our actors, director and crew.

What do you get in return?  You'll get a great (we hope) show!  The best way to support the show is to come and see it.  Tickets are available now on the Long Beach Playhouse's Website!  Get them here for:

  • February: http://boxoffice.printtixusa.com/longbeachplayhouse/eventcalendar?v=0&i=0&g=0&g2=0&m=2&y=2017
  • March:  http://boxoffice.printtixusa.com/longbeachplayhouse/eventcalendar?v=0&i=0&g=0&g2=0&m=3&y=2017

If you can't go to the show, but still want to support it with money, consider one of our perks!  We have several perks available and may even include some special surprises for higher tiers.  You'll get your name in our program and special thanks from the cast and crew and maybe even some signed photos.

If we don't reach our funding goal, don't worry.  We will still get whatever was donated to us.  All funds will go towards funding the production with the rest contributed by me.  

The Impact

This is the first time even attempting to produce my own play, so your help will be invaluable.  If this is succesful, we may continue to produce plays even producing some of my own unpublished work.  Your contribution will really make this dream a reality, and you'll get to say you are a patron of the arts.  Who doesn't want that?

Risks & Challenges

Putting on your own show can be expensive, but we are looking to keep costs low so we can put on the best show that we can for the least amount of money.  Independently producing a show can also result in low turnout.  We hope you can help be spreading the word, but financially getting some advertising on social media as well as flyers, posters and postcards will help also.

I've had some success with producing my own short films, and plan on using other talented people in helping me to put this on.  I'm building a team to make this the best possible show we can do.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, I completely understand, but you can still help in other ways.  Pass this along to your friends and family and ask them to contribute, or just tell everyone about our play and ask them to come and see it!  Hand out flyers, or post cards, or email or call people.  There are a number of ways you can help get the word out, and believe me, we can use the help!

Thanks for taking the time to read through our proposal and thank you for any help you can give us.

Thanks for taking the time to read through our proposal and thank you for any help you can give us.

story:
What We Need

  • We are looking to raise $5,000.  Big goals for big dreams!
  • This funding is going towards the insurance needed to run the academy, renting facilities, equipment and supplies, hiring the best guest artists and teachers we can find, snacks and water for the young performers, t-shirts and branding to get the word out about Drama Kids Studio!

The Impact

  • We are excited to bring quality arts and performance education at an affordable rate, in a city that's not so affordable.  We want theatre and acting to be accessible to the kids who have the craving to learn more, despite their financial situation.
  • This is not the first arts program we have created from the ground up.  A few years ago, we created a full after school program for the Tuscaloosa Elementary Magnet School, that culminated in a fully realized production. We ran this for several semesters, with incredible feedback from the kids and parents! Tommy has spent the past several years as the Theatre Director of Camp Barney-Medintz in Atlanta, putting together a full summer of theatre programs, activities, education, as well as two full scale productions involving hundreds of children.

Risks & Challenges

  • We are very lucky to have the support of Access Theater, who donated their beautiful space for our kick off workshop day!  We hope to continue our relationship with Access Theater, and would also like to be able to pay them for their space and kindness!
  • Finding affordable spaces with the capacity we need in NYC is not easy.  Your support will help put us in a position to provide the best environment possible for our Drama Kids as they learn and grow.
  • We chose the year we're getting married to start a business from the ground up. Crazy! When the time is right, you have to jump on it! Your funding will help us not lose our minds during this very expensive year we've created for ourselves. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Join our mailing list! Want to learn more about our plans and programs? Email dramakidsstudio@gmail.com to join and follow.
  • Help us get the word out!  We have been  receiving incredible social media support so far, and would love if you would continue following and sharing!
  • Instagram: @dramakidsstudio
  • Twitter: @dramakidsstudio
  • Facebook: Drama Kids Studio

Thank you to everyone for helping us make this dream come true!

story:
The Phase is an award-winning new contemporary pop-punk musical written by Meg McGrady & Zoe Morris about friendship, young love and singing loud when others want to silence you.

It’s 2014, Gay marriage has just been legalised in the UK, and Rowan and their LGBTQ+ bandmates want to sing it from the rooftops. But their all-girl Catholic school has other ideas. Disbanded and reprimanded, the group has a choice: do they bow down, retreat, and let the school rules divide them? Or, through all the angsty mess of adolescence, do they unite and fight back to make a change?

The show started in 2018 when writers Meg McGrady and Zoe Morris met at musical theatre writing course, Book, Music and Lyrics (BML). Since then, the show has won awards, been featured on musical theatre podcasts, performed at The Other Palace and gained over 45,000 TikTok followers. With two young people writing the show we’ve found many young people relate to the show and the topics it discusses like growing up and finding your identity. We also want this show to help parents, guardians, teachers and friends to understand the thoughts and experiences that young people go through during the turbulent times of adolescence.  

The Phase is a coming of age story that everyone can enjoy, filled with catchy pop songs that you won’t be able to get out of your head! A hugely exciting piece of new British musical theatre written by two upcoming, award-winning writers.

We are raising money to support the development of The Phase with a workshop taking place in October 2020.  After several read-throughs to help finesse the script and songs, this workshop is a wonderful opportunity to get the show on its feet and explore how the show will stylistically look on stage. It will also give us an opportunity to show what we have to a small, invited, socially distanced, audience including  industry professionals, prospective venues and investors.  

We need your help to put this workshop on so we can pay all respective performers, creatives, band members and to hire a rehearsal space. More details about the budget are shown further down. 

Every pound you contribute allows us to embark on this musical adventure together, with the ultimate goal of putting the show on at the Edinburgh Fringe 2021. We’ll keep you updated on how the show is progressing through and after the workshop. As a backer we guarantee that you’ll feel informed and empowered to be a part of this musical journey. We really feel that this is only the beginning of something really special!

The show started as a passion project but has since become something much greater than that! Our 45,000 TikTok followers have proven how timely and important this show is and how so many young people crave to see this musical. 

With two young people writing the show we’ve found many young people relate to the show and the topics it discusses like growing up and finding your identity. We also want this show to help parents, guardians, teachers and friends to understand the thoughts and experiences that young people go through during the turbulent times of adolescence. 

By donating to The Phase you'll be helping make this show a reality. The workshop is our next stage in development before we prepare for the Edinburgh Fringe 2021.

We pride ourselves in that The Phase is written by a young writing team who have written a wonderfully genuine and authentic story, as it is partly based on their own experiences at school.

 

MEG MCGRADY (MUSIC/LYRICS)

Meg (they/them) is a twenty-one-year-old nonbinary composer and performer. Other writing credits include: an untitled Rosalind Franklin musical; Tom Brown‘s School Days (The Other Palace); and Camp-In-Between. Meg is also one of the founders of Sinqueerly Me, a cabaret night highlighting queer woman and nonbinary people in musical theatre. 

 

ZOE MORRIS (BOOK/LYRICS) 

Zoe (she/her) is a lyricst, book writer and occasional dramaturg and director. She has a Masters in Directing from Mountview Academy of Theatre Arts and has worked on multiple productions as a director, dramaturg, and science advisor. Credits include: Boujie (Drayton Arms); DIY: how to become visible (Tristan Bates); Made in Dagenham (Bernie Grant).

 

MARTHA GEELAN (DIRECTOR/DRAMATURG)

Martha (she/her) is a theatre director, dramaturg and educational workshop leader from London. As Associate Director to Trevor Nunn, productions include: Fiddler on the Roof, Love in Idleness (West End/Menier Chocolate Factory); The Bridges of Madison County (Menier Chocolate Factory); Agnes Callander (Theatre Royal Bath). Their current project together is new Stiles and Drewe musical Identical, based on the story of The Parent Trap. As Director: St. Anne Comes Home (St Paul’s Church, Covent Garden); Macbeth, The Tempest, Romeo and Juliet, Twelfth Night (The Young Shakespeare Company, UK & International Tours); The Psychosocial Gathering, The Librarians (Edinburgh Festival Fringe); Wolf (The Bunker Theatre); Spring Awakening: The Musical, Love and Money (Studio Theatre, Norwich); Our New Girl (extract, Park Theatre London); Between the Sheets, Potato Salad, When I Wake (Waterloo East Theatre); As You Might Like It (Rosemary Branch Theatre).

 

KATIE WILMORE (PRODUCER)

Katie (she/her) is a Musical Theatre Producer originally from Yorkshire. She works as a Production Assistant for Kenny Wax Family Entertainment working on productions in the West End, regionally and internationally. She is also the Co-Founder and Producer of Shook Productions; an evening of new writing giving young creatives a platform to share their work with a live audience.

 

JAMES LEGGAT (PRODUCER)

James (he/him) is the Co-Founder and Lead Producer of Edinburgh Fringe Company, Room 29 Theatre. He was also previously a Senior Account Executive at West End Marketing Agency, AKA Promotions where he worked on productions including Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, COMPANY and True West.

CONTRIBUTE if you have the means to do so. If you can support The Phase, please do donate and you’ll be rewarded with some special perks! We have perks available from £5 up to £250, but every penny counts.   

INVEST if you wish to truly be a part of the team developing The Phase. Please email us for more information on how to do this.   

SHARE the fundraiser with your friends and family. The further and wider this goes the more opportunities we have to get support.  Help us spread the good word!

FOLLOW us on social media. We’re on nearly all social media channels where you can find content and updates of our progress.

As mentioned previously this development money will go towards a workshop. This is an opportunity to test and trial new music and script changes. 

As well as supporting our workshop, the money raised through this campaign will allow us to provide cool rewards for our backers. 

It is very important to us that we remain transparent, so we have created this handy chart to highlight how the money will be distributed. 

As seen above we are committed to paying everyone involved in the workshop including the performers, band members and creatives. Particularly during these trying times for creatives we do not want to commit to putting anything on without paying everyone involved. 

We want to give you the coolest and most-high quality rewards, all of which are exclusive to this crowdfunding campaign, which means you won't be able to find this merch anywhere else!

We’re thrilled to offer the following exclusive rewards as a thank you for supporting The Phase!

(All products shown above are prototypes, but we expect them to look similar to the composites we’ve shared with you. Please also note that any rewards connected to the workshop may have to be adjusted based on government guidelines that might change during the workshop. If things do change and you are unable to attend in person we will provide you with a private digital version of the workshop)

If we are unable to hit our target the money provided will not go to waste. It will still go towards the workshop but we have elements we can scale back on including elements of tech and extras like photography. We have also included contingency within the budget above. 

If we do hit our target, we will update you with a new target. Any extra money raised will support the continued development of The Phase after the workshop. This will include script readings, further music workshops and the Edinburgh Fringe production.

With the theatre industry in such a place of uncertainty we are very aware of the risks of putting on any form of theatrical presentation. We are also very conscious of the safety concerns of rehearsing and workshopping a show. 

To address this our creative team are implementing safety measures to make sure the workshop will be as safe for the team and actors as possible. It will follow the strict government guidelines available including at least 1 metres distance between performers, no sharing of scripts or props, and masks must be worn to and from rehearsals. Our producers and director are already experienced in running socially distanced, safe rehearsals having recently put on a new musical in August at the Actors' Church, Courtyard. You can view the full guidelines here we will be following. 

We are also conscious that a public performance may not be achievable in person at the end of the workshop. We are looking at solutions to achieve a live stream for our audience and some of our higher level backers. 

We have a fantastic team of producers, directors and creatives ready for any hurdles provided.

First, please do check our FAQ section found on the link at the top. If we do not answer your question there we are readily available to help. Send us an email at phasemusical@gmail.com​
story_txt: The Phase is an award-winning new contemporary pop-punk musical written by Meg McGrady & Zoe Morris about friendship, young love and singing loud when others want to silence you.It’s 2014, Gay marriage has just been legalised in the UK, and Rowan and their LGBTQ+ bandmates want to sing it from the rooftops. But their all-girl Catholic school has other ideas. Disbanded and reprimanded, the group has a choice: do they bow down, retreat, and let the school rules divide them? Or, through all the angsty mess of adolescence, do they unite and fight back to make a change?The show started in 2018 when writers Meg McGrady and Zoe Morris met at musical theatre writing course, Book, Music and Lyrics (BML). Since then, the show has won awards, been featured on musical theatre podcasts, performed at The Other Palace and gained over 45,000 TikTok followers. With two young people writing the show we’ve found many young people relate to the show and the topics it discusses like growing up and finding your identity. story:
[EN summary below]

Ar gali būti laimingas ir mylimas, jei esi “kitoks”? Jei gimei žalioje kūdroje tarp žalių varlių kitoks –  ne žalias, o ORANŽINIS? 

AŠ KITOKS - tai šio nuostabaus varliuko istorija.  Unikalus ir šviežias naujas miuziklas vaikams pagal menininko Rolando Dabruko populiarią iliustruotą knygą vaikams (tuo pačiu pavadinimu).  

Padėkite realizuoti šį spektaklį!  Jūsų auka padės pastatyti šį spektaklį scenoje - premjera ČIKAGOJE - 2022 metais. Po premjeros, spektaklis keliaus po Amerikos lietuvių bendruomenes.

 

APIE PROJEKTĄ

Šiame miuzikle, vaikai pamatys kaip oranžinis varliukas Tutis patiria patyčias ir diskriminaciją savo prude, ir kaip netikėtai susiranda draugę - gandrytę Orą, kuri jam parodo ką reiškia tikra draugystė.  Šios temos - tolerancija, draugystė, emigracija ir nuotoliniai ryšiai - ryškios ir aktualios, tiek mažiems, tiek dideliems.

Šis spektaklis pradžiugins visą šeimą.  Jūsų aukos padės jam ivykti!

 

REŽISŪRA

Patyrusi režisierė Rūta Bunikytė Klaipėdos valstybiniame muzikiniame teatre Lietuvoje yra sekmingai pastačius daugiau nei 20 muzikinio teatro darbų. Vėliausi: Chicago, Bonnie and Clyde, Orfeus Pragare, Silva, Brodvejus.LT.   Esame be galo nudžiuginti, kad ji pasiryžo būti šio spektaklio "galva."

MUZIKA

Kompozitorius Kęstutis Daugirdas (geriausiai žinomas kaip chorinės kantatos “Dainuojanti revoliucija” autorius) šiam miuziklui sukūrė 10 dainų pagal Editos Kliučinskaitės eiles. Tai lietuviškas-amerikietiškas hibridas: lietuviškos tautosakos įtaka ir motyvai, amerikietiškų miuziklų (Broadway, Disney) ikvepta muzika.  Dabar vyksta darbai išrašyti natų partitūras ir sukurti pilna orchestraciją ir garso takelius.

Dešinėje šio puslapio pusėje rasite visus PRIZUS iš kurių galite rinktis paaukoję mūsų projektui.

SCENOGRAFIJA ir KOSTIUMAI

Kaip ir Rolando knygoje, scena ir kostiumai bus ryškūs, spalvingi. Mus ikvepia paties menininko stilius ir Broadway kūriniai. Scenografiją įgyvendins menininkas ir skulptorius Sigitas Šniras.

CHOREOGRAFIJA

Spektaklyje matysite dainininkus ir šokėjus atliekant išraiškingą Sandros Krumhorn choreografiją - pvz. karą tarp varlių ir gandriukų, draugystės duetą, šventišką finalą. Scena bus visuomet pilna judesio ir spalvų.

APIMTIS

  • Vieta: Čikagoje 700-1,000 vietų teatro salėje (dar neparinkta)
  • Trukmė: 75 min.
  • 10 dainų
  • Atlikėjai: 22 (minimalus formatas) iki 28 (maksimalus)
  • Amžius: programa skirta 5-12m. amžiaus vaikams ir jų šeimoms

 

KOMANDA

 

KAŠTAI

  • Scenografija ir kostiumai
  • Choreografija
  • Muzikos partitūrą, aranžavimas, įrašymas
  • Honorarai 
  • Šviesų nuoma, dizainas, ir operatorius
  • Garso aparatūra
  • Salės pasirodymui ir repeticijoms nuoma
  • Kelionės ir nakvynės
  • Reklamos/plakatai
  • Administravimas
  • Indiegogo prizų teikimas

 

AČIŪ

Dėkui Jums už susidomėjimą!  Jūsų aukos suteiks mums galimybę įgyvendintį šią idėją ir dovanoti šią gražią, svarbią, ir skambią pasaką Jums ir visiems mūsų vaikams.  

 

Spauskite "BACK IT" šio puslapio viršuje!

 

[EN] Aš Kitoks ("I Am Different") is a brand-new musical for kids, created by three Lithuanian Americans artists in Los Angeles.  It's the story of TUTIS, a little orange frog without friends in a pond full of green bullies, and the unlikely friendship he forms with a most marvelous young stork named ORA.

With your donations, we can bring this unique new theatrical work to the stage in a spectacular way that will delight audiences old and young alike.  In addition to a colorful cast of characters, vibrant direction, imaginative sets and costumes, and memorable music and dance, the show also delivers a poignant and important message about diversity, difference, acceptance, and true friendship. 

With a strong creative and production team of experienced professionals, we have the opportunity to provide a one-of-a-kind theatrical experience for you and your families to enjoy.  

We treasure and appreciate your support!  Your donations will help make this show possible!

story:
*english to follow

2e événement bénéfice annuel de Danse à la carte



Danse à la carte est une compagnie sans but lucratif dont le mandat est de supporter la communauté de la danse de Montréal. Nous cherchons à favoriser les opportunités professionnelles des danseurs professionnels, tous horizons esthétiques confondus, en les mettant en contact les uns avec les autres, mais également avec des enseignants, des répétiteurs et des chorégraphes établis. En plus d’offrir des classes de haute qualité pour l’entrainement quotidien des danseurs, nous les aidons également à développer des outils professionnels connexes en marketing, communication, gestion et coordination artistique. C’est dans le but d’améliorer nos services et de diversifier nos opérations, afin de répondre toujours plus adéquatement aux besoins de notre communauté, que nous organisons la levée de fonds du 4 septembre prochain.




Danse à la carte supporte l’ensemble de sa communauté par la valorisation de chaque intervenant qui y est investi. Elle est rapidement devenue un vecteur d’échange, établissant un territoire où peuvent naître des collaborations, opportunités professionnelles et projets fertiles. 


Votre contribution sera donc associée à la santé et au développement professionnel de les artistes de notre communauté.









✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯


2nd annual Danse à la Carte Fundraiser



Danse à la Carte is an profit organization with a mandate to support the professional Montreal dance community. We strive to support and connect the dancers of our community regardless of their different training backgrounds and put them in contact with each other as well as in contact with local choreographers and rehearsal directors and teachers. In addition to offering high quality professional level training and development opportunities to dancers in the studio we also support dancers in acquiring new skills as they explore or transition into new career paths such as Marketing and Communications, Finance, Artistic Coordinating, teaching and more. In order to better serve, support and nourish our community we will be hosting a fundraising event on September 4th with some new goals. 



Danse à la Carte has quickly established itself as a breeding ground for new collaborations, partnerships, projects and employment opportunities. Most notably we support the growth and evolution of our community as a whole and from within. 


Your contribution would be supporting the health and longevity and promotion of countless members of the professional Montreal dance community.
story_txt:
*english to follow


2e événement bénéfice annuel de Danse à la carte






Danse à la carte est une compagnie sans but lucratif dont le mandat est de supporter la communauté de la danse de Montréal. Nous cherchons à favoriser les opportunités professionnelles des danseurs professionnels, tous horizons esthétiques confondus, en les mettant en contact les uns avec les autres, mais également avec des enseignants, des répétiteurs et des chorégraphes établis. En plus d’offrir des classes de haute qualité pour l’entrainement quotidien des danseurs, nous les aidons également à développer des outils professionnels connexes en marketing, communication, gestion et coordination artistique. C’est dans le but d’améliorer nos services et de diversifier nos opérations, afin de répondre toujours plus adéquatement aux besoins de notre communauté, que nous organisons la levée de fonds du 4 septembre prochain.







Danse à la carte supporte l’ensemble de sa communauté par la valorisation de chaque intervenant qui y est investi. Elle est rapidement devenue un vecteur d’échange, établissant un territoire où peuvent naître des collaborations, opportunités professionnelles et projets fertiles. 


Votre contribution sera donc associée à la santé et au développement professionnel de les artistes de notre communauté.
















✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯✯



2nd annual Danse à la Carte Fundraiser







Danse à la Carte is an profit organization with a mandate to support the professional Montreal dance community. We strive to support and connect the dancers of our community regardless of their different training backgrounds and put them in contact with each other as well as in contact with local choreographers and rehearsal directors and teachers. In addition to offering high quality professional level training and development opportunities to dancers in the studio we also support dancers in acquiring new skills as they explore or transition into new career paths such as Marketing and Communications, Finance, Artistic Coordinating, teaching and more. In order to better serve, support and nourish our community we will be hosting a fundraising event on September 4th with some new goals. 







Danse à la Carte has quickly established itself as a breeding ground for new collaborations, partnerships, projects and employment opportunities. Most notably we support the growth and evolution of our community as a whole and from within. 


Your contribution would be supporting the health and longevity and promotion of countless members of the professional Montreal dance community.

story:
The situation
The Dutch Kizomba Festival 3 was, like every year a wonderful weekend with lots of great teachers, dj’s and amazing people.
 
A lot of energy goes into organizing such an event but to us it is energy well spent and most importantly done with much love.
However, it's not only energy and love that's required to put together such an event.
It also involves a lot of money.

As you may or may not have gathered, a great injustice was done to us by the Willibrordhaeghe hotel!
We had a signed contract and merely 3 months before kick off, they backed out of this written agreement.
Basically we just got an email stating, we can not accept your business.. All bookings will be cancelled!

In order to proceed with DKF, we had to find another venue on very short notice.
This of course brought along more costs then initially agreed with Willibrordhaeghe.
Basically we are € 6.000,- short to cover all costs.
This is why we're starting this crowd funding campaign and hope for your help.

What are you paying for?
Our goal is set to € 6000,-  If we don't reach our goal we will have to reconsider whether it is realistic to keep this festival going.

Once we've reached our goal, every extra contribution will add to making DKF IV a reality. Something we hope to accomplish with even more support from you.

What you get in return
For each € 1,- of support we will jump in the air and yell.
But next to that you are keeping the Dutch Kizomba Festival alive.

Of course each donation deserves a reward. We thought it would be nice to have some exclusive stuff that will only be available here.
If you are sitting on a mountain of cash and have been waiting all this time for a good opportunity to spend it you can book a VIP Fullpass for the Dutch Kizomba Festival. Fun guaranteed!!

Take your time to check out all the rewards. We hope you'll like what we have to offer! Feel free to also make multiple contributions and to combine different items.

Dutch Kizomba Festival crew

Dutch Kizomba Festival is organized by:
Na Passada, Please contact us at kizombaflow@gmail.com if you have any questions or suggestions.
