story:
When you have a Dream...

In 2014, a new group called Penumbra:Exchange was formed with the mission of promoting emerging artists, enhancing diversity, and creating connections with the Boston dance community.  We started with our Diversity in Movement concert but quickly realized that we needed to do more.  So we invited Chun-jou Tsai aka "Dream" to be the first choreographer we produce a solo concert for since she embodies so many of the qualities we strive to support.  Furthermore, her work features a truly racially and culturally diverse cast - something still rarely found in Boston.

The Dream Project is about visualizing a Buddhist poem using traditional Chinese long-sleeves dance with Western improvisational modern dance technique.  This poem, when loosely translated, reflects the sentiments felt by many pursuing any kind of dream: just when you feel the most hopeless and defeated about your hard work is when you have to keep striving towards your goal, like a plum blossom breaking through the first snow of winter.

Just like our previous campaign, we are asking for help with the production costs of this concert.  Unlike the Diversity in Movement concert, however, we will be paying for the costumes, designs, and other costs that most choreographers must normally cover.  In exchange, we promise to contribute a portion of our profits towards an organization whose cause aligns with our own.


Meet "Dream"

Dream is a native of Taiwan with extensive knowledge of dance performance, choreography, education, and acting.  Her prolific career includes touring internationally with the Lan Yang Dance Company, commercial work as lead actress/dancer in music videos, and performing with the Pascal Rioult Dance Company during their summer intensives.  She has received numerous awards for her choreography and performance since 2005 as well as funding to attend the prestigious American Dance Festival and Vienna International Dance Festival (ImPulsTanz).  Dream accepted a full scholarship in 2010 to attend the Case Western Reserve University MFA in Contemporary Dance program where she continued to receive accolades for her work.  After coming to Boston in 2013, she joined Urbanity Dance and Penumbra:Movement with performances at the Boston University Dance Theatre, Dance Complex, Green Street Studios, and Boston Contemporary Dance Festival.  Dream passes on her deep knowledge and love of dance to her students each day at the Chinese Folk Art Dance Workshop, Bright Pearl Dance Academy, Gia Yung Dance Company, and Winchester Wen Chen Dance Group.


What a Dream Costs and How to Help it Come True

These are the total costs of putting on the production:

  • $600 - Theater rental for 1-night performance (including tech/dress rehearsals)
  • $150 - Costumes for 3 women and 2 men featuring custom long-sleeves
  • $150 - Posters and programs for the audience
  • $500 - Lighting and video design
  • $500 - Performance stipends for 5 dancers
  • $500 - Rehearsal rental fees
  • $100 - Cost of supplies for perks
  • $100 - Transaction fees if we don't meet our goal (yes, it does add up to that much!)

That comes out to $2600 - and we're only asking for $1500. To help reduce the amount that we are asking for from the Indiegogo community, we are pledging to hold a fundraising dance workshop as well as asking for sponsors to advertise in our concert program.

The theater seats about 100 people and our tickets are going for $15 each.  If we are lucky enough to get a full house, we may bring in $1400 after transaction fees and such. The more that is covered by our Indiegogo campaign, the more that we can donate to back to the Boston community.


    About that Plum Blossom...

    Like anyone else, Dream has her own dream as well.  In 2010, she came to the US to further her studies in contemporary dance as a graduate student at Case Western Reserve University.  As part of the program, they give their foreign MFA graduates a one-year work visa in the US before they must apply for a sponsored visa that must be renewed each year.  For most dancers in the US, it is tricky to find an employer that will agree to this.  Dream currently has one more year before she must find another sponsor or switch to different visa enabling her to work as a freelance artist.

    What the average American citizen doesn't know is that in order for a foreigner to work in the US as a non-sponsored freelance artist, they must apply for a special visa.  In the application, they must show evidence of a high-level of expertise and many accomplishments in their field.  A 'Nobel Prize' is listed as an actual example on the US government website. This is a far cry from how immigrants are typically described in news media and popular culture. Most US-born artists would have a hard time meeting the requirements outlined for foreign-born artists seeking to work as a freelancer.  This concert would help demonstrate that Dream meets the requirements that the US government is asking of her.

    Dream came to Boston because of her close relationship with her aunts and uncles. Her "family" has expanded to include all the students she teaches around Boston, Urbanity Dance artists, and many others.  On top of that, she is one of very few artists in Boston currently merging Asian traditional dance with Western contemporary forms.  To see that kind of dance elsewhere requires going to a place like New York City or Los Angeles.  So Dream's departure would also mean a big loss for Boston.

    Pushing through the Snow

    We know that we are risking a lot and putting in great effort for something that might not pan out.  But just like the Buddhist poem says, you can't achieve your goal without "pushing through the snow"  What we learn this time around can only help us do better, whether in helping Dream demonstrate expertise, helping another artist achieve their goals, or finding more sources for funding future Penumbra:Exchange productions.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Perhaps you would like to help but don't have a lot of cash? Or maybe you don't feel comfortable donating through Indiegogo?  Here are some options to consider:
    • Volunteer as a stage crew member or usher!
    • Attend our fundraiser on Saturday, Dec. 6 by taking a 7pm class to learn choreography from the show
    • Contact penumbra.rme@gmail.com to place an ad in our program
    • Make a direct donation through our fiscal sponsor, the Boston Dance Alliance (choose 'Penumbra:RME' from the beneficiary list)
    • Post an encouraging message on our Facebook page
    • Come to the show
    ...or contact us with other ideas!

story:
Box of Clowns is a trio of performers from Portland, Oregon. Our show, "Mom?" A Comedy of Mourners, is about three clown siblings scattering the ashes of their mother. Usually, clowns, grief, and the loss of a loved one are very scary things. Our show finds joy. Local audiences agree, and often come up to us after a show and say so.

NOW---we're bringing it to audiences nationwide!

This is where you can help: put gas in the clown car! We have to transport our set, the beloved "Box" of "Box of Clowns, with a trailer hitched to a Honda Fit and strap our belongings to the roof. And we'll do it all for the laugh!

$1778 is the amount we're asking for. It's approximately the cost of gas to get us to Montreal, our first stop on our tour. It's also the year Joseph Grimaldi was born, our patron clown for this summer! Grimaldi was a fearless comedian who was famous for his ability to make audiences laugh, and we get lots of inspiration from him.

Poke around our company website for a longer show description and reviews from The Oregonian and PLANK Magazine:

www.boxofclowns.com

Check out our Vimeo for clips from the show:

www.vimeo.com/boxofclowns

And if you don't have cash but want to help, please share this page on social media! You can also stay in the loop by subscribing to our monthly NOSEletter:

http://eepurl.com/baKKur

Thanks!

With laughter,

Box of Clowns

story:
The Price of Brotherhood

 

Greetings. My name is Stephen Harris and I am the writer,director and producer of the play The Price of Brotherhood. It iis a mystery about Steve Moore, a successful lawyer and mystery author who returns to his college campus, and he solves a homicide. This project is very important to me because I truly believe that people will enjoy this play. I am asking for $50,000 which will cover props, sovenirs, paying for space and paying a quality cast. I have perks for different amounts of support. For $10, supporters receive a fraternity t-shirt. For $50, supporters receive a t-shirt and the video. For $50, supporters receive the t-shirt, the video and free tickets for the stage performance. Please help in making this excellent play a reality. I thank you for any amount of support that you can give.

story:
Greetings from the Professor

Hello! I am Professor Horatio Octavious Algernon, time-traveling cryptoarcheologist ans Steampunk.  For more than 20 years, I have been inviting people to join me in the world of steampunk with eye-catching performances, inventions, and magic.  Along with my personal zombie, Olivia Nevermore, I take audiences through time and demonstrate wonders that man has forgotten and shamanistic rituals they wish they could forget!

I take great joy and pride in bringing laughter and fun to adults and children alike, and have been invited to bring my "World of Oddities and Wonders" to UtopiaCon in Cincinnati, Ohio, in October 2012.  To do this, however, I need your help.  To get our show from California to Ohio, we will need to rent an RV capable of hauling our crew and prop trailer on a 5000 mile trip. 

Not only will your contribution get us to the biggest gig of our respective careers, but you will be launching our show from regional to national exposure and acclaim.

The List

To make this trip happen, I need $8,500.  Here's how it breaks down:

  • Cruise America Large RV rental: $3000
  • Covered UHaul trailer: $400
  • 13, 55-gallon tanks of gas (7 miles/gallon while towing) at about $4.50/gallon: $3300
  • Two weeks of meals for five people, cooking and eating out: $800
  • Hotel rooms at UtopiaCon: $1000
  • TOTAL:  $8,500
These figures are rough estimates, based on current prices.  No matter how you calculate it, though, this is an expensive trip.  By helping us accomplish this, you will be an invaluable part of helping me realize a lifelong dream:  being a full-time, self-supporting performing magician, one that can actually pay a crew AND keep the lights on at the same time.  (Believe me, my wife will eternally love you, and, more importantly, me, if you help me do this...)
 
If we do not make our goal, all monies raised will be put in the "UtopiaCon or Bust!" bank account and be used, in conjunction with car washes and other fund raisers, to get us, by hook or by crook, to Cincinatti.
 

What You Get

The following contributions come with perks...little tchochkes and trinkets to forever remember how you helped change our lives:
 
  • $10 - A very steampunky, Professor Algernon pin
  • $25 - A very steampunky, Professor Algernon pin AND a signed photo postcard of the Professor and Olivia
  • $50 - A very steampunky, Professor Algernon pin AND a signed photo postcard of the Professor and Olivia AND a Professor Algernon T-shirt
  • $100 - A very steampunky, Professor Algernon pin AND a signed photo postcard of the Professor and Olivia AND a Professor Algernon T-shirt AND a DVD of the UtopiaCon trip and show

What Your Support Will Do

Why is this so important, to me and to others?  Here are just a few things

  • UtopiaCon is counting on our presence; we're a major steampunk headliner this year! (Check it out at http://www.utopiacon.com)
  • The exposure of this particular show will open the doors to other major performances.  
  • Major performances (meaning PAID) mean my zombie will be able to finish her college education (she's an anthropology major at California State University).

Moral Support

If you can't contribute financially, here are some other things you can do:

  • Friend me on Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/scot.violette) 
  • Like my Facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/Professor.Algernon)
  • Check out my website, http://www.professoralgernon.com/ , to get a glimpse of my show!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word!

 

Thanks for listening and supporting me in this life-changing opportunity!

story:
Our Story

A courageous little girl's heart-warming journey

through 20 cities in 12 months

as she shares her joy, faces her fears and grows love.


MAfrika2012 travels twenty cities in 12 months combining theatre & workshops to physically support thousands of children (and the adults with those children) throughout Africa and the world - to inspire the growth of LOVE, JOY & UNITY.              

For every paid show we do in a city â€“ we will do at least another show in a rural or previously disadvantaged area. Bringing the inspiring story to masses and documenting the inspiring human beings who are making a remarkable difference in the world.

We are boldly saying to all the children and adult children - WE ARE THE ONES WE'VE BEEN WAITING FOR - let's do it - create and support the solutions for our world. You can easily become a Dear One and support us and with many collaborators we really can heal the world!                                                                     

As MAfrika says â€œWe can do it - we just must just let go our fears and keep choosing love."


2012 is not just this year it's also our intended outreach - 20 cities 12 months and the intention is to document it all. We will be vlogging, blogging and producing a documentary at the end of the tour and there's still the possibility of a childrenâ€™s TV broadcaster commissioning our 26 x 11m TV episodes. The documentary will be due for release in 2013.


MAfrikaâ€™s been in development for 5 years and now we're super-duper excited to share this inspired, all-loving character MAfrika with the world (hereâ€™s a press-link from our first international show last year in Namibia - http://db.tt/SSvHWljB).

AS THE SHOW TRAVELS - each of the 20 CITIES' will have a paid show - which will further support the show reaching at least 20 RURAL areas too.

Following each show, whilst in each community - MAfrika will find WOWDERS (inspiring people who are contributing to the world) and she'll share her fantastical tale and together with the children they'll learn the FUNdamentals of how to have more joy in life, how to live with love for each other and even basics on growing vegetables, conserving water and caring for our planet.

 

MAfrika was once a Care Clown in hospitals - sharing joy with the children in Southern Africa and her desire to reach more children & even the adult children, has grown into this magically heart-warming fairy tale that truly inspires Unity, Joy & LOVE.

 

Your collaboration will ensure the first leg of the journey takes place - so be a Dear One and join MAfrika's grand quest.

 

 

The Impact

In January we start with 2 shows in Cape Town and then onto Namibia in February...

The journey will be done in partnership with The UP and numerous other NPO's which will support the workshopping side of the MAfrika2012 tour.


By December 21st 2012 when we give our final show - we envision there will have been thousands of children and adults uplifted, inspired and motivated to be joyful and loving contributors to this planet. Loads of joy activists will be inspiring solution-orientation and supporting the transformation of rife conflicts in so many areas throughout Africa & the world.

We envision peace - an awe-inspiring decrease in Xenophobia & Conflict and 1000's of children will be united actively inspiring love and joy to grow in the world.


What We Need & What You Get


Currently we are raising resources to get the show on the ground, material, props, equipment for the fisrt couple of months shows.
Any extra resources will go into the rest of the tour and building of the mobile stage as well as the tools and team for filming MAfrika2012. Namibia is the next scheduled MAfrika country in late February. We are also currently sending proposals out to potential sponsors and trusts that support arts and humanity . Due to the length of this tour and the intended impact we are aware ALL the support we can get, is what's going to make MAfrika's message grow.


As MAfrika says in her theatre show - "Ancestree said I must find the Dear One's who will take the journey with me, together we can let go of Fear & find the remedy stories for the Numshaq disease that is stealing feeling from so many."


IF you become a Dear One - depending on the level of your support â€“ our gift back to you will vary from signed pictures of MAfrika, to credit in her VLOG entries, free tickets to her shows and even executive producer title credits on her Webisodes / TV Show / Documentary.


Other Ways You Can Help

Become a Dear One could mean sharing your skills...                                                                                                           

You could help us by spreading the word or send us your ideas for how we can reach more Dear Ones, or perhaps you may want to network MAfrika with journalists or any other people you think may be keen to help...

                                                

ALL support makes you a Dear One...

 

MAfrika reckons since you have read this far YOU already ARE a DEAR ONE - so thank you...

 

She says "Mintyl HaXaku" - and thatâ€™s her language MinXadeesh for I Love You... (& the X is a click sound)


p.s. Hereâ€™s our current press release for more reading - http://db.tt/pZArr6KL

story:
SharkMother Arts Collective is in the middle of an exciting rehearsal process for our workshop production of The Lost Light, a new music theater show for adults and children.  The Lost Light follows Penny, a quirky imaginative little girl, on her journey to understand hope and save her family from a land without dreams.  New friends, crafted from her family’s belongings, join her on an exciting adventure that puts her tenacious spirit to the test.  The show features a talented cast of 14 actors, accompanied by a stellar group of 7 musicians.


Although the show is taking shape, we still have a long way to go to make The Lost Light a reality.  Our goal is to raise $2,500 by December 4th—a big goal for a small company!  In order to reach this objective, we need your support.   Your contribution will help us to fund our theater rental and pay for set and lighting costs.  Anything you can spare would be deeply appreciated, and will help us come closer to making this project happen.


Because SharkMother is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization, your donation is tax deductible to the extent permitted by law! (Please see details to the right.)


We will be keeping this page fresh with updates from rehearsals, as well as photo and video content for the show.  Check back soon and stay in the loop!


This project is sponsored, in part, by the Greater New York Arts Development Fund of the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs, administered by Brooklyn Arts Council, Inc. (BAC).


For more info about the show, and to purchase tickets, please click here.

story:
Thank you Worker, Warrior and Foraging Ants! You helped us make our initial goal of 5K and we are each waving six legs in the air for joy! Because we are industrious by nature, we want to use the remaining month we have on this site to raise as much as we possibly can. The secret remaining goal amount is 10K. That may sound daunting, but have you ever seen how fast fire ants can repair damage to their nest? They are amazing, just like all of you. Spread the word or the chemical trail, whichever you prefer. Love, all the ants down south.

 

In a nutshell: The theatre program at St. Andrew's-Sewanee School is fundraising to tweak our original production, "The Ants," and take it to the Fringe Festival in Edinburgh, Scotland August 2013.

 

This happened first: E.O. Wilson, famous naturalist and foremost expert on ants, with his writing partner Bert Hölldobler, graciously permitted us to conduct the experiment of adapting a science encyclopedia to the stage. Their books "Journey to the Ants," "Leafcutter Ants," and the Pulitzer Prize-winning "The Ants" are fascinating, beautifully written texts. In our show, sections of their prose were presented in various spoken word art styles. Text co-mingled with student music compositions. Cello, guitar, beat boxing and improvisational vocalizing were all part of the soundscape. An extremely physical piece of theatre, each scene came to life with the performers' movement. Our original version of "The Ants" was produced last winter. This spring, we are lucky enough to have another go.

 

Here we are: St. Andrew's-Sewanee School is a beautiful, small day and boarding school in a rural area of Tennessee. The campus includes five hundred acres of woods with caves and a swimming hole. Our student body includes international boarders, boarders from around the Southeast, as well as local day students who come from here on the Cumberland Plateau. Being a small school, we don't have deep pockets, so the performing arts department is committed to raising the funds for our young performers.

 

The money: Sometimes an opportunity is worth making plenty of noise to get the message out.  We know the experience our student performers will have and bring back to our campus is extraordinary, so we are willing to work like fire ants to gather the necessary funds. Come on, join our colony and help us close the gap with our Indiegogo campaign.

 

Bios: Robie Jackson and John Holleman are from Knoxville, Tennessee. They studied theater at UT Knoxville, and have degrees in arts and education from University of Tennessee, Belmont College and Vanderbilt. Robie is almost, almost done with her M.F.A. from Sewanee: The University of the South. They have taught kindergarten through twelfth grade in Nashville and Sewanee. John produced shows with a masked ensemble in Nashville for several years and has had scripts produced here and there – notably at Theater Wit in Chicago this past summer and at the New York Fringe Festival in 2006. Robie was named Theater Teacher of the Year 2010 by the Tennessee Governor's School for the Arts.

story:
**Just-In Reviews!**

4-Stars and Critic's Pick!

(Time Out New York, Aug. 16, 2013)

http://www.timeout.com/newyork/theater/naked-in-alaska

"Uplifting and one of a kind"!

(NYTheatre.com, Aug. 16, 2013)

http://www.nytheatre.com/Show/Index/2013-naked-in-alaska

"Hager is hilarious and masterful. The show is so fearless, candid, and personal that it is impossible not to be moved."

(Maxamoo, Aug. 19, 2013)

http://www.maxamoo.com/fringenyc-naked-in-alaska-2/

"If you're an audience member, come see one of the very best shows of the [Fringe] festival. And if you're in the industry, hire Hager. She's got what it takes to be a star."

(Hy on the Fringe, Aug. 23, 2013)

http://hyreviews.com/fringenyc2013.htm#Val

"New, funny, and raw... [with the] ability to really change lives"!

(Usher Nonsense, Aug. 16, 2013)

http://www.ushernonsense.com/Usher_Nonsense/Reviews/Entries/2013/8/16_Naked_In_Alaska.html

"A talented and engaging solo performance with jaw-dropping moments throughout"!

(Theatre is Easy, Aug. 20, 2013)

http://www.theasy.com/Reviews/FringeFestival/2013/nakedinalaska.php

"You won’t go wrong if you head to Valerie Hager’s autobiographical, solo show, Naked in Alaska."

(OffOffOnline, Aug. 20, 2013)

http://offoffonline.com/?p=10043

"Naked in Alaska is captivating and convincing... The writer/actress Valerie Hager pulls few punches... Raw and entertaining!" 

(Woman Around Town, Aug. 23, 2013)

http://www.womanaroundtown.com/sections/playing-around/three-from-the-fringe

*******

**News Updates!**

A New Yorker Illustration! (Aug. 12th & 19th Issue)

Naked In Alaska was chosen out of around 200 shows to be one of the five that The New Yorker magazine highlighted in its August 12th & 19th issue. Here's the awesome cartoon they created (note Valerie's airborne ruby red high heels!):

A New York Daily News Full-page profile! (Aug. 4, 2013)

Valerie Hager was interviewed by the New York Daily News and received a feature article--a whole page!--on Page 3 of their Sunday Edition on August 4, 2013!

The web version of the article can be seen here:

http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music-arts/stripper-bares-onstage-memoir-article-1.1416928

Naked In Alaska has been highlighted in these exclusive lists...

"Top 10 Shows to See at the NYC Fringe"!

(Backstage Magazine, July 31, 2013)

http://www.backstage.com/galleries/10-shows-see-ny-fringe-festival/5

"Top 10 Shows that Stand Out at the NYC Fringe"!

(Tony Award-Winning Producer Ken Davenport's blog The Producer's Perspective: A Broadway Producer's Perspective on Everything Broadway and Beyond, Aug. 7, 2013)

http://www.theproducersperspective.com/my_weblog/2013/08/10-shows-that-stand-out-at-the-fringe-2013.html

"Top 8 Shows You Should Definitely Consider at the NYC Fringe"!

(TheaterMania, Aug. 7, 2013)

http://www.theatermania.com/new-york-city-theater/news/08-2013/cowboys-strippers-and-tom-cruise-take-the-stage-at_65714.html

"Top 5 Sexiest Shows to See in New York"!

(Time Out New York, Aug. 15, 2013)

http://www.timeout.com/newyork/clubs-nightlife/nsfw-nyc

Highlighted by NPR's New York City affiliate WNYC!

(WNYC, Aug. 11, 2013)

http://www.wnyc.org/articles/wnyc-news/2013/aug/10/fringe-festival/

Valerie Hager interviewed by Michael Block for Theater in the Now's Artist Spotlight!

(Theater in the Now, Aug. 10, 2013)

http://www.theaterinthenow.com/2013/08/spotlight-onvalerie-hager.html

*******

Naked In Alaska:

The True Story of Stripping in the Last Frontier

My name is Valerie Hager. I was inspired to write and perform Naked In Alaska after I moved to New York City from Los Angeles and began to go through dozens of old journals and hundreds of photographs that I had been carrying around with me for over a decade. As I sat in my empty apartment, I suddenly saw this young girl who I'd forgotten about. This girl who had been ashamed of her body, addicted to drugs, longing to be loved, and yet doing everything she could to push the world away.

And I realized that in having separated myself from her and judged her as bad and wrong, I had also forgotten and abandoned the rebel in me--that untamed part that had been determined to pave her own path in the world and feel alive.

So I began to turn these experiences I had as a young girl into short performances pieces. I knew that if I had had these types of experiences, other women (and men) must have as well. And didn't want anyone else to feel as alone as I did in those experiences. I wanted to shine a light on all of it and let people know that all of it matters, can be made beautiful, and doesn't have to be shut away in the dark. This is how Naked In Alaska was born.

Now Naked In Alaska has been invited to two of the most well-regarded theatre festivals in the United States: the 2013 International New York Fringe Festival in August and the 2013 Chicago Fringe Festival in September. We--myself and the show's director, Scott Wesley Slavin--are incredibly grateful to have been chosen to be part of these festivals and now we need your help to make it happen!

 

 

"Where has Naked In Alaska been so far?"

Naked In Alaska premiered to two sold-out houses at the Women at Work Festival in September-October 2012 and was the bestseller at the EstroGenius Festival in November 2012. In April of this year, Naked In Alaska performed to a full house at Dixon Place, an Obie Award winning New York City theater devoted exclusively to presenting original work.

The feedback from audience members and press alike has been outstanding and we have been humbled by the amount of support and encouragement we have received from everyone who has experienced the show.

Selected Past Reviews:

"Utilizing much humor and some very impressive pole dancing, the story unfolds as Valerie combines vulnerability and honesty with the survival skills needed to navigate the murky world of strip clubs and private party rooms. The ability to laugh at herself only enhances her charm. You will root for her indomitable spirit and celebrate the triumph of Valerie Hager in Naked In Alaska." -- Laurie Lawson, Theatre Critic, Off-Broadway

"Valerie Hager is the real deal: stunningly beautiful and even more stunningly talented. Evocative characterizations and a compelling personal story combined in a finely executed piece of theatre. Go, just go." -- Jen Thatcher, Producer, EstroGenius Festival

"As a performer, Valerie is luminous. As a writer, she is fearless. Naked In Alaska highlights her talents in both fields, and the result is theater that is equal parts gut wrenching and inspiring - in other words: theater that is not to be missed." -- Molly Pearson, Co-Artistic Director, Partial Comfort Productions 

"By the end of the show I told myself, 'Get as many people as you can to see this show.' I think that may be one of the best one woman shows I've ever seen… because your show is so dangerous. I loved every minute of it!" -- Adam Delia, Writer/Director/Producer, Bryan and Kim

Read additional reviews and learn more about the history of Naked In Alaska on our website.

 

"What kind of support do you need?"

Participating in two major Fringe festivals in the same summer is a major undertaking--financially and energetically. We are fiercely committed to Naked In Alaska's success at both festivals and far beyond! With your help, Naked In Alaska can reach the audiences that could most benefit by seeing it and sharing it with others. We need help paying for:

- Festival Entry fees
- Marketing and publicity
- Rehearsal space
- Technical staff and stage managers
- Travel to and from Chicago (and prop transportation)

We need to raise the entire amount! You'll receive cool perks for donating and Naked In Alaska is sponsored by Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts organization--so your donations are 100% tax-deductible. If we can make this happen, Naked In Alaska has the chance to inspire women and young girls to make choices to honor themselves in ways that can change the course of their life.

 

"What if you exceed your funding goal?"

If we exceed our fundraising goal (yay!), we can fulfill our dream of bringing Naked In Alaska to our home state of California! We look forward to touring it around the U.S. and reaching as many people as possible. Additionally, we very much seek to expand opportunities around every performance to include writing and storytelling workshops, artist Q&As, and local outreach.

 

"And how else can I help?"

Please help us spread the word! Please forward this campaign to your friends, family, and networks. Feel free to reach out to me via email, connect with me on Facebook, and follow me on Twitter. Please use the IndieGogo Share Tools below and let's get the word out to as many people as we can! Thank you for your help!

 

Thank you!!!

To everyone who has taken the time to visit this page and learn more about Naked In Alaska--THANK YOU!

To the Indiegogo community who continues to inspire me everyday--THANK YOU for considering my campaign and supporting Naked In Alaska!

I will continue do everything in my power to present Naked In Alaska as a vehicle to inspire and open up honest and courageous conversations so that lives may be changed wherever it goes!

Xoxo,

Valerie Hager & Scott Wesley Slavin (Director of Naked In Alaska)

http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music-arts/stripper-bares-onstage-memoir-article-1.1416928
Naked In Alaska has been highlighted in these exclusive lists...
"Top 10 Shows to See at the NYC Fringe"!
(Backstage Magazine, July 31, 2013)
http://www.backstage.com/galleries/10-shows-see-ny-fringe-festival/5
"Top 10 Shows that Stand Out at the NYC Fringe"!
(Tony Award-Winning Producer Ken Davenport's blog The Producer's Perspective: A Broadway Producer's Perspective on Everything Broadway and Beyond, Aug. 7, 2013)
http://www.theproducersperspective.com/my_weblog/2013/08/10-shows-that-stand-out-at-the-fringe-2013.html
"Top 8 Shows You Should Definitely Consider at the NYC Fringe"!
(TheaterMania, Aug. 7, 2013)
http://www.theatermania.com/new-york-city-theater/news/08-2013/cowboys-strippers-and-tom-cruise-take-the-stage-at_65714.html
"Top 5 Sexiest Shows to See in New York"!

(Time Out New York, Aug. 15, 2013)
http://www.timeout.com/newyork/clubs-nightlife/nsfw-nyc
Highlighted by NPR's New York City affiliate WNYC!
(WNYC, Aug. 11, 2013)
http://www.wnyc.org/articles/wnyc-news/2013/aug/10/fringe-festival/
Valerie Hager interviewed by Michael Block for Theater in the Now's Artist Spotlight!
(Theater in the Now, Aug. 10, 2013)
http://www.theaterinthenow.com/2013/08/spotlight-onvalerie-hager.html
*******
Naked In Alaska:
The True Story of Stripping in the Last Frontier
My name is Valerie Hager. I was inspired to write and perform Naked In Alaska after I moved to New York City from Los Angeles and began to go through dozens of old journals and hundreds of photographs that I had been carrying around with me for over a decade. As I sat in my empty apartment, I suddenly saw this young girl who I'd forgotten about. This girl who had been ashamed of her body, addicted to drugs, longing to be loved, and yet doing everything she could to push the world away.
And I realized that in having separated myself from her and judged her as bad and wrong, I had also forgotten and abandoned the rebel in me--that untamed part that had been determined to pave her own path in the world and feel alive.
So I began to turn these experiences I had as a young girl into short performances pieces. I knew that if I had had these types of experiences, other women (and men) must have as well. And didn't want anyone else to feel as alone as I did in those experiences. I wanted to shine a light on all of it and let people know that all of it matters, can be made beautiful, and doesn't have to be shut away in the dark. This is how Naked In Alaska was born.
Now Naked In Alaska has been invited to two of the most well-regarded theatre festivals in the United States: the 2013 International New York Fringe Festival in August and the 2013 Chicago Fringe Festival in September. We--myself and the show's director, Scott Wesley Slavin--are incredibly grateful to have been chosen to be part of these festivals and now we need your help to make it happen!
 

 
"Where has Naked In Alaska been so far?"
Naked In Alaska premiered to two sold-out houses at the Women at Work Festival in September-October 2012 and was the bestseller at the EstroGenius Festival in November 2012. In April of this year, Naked In Alaska performed to a full house at Dixon Place, an Obie Award winning New York City theater devoted exclusively to presenting original work.
The feedback from audience members and press alike has been outstanding and we have been humbled by the amount of support and encouragement we have received from everyone who has experienced the show.
Selected Past Reviews:
"Utilizing much humor and some very impressive pole dancing, the story unfolds as Valerie combines vulnerability and honesty with the survival skills needed to navigate the murky world of strip clubs and private party rooms. The ability to laugh at herself only enhances her charm. You will root for her indomitable spirit and celebrate the triumph of Valerie Hager in Naked In Alaska." -- Laurie Lawson, Theatre Critic, Off-Broadway
"Valerie Hager is the real deal: stunningly beautiful and even more stunningly talented. Evocative characterizations and a compelling personal story combined in a finely executed piece of theatre. Go, just go." -- Jen Thatcher, Producer, EstroGenius Festival
"As a performer, Valerie is luminous. As a writer, she is fearless. Naked In Alaska highlights her talents in both fields, and the result is theater that is equal parts gut wrenching and inspiring - in other words: theater that is not to be missed." -- Molly Pearson, Co-Artistic Director, Partial Comfort Productions 
"By the end of the show I told myself, 'Get as many people as you can to see this show.' I think that may be one of the best one woman shows I've ever seen… because your show is so dangerous. I loved every minute of it!" -- Adam Delia, Writer/Director/Producer, Bryan and Kim
Read additional reviews and learn more about the history of Naked In Alaska on our website.
 
"What kind of support do you need?"
Participating in two major Fringe festivals in the same summer is a major undertaking--financially and energetically. We are fiercely committed to Naked In Alaska's success at both festivals and far beyond! With your help, Naked In Alaska can reach the audiences that could most benefit by seeing it and sharing it with others. We need help paying for:
- Festival Entry fees- Marketing and publicity- Rehearsal space- Technical staff and stage managers- Travel to and from Chicago (and prop transportation)
We need to raise the entire amount! You'll receive cool perks for donating and Naked In Alaska is sponsored by Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts organization--so your donations are 100% tax-deductible. If we can make this happen, Naked In Alaska has the chance to inspire women and young girls to make choices to honor themselves in ways that can change the course of their life.
 
"What if you exceed your funding goal?"
If we exceed our fundraising goal (yay!), we can fulfill our dream of bringing Naked In Alaska to our home state of California! We look forward to touring it around the U.S. and reaching as many people as possible. Additionally, we very much seek to expand opportunities around every performance to include writing and storytelling workshops, artist Q&As, and local outreach.
 
"And how else can I help?"
Please help us spread the word! Please forward this campaign to your friends, family, and networks. Feel free to reach out to me via email, connect with me on Facebook, and follow me on Twitter. Please use the IndieGogo Share Tools below and let's get the word out to as many people as we can! Thank you for your help!
 
Thank you!!!
To everyone who has taken the time to visit this page and learn more about Naked In Alaska--THANK YOU!
To the Indiegogo community who continues to inspire me everyday--THANK YOU for considering my campaign and supporting Naked In Alaska!
I will continue do everything in my power to present Naked In Alaska as a vehicle to inspire and open up honest and courageous conversations so that lives may be changed wherever it goes!
Xoxo,
Valerie Hager & Scott Wesley Slavin (Director of Naked In Alaska)

story:
Tall Tales for Short People!

We love telling stories. Stories intrigue and surprise us. They keep us going. When we (Luke and Hayley) got together to talk about creating a children's show for the 2013 Toronto Fringe, we talked about telling good stories. After assembling a crack team of actors, designers and director, we put together a collectively-created script, and now sit ready to produce what is sure to be a hit at the Fringe this summer: Honest Aesop's Fables.

Based on centuries-old fables, Honest Aesop's Fables is a modern retelling of some of the best known stories from our childhood: The Tortoise and the Hare, The Ants and Grasshoppers are just a few. Working with all the stories we could find, we narrowed it down to our favourites, and then honed them into a quick-witted and physically active show that is entertaining while also teaching important lessons about life and living well.

A Hare-Raising Tale

Fringe Festivals return all the ticket money to artists. Because of that, Fringe productions often operate on a profit-share model, where all the expenses of the show are paid, and then everything that's left is split fairly between the people who worked on the show.

What we're trying to do with this campaign is help tip the equation in favour of the 10 artists who are working on Honest Aesop's Fables. We're hoping to raise enough money now to cover the cost of our production, so that every penny of our ticket sales goes straight into the pockets of our artists - actors, director, designers, stage manager. But who are these lovely people? Check out these gorgeous headshots!

From left to right, the cast: Geoffrey, Hayley, Marcel, Luke, Leslie and Emily.

From left to right: Teodoro (director), Matt (designer), Kjell (stage manager), Tara (musical director).

The contributions you make during this campaign will help us cover costs like the Fringe Festival fee, rehearsal space, costumes, sets, and marketing. If we can get those costs covered now, it will help us go a long way to making sure that everyone gets a fair wage. Anything raised above and beyond the production costs goes straight to our artists, so every dollar you contribute has a very big effect.

Help Us Help You Help Us!

We know that it's tough to figure out what to see at the Fringe each summer, so we thought we'd offer you the chance to get your tickets for our show early! As part of the perks for contributing to the our Honest Aesop's Fables campaign, you can secure a seat now for an Honest Aesop's Fables show of your choice this summer, for only $20. That saves your seat, and it provides us with the help we need now to get the show off the ground. We've got the show dates, and here they are: 
 

July 4, 7:15pm | July 6, 12:45pm | July 7, 5:45pm | July 8, 2:45pm | July 9, 4:15pm | July 11, 5:15pm | July 12, 1:00pm | July 13, 4:15pm

 
On top of that, we have some pretty awesome other perks, offered on the sidebar to the right of the screen. Read each one, and consider contributing today!

The "Ant Colony" Effect

Just like the ants that work together in our show, every little bit helps to getting us to our goal for the campaign. A great part of Indiegogo is that as a group, each contribution adds up to a lot of funding for our artists. With that in mind, we need your help to make our ant colony as big as possible. The more people that know about our campaign, the better we'll be able to share our stories with kids this summer. Please take the time to:

  • Tweet, Facebook and e-mail people you think would want to help us!
  • Buy a ticket to our show, either through Indiegogo or at the Fringe website.

On behalf of the entire cast and creative team for Honest Aesop's Fables, thank you for considering helping us, and thank you for sharing with people you know!

Until the Fringe,

Luke LaRocque and Hayley Carr

story:
Inspired by a real life journey by train from Brattleboro to New Haven, Moment of Impact explores the vast ripple effect caused by one unexpected and tragic event. Seamlessly shifting between lyrical aerial performance, virtuosic physical theatre, storytelling and comedy, solo performer Bronwyn Sims shares a deeply personal story of love, loss, life and ambition. Strong Coffee Stage is a professional theater company dedicated to creating compelling theatre productions that combine movement, music, vulnerability, virtuosity and wit. 

Strong Coffee Stage also facilitates periodic master classes in physical theatre, clown, improvisation and acting and brings master teachers and performers to share their knowledge with the Southern Vermont community. Founded in 2009 by Bronwyn Sims and Patrick Donnelly, Strong Coffee Stage is a New England States Touring Artist (NEST), Juried Teaching Artist in the State of Vermont, and has received funding from the National Endowment for the Arts, Vermont Arts Council, and the Vermont Community Foundation.

Moment of Impact represents a major step forward in our development. It is also the first full length solo peice created by Bronwyn Sims. Our production team includes a talented group of artists. We can do great things with a modest budget. Donations raised will allow us to continue to further our development of a growing Theatre Compnay in Southern VT. The funds raised will enable us to create a beautiful spectacle that will move the heart and deepen the soul. www.strongcoffeestage.com

If you would prefer to make a tax deductible donation to Strong Coffee Stage please go to our website or click this link below to contribute directly to Strong Coffee Stage.

Thank You!

www.strongcoffeestage.com

Please click here to donate through The Field.

 It will take you directly to Strong Coffee Stage page.

https://www.thefield.org/Profile.aspx?SAID=324

story:
Little Matchstick Factory’s

THE OTHER MOZART

"One of the most remarkable theatrical presentations I saw in 2013...”­- New York Arts

There was another Mozart - a forgotten genius, an other Mozart.

THE OTHER MOZART is the true and untold story of Nannerl Mozart, the sister of Amadeus - a prodigy, keyboard virtuoso and composer, who performed throughout Europe with her brother to equal acclaim, but her work and her story faded away, lost to history. 

In 2006 performer and musician, Sylvia Milo, found Nannerl in the Mozart family portrait, and this project started.

Set in and on a sweeping 18-foot dress (designed by Magdalena Dabrowska from the National Theater of Poland), directed by Isaac Byrne, the play is based on facts, stories and lines pulled directly from the Mozart family's humorous and heartbreaking letters. Along with music composed by her famous brother and Marianna Martines (a female composer who inspired Nannerl), original music was written for the play by Nathan Davis and Phyllis Chen (of Lincoln Center's Mostly Mozart Festival and the International Contemporary Ensemble) using clavichords, music boxes, teacups, and fans.


In a world still unequal in opportunities for women, it is necessary to hear and understand stories such as Nannerl’s.

We feel compelled to bring Nannerl’s story to as wide an audience as possible - after critically acclaimed, sold out performances at festivals around the US and in Austria, we present the play for the first time as a full, three-week (24 performances), theatrical run:

HERE Arts Center, NYC  - June 22 - July 12

(Opening Night and party: June 25)


We need your help in raising the necessary funds to make this happen.

Amadeus was able to become the first successful freelance composer by taking matters into his own hands:
“Wolfgang has arranged for a list of subscribers - including many members of high aristocracy - for whom he gives concerts. He rents a concert hall, even brings his own fortepiano, and performs his music for their pleasure and their pay.”
Nannerl was not able to do that, but now we can do it for her.

You have a chance to become a member of high aristocracy for Nannerl Mozart!
 
WHAT IT ACTUALLY COSTS

The 3-week run (24 performances) at this Off-Broadway theater will cost over $20,000. 

What it breaks down into is:
the (subsidized*) cost of the theater -$4500/week
rehearsal space (ten 5-hour rehearsals for Sylvia and Julia - the understudy) - $1000
insurance - $500
extra lights rental - $500
fireproofing the dress - $300
marketing and PR - $3500
postcards, posters, postage, printing of programs - $1000

That is already over $20,000... and we still need some artist/crew fees, some new tea cups and bloomers!

IT IS TAX DEDUCTIBLE!
The Other Mozart is the first project by Little Matchstick Factory - Sylvia Milo's and Nathan Davis' theater production company. Little Matchstick Factory is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Little Matchstick Factory must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP!

Please share this campaign on your facebook, twitter, via email, etc.

Follow us:
https://www.facebook.com/TheOtherMozart
http://instagram.com/othermozart
https://twitter.com/NannerlOMozart
https://twitter.com/TheOtherMozart

And    COME SEE THE SHOW!
                      http://here.org/shows/detail/1467/


PRESS
"One of the most remarkable theatrical presentations I saw in 2013... Brilliant and absorbing... Sylvia Milo has brought off a tour de force in creating such an absorbing, intelligent, and sure­ footed entertainment." ­ New York Arts
"Sylvia Milo’s luscious depiction... eschews the dreaded bio-adaptation problem – and it does so with class and evocative energy.  ... a surprisingly deep and penetrating analysis of the life of  Wolfgang’s older sister... She sometimes resembles the dancing girl in the center of a music box " - Stage and Cinema
THE TEAM

We believe in this project with all our hearts.

Written and performed by: Sylvia Milo
Directed by: Isaac Byrne
Music composed by: Nathan Davis and Phyllis Chen
Additional music by: Marianna Martines and Wolfgang A. Mozart
Costume by: Magdalena Dąbrowska and Miodrag Guberinic
Style coached by: Janice Orlandi
Lighting design by: Joshua Rose
Hair styled by: Courtney Bednarowski
Understudy: Julia Rosa Stöckl
 
Please read more about our impressive team here: http://www.theothermozart.com/about

For more information please visit www.TheOtherMozart.com.

HISTORY

In March 2013 The Other Mozart had its first performance at the Smith Museum of Fine Art in Auburn, Alabama. From there the play was presented at various festivals in the US - Charleston’s Piccolo Spoleto, NYC’s All for One Theater Festival at the prestigious Cherry Lane Theater, the Berkshire Fringe Festival in Massachusetts (the play named “Best Theater of 2013” by Berkshire on Stage), et. al - and in Austria - at the Mozarthaus Sankt Gilgen, at the DIVA Monodrama Festival (under patronage of UNESCO) in Tux - all to great reviews and raving audiences in sold out houses.

This May THE OTHER MOZART will be presented in Salzburg - Mozarts’ Wohnhaus - at the invitation of the MOZARTEUM.

MORE PRESS

"THE OTHER MOZART is a must-see masterpiece. SYLVIA MILO gives an astonishingly brilliant performance... Costume design and set design are outstanding... THE OTHER MOZART is pure pleasure on every level." - Off-Broadway Journey (NYC)

"Beautiful? The word isn’t adequate. Unique? A cliché. Powerful? Immensely. Emotional? Deeply. Funny and fun. Sad and desperate... A rich combination of talents coming together, resulting in a performance of rare magnitude... So much brilliance in one night."  - OA News (Alabama)

"... spry and witty, turning what could have been simply a revisionist complaint into a penetrating portrait of the Mozart who might have been."  - The Valley Advocate (The Berkshires)

"The massive amount of research Milo has done for this project is astounding. The facts of this woman’s life are truly fascinating... fiercely talented director, Isaac Byrne. ...one of the most stunning stage pictures I’ve seen in years." - Theater Pizzazz (NYC)

"Not only did THE OTHER MOZART tell a fascinating and important story – but it did so most theatrically. I loved the concept of Nannerl literally allowing her world to be proscribed by the circumference of her dress. ...here the brilliance of director Isaac Byrne literally shines... The reality and the visual effect were really impressive." - Berkshire on Stage

"Through Milo's layered and beautiful performance, brilliant lighting and atmospheric sound design, Nannerl's tale is told with heartbreaking beauty." - New England Entertainment Digest


*This production is a part of SubletSeries@HERE, HERE’s curated rental program, which provides artists with subsidized space and equipment, as well as technical support.

The reality and the visual effect were really impressive." - Berkshire on Stage"Through Milo's layered and beautiful performance, brilliant lighting 
and atmospheric sound design, Nannerl's tale is told with heartbreaking 
beauty." - New England Entertainment Digest
*This
 production is a part of SubletSeries@HERE, HERE’s curated rental 
program, which provides artists with subsidized space and equipment, as 
well as technical support.

story:
We're premiering Nandi Keyi's powerful new Musical, "Flambeaux" in New York City at Theater for the New City's "Dream Up" Festival in August 2013.

http://www.theaterforthenewcity.net/dreamup.htm

BREAKING NEWS: We're thrilled to announce that we've been invited to premiere "Flambeaux", a Caribbean Musical at the fabulous Theater for the New City in New York City. This is an incredible opportunity for Obsidian Media group to introduce Nandi's riveting play.

We're Obsidian Media's Development Team for "Flambeaux", a Caribbean Musical: Nandi Keyi, (Playwriight) Roderick Warner, Isaac Suggs, Jr, Larry Floyd, Jeff Bolding, LaDawn Newton, Shawn Renee Graham, Melissa Maxwell, Antoinette Tynes and Derrick Minter. 

HOW TO BE A FRIEND OF "FLAMEBEAUX, a Caribbean Musical:

               1. BE A RESOURCE! Be sure to tell anyone who could be of help to this project. Forward and Publicize.

               2. DONATE.  Click Below and give what you can.

 

 

DEFINITION: Flambeaux: a flaming torch (such as are used in processions at night.) In our Carnival Musical, it represents the spirit in the bellies of the African people who were uprooted and shipped around the globe. We salute their sacrifice and struggle.

Using elements of Calypso and other various styles of music, choreography and Stickfighting, "Flambeaux" tells the story of a Community in Trinidad in the late 1880's. Set in fictional Homer Yard during Carnival, they are striving for relevance and Home.

With your support, we'll be able to produce Nandi Keyi's provocative, new Carnival Musical. We'll also launch our 2013-14 Touring and development cycle, where we hope to expand our audiences by touring Toronto, Canada, Charlotte, NC, Atlanta, GA and Houston, Texas.

Caribbean-American Theatre is vital to  diaspora work and Cultural Ambassadorship, but for many years  it has not been able to contribute within the grand Vision of Theatre Culture. With this project, "Flambeaux" we are seeking to rectify that. 

Through this "Indiegogo"  campaign, we will be able to produce 12 full shows of "Flambeaux" this Summer/Fall.  This is one of our most exciting projects to date, with new surprises and the Obsidian Media Group commitment to making every performance an accessible theatrical event.

Where the Money is Going

The Actual Budget needed is $20,000.00. Indiegogo is just one of the Fundraisers we will be having. Here's how the costs break down:

Festival Participation: $500

Rehearsal Space: $2,000

Theatre Space rental for Extension: $5,000

Production costs and fees for artists: $8,000

Marketing: $1,500

Extension Preparation: $4,500

 

Anyone who has ever tried to produce Caribbean Theatre knows the challenges of doing so. There are misconceptions about what Caribbean Theatre used to be, is currently or should be. But how can we do the right things if there is no "Doings"? Our endeavor and purpose for "Flambeaux" is also a chance we're taking with the world community, no matter what island or country you, your Parents and/or Grandparents are from. This effort will unite us all in the name of World Theatre.

Obsidian Media Group has had a great track record, From "Black Man Rising" to "ResurGENTs" and from collaborations with the School Systems in Stamford and Greenwich Ct. to our work with the youth in Bermuda. Yet, we have never had a Cast and Crew of nineteen (19) who have to be rehearsed and compensated. And we have to do it in New York City. Mercy!

There are many obstacles that we will face even after we're funded, but we don't have to face them alone and this only strengthens our resolve to succeed.

This is where our "FRIENDS OF FLAMBEAUX" come in, to help make it easier to deal with the struggles. There is a chance for a setback, but we believe that there exists a strong audience and Caribbean community to support our endeavor. Let's prove ourselves right. Join us.

SUPPORT CARIBBEAN-AMERICAN THEATRE. BECOME A "FRIEND OF FLAMBEAUX."

story:
*
Lisa: here's a question
Emilie: yessss
Lisa: would you have any interest in doing this long-distance communication play with will and elly and me?
Emilie: fuck yeah!
(actual GChat transcript)

The Past

We started this play sitting around a kitchen table. We searched the word “sorry” in our Gmail accounts, and then we tried performing the emails that we found. We talked about the secret rules of texting. We texted each other. When we travelled, we had rehearsal over Skype (once) and shared stories about visiting old friends. We friended each other. One of us moved away for grad school. We chatted with another friend and emailed her the script.* We posted a Facebook event, and then people showed up at our friend’s apartment. We squished into a Bed-Stuy brownstone’s living room over several hot spring nights and made something live - in person, in the present.

Audiences said:

“One word: devastating. This show really tapped into some deep anxieties I think we all share to some degree about friendship, loyalty, the passage of time, and constantly changing methods of communication in what can be an increasingly disorienting world.”
“I thought the show was a beautiful (and rare) exploration of female friendship. Theatrical, magical, and fun, with an emotionally raw underbelly.”
“What felt strange was balanced by what felt very familiar, creating a creeping sense of witnessing something that was beyond natural, but rather True."

The Present

You’re reading this on a screen. That we know. We thought a lot about what your experience reading this text would be like, but we have no idea. We hope you’re feeling good (and generous).

Over a year and a half after we began, we're still obsessed with this play. We're still living in its world. We're still analyzing text messages and tending to our Facebook profiles and wondering what the relationship is between our digital and real life selves.

The Future

With your support, we're going to bring We Were Nothing! to a larger audience. We've got our dream venue lined up - a big beautiful loft apartment on Broadway, just northwest of Union Square. We're going to run for three weekends, so we can build on press and word of mouth. And we're taking responsibility for our production by compensating artists and our collaborators fairly, as well as paying for precautions like insurance and a first aid kit. Your contribution will help us cover these new costs, as well as paying for the set, lights, costumes, and props.

It’s a big jump from brainstorming around a kitchen table to inviting strangers and critics to see our work. But that's what this is about - taking a risk to come together in a room and share an experience. That’s why we’re reaching out for your support.

Please take the leap with us by making a tax-deductible donation.

Clicking one of the reward buttons on the right will set indiegogo algorithms in motion. We'll get in touch with you through the method you've selected: text, letter, message in a bottle, package, or in person. And We Were Nothing! will be something because of your kind support!

story:
Our organization believes that 'One is too small a number to achieve anything great!'(Author Unknown). The primary mission of Greatness Is In You, founded by Kareem Rogers, is to help EVERY CHILD/YOUTH in the Philadelphia area discover and cultivate their GREATNESS. Join us as we open our state-of- the-art Education & Arts Center in the Germantown Section of Philadelphia.

Our programming will include: 

Education & Arts Summer Program

Readers Theater

Mentoring

Art and Theater Training

Family Theater Series

You donations will help us purchase needed equipment to bring Education to life through theater and the arts.  

Light and Sound System

Theater Training Curriculum

Plywood and supplies to build sets

Power Tools

Stage Curtains

Easels

Art Supplies

Chairs

Join us as we help our youth discover their GREATNESS.

Thank You
Kareem Rogers

Founder

story:
Our Story


b current Performing Arts and Theatre Archipelago are two independent theatre companies in Toronto who have come together to stage the world premiere of Nicole Brooks' Obeah Opera. This Caribbean themed opera is sung entirely a capella (just voice, no musical instruments) by 5 leads and a chorus of 10 women.b current has been developing Obeah Opera for the last four years;  the full premiere production is February 16 to March 4 at the 918 Bathurst Centre for Culture, as part of the Black History Month festivities in Toronto.


Set in the late 17th century, Obeah Opera tells a story of women silenced by the most infamous 'witch-hunt' in history. Tituba and a handful of Caribbean women imported as slaves into the American colony of Salem are arrested and accused of practicing obeah! A healing art seen only as blasphemy and witchcraft through the eyes of the local Puritans.We follow Tituba in the days before her capture, her incarceration, and her stand on trial in this uplifting operatic journey. Obeah Opera explodes myths surrounding the Salem Witch Trials, unravels the branding of obeah with evil and witchery through tying it back to its true spiritual nature rooted in West Africa, and finally, it gives voice to a group of women whose story has been missing from history.


We have raised some of the money needed through public funding but have fallen drastically short on the private and corporate funding support; even after continuously scaling back the size of our budget for the last three months but still aiming for cutting edge production aesthetics. With a top notch cast and crew, signed up to work on this ground breaking opera for way less than what they are worth, we see no more possible budget cuts. So, we are setting a 30-day challenge to raise $10,000 between now and opening night.


The Impact
 

Musicals are popular, and many people who don't usually attend live theatre go to see commercial musicals as a once-in-a-while night out. Obeah Opera is steeped in centuries of black music, and will definitely satisfy this once-in-a-while musical desire. Plus the subject matter will resonate and allow both casual and regular theatre audiences to enjoy ruminating well after watching. The show also affirms Caribbean cultural pride for the cast, crew and audiences alike! 


From early showcasing of Obeah Opera, audiences have been extremely excited. The anticipation was palpable 

during the 10th rock.paper.sistahz Festival where a final previewing was filled beyond capacity (and another 20-30 people turned away for lack of standing room!). Feedback from audience members ranges from:

â€œThe most profound piece of theatre I have seen in yearsâ€ to â€œA fantastic odysseyâ€

And, â€œ[It] speaks directly to my own backgroundâ€¦â€ & â€œCanâ€™t wait for the production"

 

While our box office revenue is a conservative projection, we cannot depend on this as a huge income stream. Your donation can help us to break even. Keeping us out of debt will allow us to  mount Obeah Opera and be in a good position to handle future new productions too.  

 

What We Need & What You Get 


We need to raise $10,000 in 40 days. With the funds we raise on indiegogo, we will offset any potential deficit. No amount is too small, and every dollar will go towards paying an actor, a designer or a stage crew. Your contribution gives us the peace of mind that come closing night we will be able to meet all our financial commitments for this production. You get our thanks in the way of your name listed as a sponsor, a special customized gift,  and everyone who donates can receive a charitable receipt for contributing!

 

Additional Ways You Can Help
  
Here are a few additional ways you can help us before opening night and through the run of the show: 


1. Facebook
    * Like our Facebook page and invite all your friends: 
 http://www.facebook.com/
    * Change your profile picture to our campaign poster (see our FB page).
2. Twitter
    * Twitter about the show and follow us at @obeahopera
3. Email:
    * Share our campaign link with friends, family, colleagues & more!
4. Other: 
    * Write about us on your blog and/or newsletters.

    * Write to your local and online media about us.
5 . Obeah Opera Website & Blog    
    * Read & share our blog, plus encourage others to buy tickets!
http://www.obeahopera.com & http://www.obeahopera.wordpress.com

story:
Our Story

Performing Arts Academy is committed to building the skills and confidence of each participant through the performing arts in a safe space for learning, and raise funds and awareness for local and international missions through performance. Students join us to explore, create, and perform in classes and full scale productions. Students study music, voice, theory, acting, improvisation, dance, and technical theatre. Young people exercise their imagination and grow in wonderful and unexpected ways. We are hoping to fund scholarships for ten participants through this project. Scholarship winners are selected on the basis of financial need and funds available. Your contribution, of ANY size, is very much appreciated.


The Impact

Through this campaign we would like to fund scholarships for ten participants through this project.  This would help students who would not be able to attend if not for this program.  Its shown that the arts help students grow in many ways.  Please help make this a possibility for all students.


What We Need & What You Get

In order to make it possible for these students to attend we are looking to raise $4,500.  If we are not able to meet this goal we will put it towards as many students as we can. 


We would like to offer the following at different levels as gifts for helping us out:

Understudy ($25): Water Bottle with PAA logo 

Actor’s Circle ($26-99) Super Soft Tri-blend T-shirt with PAA logo and Water Bottle with PAA logo

Designer’s Circle ($100-249) Stainless Steel Thermal Coffee Tumbler with PAA logo,  Water Bottle with PAA logo, and Super Soft Tri-blend T-shirt with PAA logo 

Producer’s Circle ($250-499) Tote with PAA logo, Water Bottle with PAA logo, and Super Soft Tri-blend T-shirt with PAA logo, and Stainless Steel Thermal Coffee Tumbler with PAA logo. 

Director’s Circle ($500 and above): Fleece Jacket with PAA logo, Water Bottle with PAA logo, and Super Soft Tri-blend T-shirt with PAA logo, Stainless Steel Thermal Coffee Tumbler with PAA logo, and Tote with PAA logo.

story:
There's A New Children's Christmas Story!

On a mission to exchange coins for a tooth on Christmas Eve,
the Tooth Fairy accidentally knocks Santa dizzy with her bag of coins. He must rest and can't continue. Flustered, yet encouraged by Little Sally Ann, whose tooth came out, the Tooth Fairy agrees to deliver the toys. Many hilarious happenings occur as she finds her way to Santa's sleigh. The reindeer grumble and are not happy; she doesn't know their names, yet they know the way. What to do? And, she is working off of two lists; her tooth list and Santa's. Will she get them mixed up? All's well that ends well and Santa is OK, and Sally Ann has a normal Christmas. Her presents are under the tree and in her stocking, and a shiny quarter is under her pillow. However, the rest of the children in the world wake up with all their presents under their pillows!

You Ought To Know Me First.

Three years ago I wrote "One Story of Art" a 6-minute film by Blue Marble Productions for The Marco island Center for the Arts in Florida. I am the subject of the film--Lynn M. Holley, M.A., an Executive Consultant to the Arts, now living in Los Angeles. I wrote the script. I am a credible storyteller and writer as well as a fund raiser and campaign manager.

 Join me on my journey; join Sally Ann and the Tooth Fairy on theirs. I am confident you will have fun with the story, and be glad you can help children understand the need to care for their teeth.

 How The Tooth Fairy Saved Christmas was written for family and friends. It was illustrated by a close friend and colleague, Sue Ellen Mathers.

With your help I now begin a Campaign to turn this delightful story into a series of readings and a stage-play. Long-range plans are to produce a professionally animated version for download, purchase or broadcast. Longer-range plans include making it a musical.

What is special about this Christmas Story, beside the fun and twists? 

It's New.

It's Wholesome.

Children, teens and adults may be cast in the play not to mention Santa and the Tooth Fairy. 

 There are lessons to be learned about helping in an emergency and not being afraid to take risks.

 It also offers parents and pediatric dentists an opportunity to spread the word about the essential need for the care of teeth, especially in children.

One in five kids in the USA have cavities that go untreated, which may cause more problems and serious health issues.

 

From the Script

Act II, Scene I. (Up On the Roof Top the 8 Reindeer are dancing and prancing in place, jingling their bells and singing, until Dasher turns and sees the Tooth Fairy).

Dasher: Oh boy Dancer, we've got problems; there's a fairy on the chimney with the old man's bag of toys. Not good. Not good!

Dancer: Whow everyone. Hold it! There's a problem.

(The Reindeer stop, except Cupid who is oblivious; the rest look toward Dasher then back at the chimney)

Dasher: It's goin' to be OK. I'm the lead pony tonight; I'll trot over and see what's up.

Dancer: You're not a pony; how many times has Santa told you that?

The rest of the Reindeer: Yeah, you're not a pony, we are Reindeer, Santa's Reindeer!

Dasher: I don't care. I trot like a pony and my cousin is a horse. Just watch my back.

Dancer: All right, all right. Go. We've got a time-crunch. (He unhooks Dasher and bumps him over toward the chimney. Dasher struts and swaggers his way toward the Tooth Fairy.)

Tooth Fairy (Flustered, muttering and dusting off her dress, coils when she sees Dasher and puts her hands up to keep him at a distance): Stay, stay, I'm just filling in. Santa's...

 

What has been accomplished already:

  1. The play has been written.
  2. The original storybook has been published.
  3. The story has been registered with the Writer's Guild of the West.
  4. The play has been reviewed with comments by a veteran stage actress and director.
  5. Hollywood Actress Jennifer Laks will read as the Tooth Fairy. 
  6. A few other actors have been chosen to read other parts for the series of readings.
  7. A theater will be chosen for the first reading in Los Angeles; and another in Santa Barbara.
  8. 2014 Spring dates are being chosen for the readings.
  9. Research into possible venues/theaters for the full production are beginning.
  10. A list of potential Sponsors is being developed for full play production.

What must happen next:

  1. The play must be finalized for readings, casting, distriution.
  2. Invitations and advertising for the readings will be sent.
  3. Rehersals for the readings to be scheduled.
  4. All venues and dates for readings finalized.
  5. More books need to be purchased for marketing, outreach and donors.
  6. A Director, theater and cast must be secured for the production.
  7. Dates must be finalized for a production.
  8. Sponsors must be found for parties and underwriting final production.
  9. Appropriate music must be found for background (this is not a musical (however, it lends itself to one in the future).

Goal I - $ 500

Print more copies of the storybook for marketing and PR.

Goal 2 - $1,500

Finalize and print the play for distribution, casting, rehersals and readings.

Goal 2- $ $2,500

Create a website, brochure for marketing and PR in print and on-line.

Goal 4 - $ 3,500 Readings and Parties.

Produce two readings in Los Angeles and one in Santa Barbara.

Find a director, cast and a theater for full production. 

Identify an organization to receive a % of net-revenue from the production of the play to promote pediatric dental care.

Goal 5- $26,000

Produce the Play in a theater. 

Your Benefit.

You are part of a new story for children and family entertainment. This project and play have been accepted by a 501(c) Non-profit arts-mentoring organization as its fiscal receiver.Your donations are tax deductable to the extent of the tax laws. You will also be helping to spread the word on the need for pediatric dental care.

The Impact.

This fun-filled story is destined to become a new Children's Christmas Classic, by stage and animation. It has great potential to create awareness about the need for pedatric dental care. Each child who attends the play will receive a dental care package.

Other Ways You Can Help.

Offer contacts for dentist, pediatric associations, actors, animator or theater groups or any corporation that might like the connection and publicity. Like us on Facebook and send information out to those you know who might be interested in getting this story further off the ground and into new mediums. After you donate, find others to follow you on this theatrical journey. Be an active part of this project. I need your support.
story_txt:
There's A New Children's Christmas Story!On a mission to exchange coins for a tooth on Christmas Eve,the Tooth Fairy accidentally knocks Santa dizzy with her bag of coins. He must rest and can't continue. Flustered, yet encouraged by Little Sally Ann, whose tooth came out, the Tooth Fairy agrees to deliver the toys. Many hilarious happenings occur as she finds her way to Santa's sleigh. The reindeer grumble and are not happy; she doesn't know their names, yet they know the way. What to do? And, she is working off of two lists; her tooth list and Santa's. Will she get them mixed up? All's well that ends well and Santa is OK, and Sally Ann has a normal Christmas. Her presents are under the tree and in her stocking, and a shiny quarter is under her pillow. However, the rest of the children in the world wake up with all their presents under their pillows!You Ought To Know Me First. Three years ago I wrote "One Story of Art" a 6-minute film by Blue Marble Productions for The Marco island Center for the Arts in Florida. I am the subject of the film--Lynn M. Holley, M.A., an Executive Consultant to the Arts, now living in Los Angeles. I wrote the script. I am a credible storyteller and writer as well as a fund raiser and campaign manager. Join me on my journey; join Sally Ann and the Tooth Fairy on theirs. I am confident you will have fun with the story, and be glad you can help children understand the need to care for their teeth. How The Tooth Fairy Saved Christmas was written for family and friends. It was illustrated by a close friend and colleague, Sue Ellen Mathers.With your help I now begin a Campaign to turn this delightful story into a series of readings and a stage-play. Long-range plans are to produce a professionally animated version for download, purchase or broadcast. Longer-range plans include making it a musical.What is special about this Christmas Story, beside the fun and twists?  It's New. It's Wholesome. Children, teens and adults may be cast in the play not to mention Santa and the Tooth Fairy.  There are lessons to be learned about helping in an emergency and not being afraid to take risks. It also offers parents and pediatric dentists an opportunity to spread the word about the essential need for the care of teeth, especially in children. One in five kids in the USA have cavities that go untreated, which may cause more problems and serious health issues. From the ScriptAct II, Scene I.
