story:
Short Summary


A five hundred year old Faust has been successfully staying one step ahead of the Demons charged with pulling his soul down to Hell but every once in a while the Devil locates him and Faust must evade, hide and escape from the Devil's agents. 

The audience are conjured as dreamers into the space to obscure Faust from the diabolical creatures without. They are sealed into the room with Faust and told that they must not open the door for one bare hour. Faust gives the audience his story in return, detailing how he came to sell his soul however, things do not go to plan, they are discovered and The Devil Without starts to manifest within. 
A terrifying struggle ensues as the Devil starts to make his presence felt resulting in a battle for Faust's survival and a member of the audience's soul.

Who am I?

I am an actor and performer of mentalism and hypnosis, you can check out my website: www.theempathist.com

and my YouTube Channel:

www.youtube.com/channel/UCf0-B4qCQJpbo52bJFwkQRQ

I read people- their minds, their feelings, their bodies. I'm a lover of mystery, magic and the arcane. Last year I took a show called 'Your Place or Mind' to Brighton and Edinburgh having toured it in the UK and Abroad. I've played Off-Broadway, theatres in the Far East and Corporate functions in swish hotels in Asia and Europe as well as performing impromptu in the street.

I collect skills wherever I go, whenever I find a willing teacher. I have been performing for over ten years and have directed and put up my own shows and now I have a golden opportunity and a golden team to make this project..


With this exciting, immersive performance, I hope to lead the audience into a dark, rich world of fantasy such as those enjoyed by readers of comics and graphic novels. It is my intention to use media, suggestion, imagination and the mystery arts alongside solid story-telling to provoke, play, scare and confound the audience. They will be complicit in Faust's journey, they will make decisions that impact upon how the hour turns out and there will be a vital moment where an unsuspecting member of the audience will experience the creeping sensation of possession live on stage.

The performance will feature an original score by Daniel Sarstedt, son of Ivor Novello award winner Peter Sarstedt and member of Danish electronica band Det Sejler  I Effekter including a 'silent score' using infrasound designed to be felt rather than heard. 

The show itself has more rare talents on-board to ensure an unforgettable experience including:

Peter Bryant- an expert in binaural beats and infrasonic sound is giving professional advice on sound design.

Mr. X- A renowned magic consultant to Derren Brown, Dynamo, David Blaine and Criss angel consults on the mechanics of the special effects, who wishes to remain in a cloak of mystery!

Anthony Jacquin- Experienced hypnotist and author of Reality is Plastic ' will be working with me on the imaginative journey taken by the audiencewww.anthonyjacquin.com

  • Anthony Jacquin`s Website

    www.anthonyjacquin.com

    E. Raymond Carlyle- son of Houdini's prop maker acts as mentalism consultant and executive producer. Ed ran The Houdini Seance at Hollywood's famous Magic Castle for over ten years and I am proud to call him my mentor. Ed is a world-class thought-reader. and magical thinker.

    Glenn Fabry- world famous artist for Marvel, DC and 2000AD has created an amazing piece of art for the poster- the man who drew Judge Dredd, Batman, Thor and alternative titles such as Constantine, Neil Gaiman's Neverwhere and Preacher brings his singular style to the project.


    Glenn Fabry's 'Devil Without' Poster

    http://www.glennfabry.co.uk/

    Pete Benson- independent film-maker and winner of London Independent Film Festival award for best independent horror for 'Scar-crow' adds technical finesse, direction and knowledge.

    Christopher Gould- mystic, esoteric explorer and artisan crafts some beautiful props for the production.

    http://alchemy-moon.co.uk/

    A cutting-edge crew!

    Paul Voodini http://www.readerofminds.co.uk/

    psychic entertainer and author, offers up some choice rewards alongside

    Artist Keith Baugh http://keithbaugh.com/

    who has kindly designed some limited edition badges as an incentive to get involved.

What We Need & What You Get

The whole project is about £12'000 of investment. We've put in about thirty percent of our own money and we are busy securing funding from the corporate sector and also the Arts Council. Honestly, to do this project without compromising on quality I need to raise another £6000. I reckon we can get £2000 by crowd funding and the rest by a charity performance in July of my previous show 'Your Place or Mind'.

The money generated here will be spent on the infrasonic speakers, set design and props for the show- all of which we need to have built from scratch. Any money over and above the funding goal will go towards publicity and poster costs and paying the various collaborators involved in the project.

The perks we are offering are many and varied. If you are into comics, then look at the limited edition prints of Glenn Fabry's amazing poster and Will Simpson's contribution.

If you are into the mystery arts, I'm setting down some of my secrets into a book (which I recommend for seasoned performers only and in fact, you will have to answer a question set by me about our art in order for me to release the book to you). Paul Voodini a paranormalist and author friend of mine has very generously offered two of his signature (and rave reviewed) treatises on framing the bizarre and magical.

We got T-shirts, badges and even some experiences such as training in hypnosis with hypno-guru Anthony Jacquin. An opportunity that could change your life!

The Impact

Be Part of Something Original

By backing this project you'll be promoting and indeed, producing independent theatre. Not only that, but you'll be helping me do something that's never been done before on stage, ever.  It's not easy getting the right platform. The Edinburgh Fringe is the world's biggest arts festival and an ideal chance to showcase The Devil Without. Ideally, I want to tour this production throughout the UK, Europe, the States and beyond. To gather the sort of traction needed to give theatres confidence in the current financial climate, I have secured a good central Edinburgh venue and designed a show that will appeal to different strands of society. I'm pushing the boundaries of the actor/ audience relationship into new, unchartered territory. It's bold and scary for me as well as the audience but I fervently believe that the impacts and resonances of this project could be far-reaching.

I have gathered an exceptional set of artistes, thinkers, designers and consultants. I did this by force of will and belief in the project. You are the person I now need and I want you to lend me your support and to back this show. 

Other Ways You Can Help

You may not have any scratch! We are living through hard times, I know it. You can still help by spreading the word. Using the share tools here, tweeting, updating your status and sharing the project around is SO important. The more buzz we generate, the more pick-up we'll get.

story:
Short Summary

I am Malcolm White.  I am 87 years old and a resident of Palo Alto, CA.  I have written a play that recounts the real life experiences of an 6 year old Polish Jewish boy,  named Richard Rozen, and his inspirational journey to overcome great odds during the holocaust to eventually become a celebrated chess and bridge champion, among many other achievements. 

The dream of getting back on stage one last time to share this wonderful real-life story gives me the energy to sustain my own health matters.  While I struggle with heart surgeries, and dialysis 3 times per week, I am propelled not only by the story of Richard Rozen overcoming his odds, but because it is my dream to act once again on stage.

Your purchase of tickets, or donation of a ticket to a local student, will go to fund our production, currently planned for April 25-27 at the Menlo Atherton Performing Arts Center.  

Not only will your support be fulfilling my dream, while promoting a message of tolerance, but we are also certain you will enjoy this wonderful moment on stage with Richard Rozen there in person.

Learn more at www.mynameisrichardrozen.com

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need a venue, set, lighting, sound and marketing.  We will size the production accordingly, but we are eager to reserve a venue that seats 500 and plan on running up to 4 shows....so we want to presell as many tickets as possible!
  • Approximately 25% of all profits going to War Child http://www.warchild.org/ to help support children in conflict zones today.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are wide open for sponsors

  • We are wide open for sponsors (both private and corporate).
  • Consider buying a ticket for you, a friend, and donate one to a local student.
  • Please share this campaign with your friends, and family.

story:
Summary

This project continues the development of WHYTEBERG’s most recent work, as occurred as recalled, which was produced and supported by Live Arts Exchange (LAX Festival) in September 2016 at Automata Theatre and its surrounding areas in Chinatown, Los Angeles. The piece is a site-sensitive work exploring visceral memories and guides the audience through non-traditional dance spaces to create a series of images and vignettes. As the audience moves through various scenes, the piece becomes a personal reflection of perception. Due to the sectional nature of the piece, it is ideal to take in residency for further development in collaboration with Boise-based company Project Flux.

This collaboration with Project Flux is the first opportunity WHYTEBERG has had to work in residency in another city, further exploring new spaces, choreographic inspirations, as well as dancing alongside a new group of professional dancers. Cross-collaborations such as this provide WHYTEBERG immersive insight into the creative workings of other companies as well as inspiration from a new city and different dancers. It provides Project Flux a skeleton for both companies to work within, culminating in a unique experience, which is situationally specific for company members and local audience members alike.  The skeletal concept and the opportunity to build anew on that armature is what makes this project forward-thinking and transferable. This is a new kind of residency we are interested in pursuing across the US and this residency with Project Flux is the first step in making this new kind of collaborative work possible.

The residency would include a weeklong Research and Development phase in which WHYTEBERG dancers and Project Flux dancers would rehearse to create new sections based on dancers’ memories and find corresponding local spaces in Boise for these sections. There would be a 2 show run of the piece during the final weekend of our residency. During the rehearsal period, we have scheduled multiple master classes for local dancers, taught by WHYTEBERG, our dancers, Matt Luck and Jobel Medina, and Lydia Sakolsky-Basquill.

Travel Budget

Here's where you come in! We need your help getting WHYTEBERG to and from Los Angeles! 

WHYTEBERG’s travel costs are listed below.  Choreographer and dancer pay & per diem, space rental, accommodation, and technical costs are covered generously by Project Flux and their donors, as well as revenue generated through workshops and ticket sales. 

Airfare: $650 for Laura and Gracie, roundtrip for Treefort

Driving: $200 for Laura and Gracie, roundtrip for the residency

Airfare: $650 for Matt and Jobel (dancers), roundtrip for the residency

Grand Total: $1,500

Timeline

March 24: WHYTEBERG arrives in Boise for Treefort

March 26: Treefort performance

June 16: WHYTEBERG & dancers arrive in Boise for residency

June 17-22: WHYTEBERG and Project Flux in rehearsal developing new material

June 19-22: evening master classes offered to local pre-professional and professional dancers dancers

June 23-24: Performance

Bios

WHYTEBERG is a Los Angeles based duo created by Gracie Whyte and Laura Berg as a platform for their collaborative work. Since their inception in August 2014,  WHYTEBERG has created and performed work for stage and film, including Warner Bros. produced “Dang,” a music video for hip-hop musicians Mac Miller and Anderson .Paak and an evening of dance hosted by Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros at their Pop-Up Gallery. WHYTEBERG has performed live work at venues such as REDCAT, Musco Center for the Arts, Tempe Center for the Arts, Robert B Moore Theatre, Bootleg Theatre, Electric Lodge, among others. They teach a floorwork and release class to professionals in Los Angeles and college-level students at universities such as CSULB, LMU, Chapman, UCLA, CSULA.  Gracie and Laura are most interested in figuring out how to blend disciplines, integrating dance into other genres to elevate the level of art being created.

 

Project Flux:

Since its inception in 2013, Project Flux has established a strong following amongst Boise audiences and the Treasure Valley dance community, presenting works that fuse intricate gestural movement with classical technique and improvised play.  It has previously collaborated with many local artists and companies including Ballet Idaho, Boise Dance Co-op, Idaho Dance Theatre, MING Studios, Off Center Dance, Treefort Music Fest, and Boise State University's Summer Dancefest.

 

Reviews for as occurred, as recalled:

https://seedance.com/news/whyteberg-performs-provocative-work-automata/

http://riting.la/post/151812352284/as-occurred-as-recalled-by-whyteberg
story_txt: SummaryThis project continues the development of WHYTEBERG’s most recent work, as occurred as recalled, which was produced and supported by Live Arts Exchange (LAX Festival) in September 2016 at Automata Theatre and its surrounding areas in Chinatown, Los Angeles. The piece is a site-sensitive work exploring visceral memories and guides the audience through non-traditional dance spaces to create a series of images and vignettes. As the audience moves through various scenes, the piece becomes a personal reflection of perception. Due to the sectional nature of the piece, it is ideal to take in residency for further development in collaboration with Boise-based company Project Flux.This collaboration with Project Flux is the first opportunity WHYTEBERG has had to work in residency in another city, further exploring new spaces, choreographic inspirations, as well as dancing alongside a new group of professional dancers. Cross-collaborations such as this provide WHYTEBERG immersive insight into the creative workings of other companies as well as inspiration from a new city and different dancers. It provides Project Flux a skeleton for both companies to work within, culminating in a unique experience, which is situationally specific for company members and local audience members alike.  The skeletal concept and the opportunity to build anew on that armature is what makes this project forward-thinking and transferable. This is a new kind of residency we are interested in pursuing across the US and this residency with Project Flux is the first step in making this new kind of collaborative work possible.The residency would include a weeklong Research and Development phase in which WHYTEBERG dancers and Project Flux dancers would rehearse to create new sections based on dancers’ memories and find corresponding local spaces in Boise for these sections. There would be a 2 show run of the piece during the final weekend of our residency. During the rehearsal period, we have scheduled multiple master classes for local dancers, taught by WHYTEBERG, our dancers, Matt Luck and Jobel Medina, and Lydia Sakolsky-Basquill.Travel BudgetHere's where you come in! We need your help getting WHYTEBERG to and from Los Angeles! WHYTEBERG’s travel costs are listed below.  Choreographer and dancer pay & per diem, space rental, accommodation, and technical costs are covered generously by Project Flux and their donors, as well as revenue generated through workshops and ticket sales. Airfare: $650 for Laura and Gracie, roundtrip for TreefortDriving: $200 for Laura and Gracie, roundtrip for the residencyAirfare: $650 for Matt and Jobel (dancers), roundtrip for the residencyGrand Total: $1,500TimelineMarch 24: WHYTEBERG arrives in Boise for TreefortMarch 26: Treefort performanceJune 16: WHYTEBERG & dancers arrive in Boise for residencyJune 17-22: WHYTEBERG and Project Flux in rehearsal developing new materialJune 19-22: evening master classes offered to local pre-professional and professional dancers dancersJune 23-24: PerformanceBiosWHYTEBERG is a Los Angeles based duo created by Gracie Whyte and Laura Berg as a platform for their collaborative work. Since their inception in August 2014,  WHYTEBERG has created and performed work for stage and film, including Warner Bros. produced “Dang,” a music video for hip-hop musicians Mac Miller and Anderson .Paak and an evening of dance hosted by Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros at their Pop-Up Gallery. WHYTEBERG has performed live work at venues such as REDCAT, Musco Center for the Arts, Tempe Center for the Arts, Robert B Moore Theatre, Bootleg Theatre, Electric Lodge, among others. They teach a floorwork and release class to professionals in Los Angeles and college-level students at universities such as CSULB, LMU, Chapman, UCLA, CSULA.  Gracie and Laura are most interested in figuring out how to blend disciplines, integrating dance into other genres to elevate the level of art being created. Project Flux:Since its inception in 2013, Project Flux has established a strong following amongst Boise audiences and the Treasure Valley dance community, presenting works that fuse intricate gestural movement with classical technique and improvised play.  It has previously collaborated with many local artists and companies including Ballet Idaho, Boise Dance Co-op, Idaho Dance Theatre, MING Studios, Off Center Dance, Treefort Music Fest, and Boise State University's Summer Dancefest. Reviews for as occurred, as recalled:https://seedance.com/news/whyteberg-performs-provocative-work-automata/http://riting.la/post/151812352284/as-occurred-as-recalled-by-whyteberg

story:
For the last half decade I have been creating performance works with my company Zullo/RawMovement exploring the human condition and pushing the boundaries of how we experience a performance. 

In the new work The Architecture of Proximity, I am interested in erasing the boundary between performer and spectator and delves into the physical, emotional and psychological affects that space has on the body. We will do this by exploring architecture, movement, sound, and the relationship between isolation and intimacy. Composer David Engelhard will create an original, interactive sound score for the work. The music will be performed live and is unique for each performance and as he responds to the spontaneous choices the dancers make within the shifting landscape of the work. 

The Architecture of Proximity will have a 5 night performance run this October 28th through November 1st at the Theater at the 14th Street Y in NYC. This will be our longest performance engagement to date!
 The money raised from this campaign will help us to cover the rehearsal costs, the performer rehearsal and performance payments and the theater rental fees. Publicist Michelle Tabnick will work with Zullo for the 3rd time on the marketing and promoting of the work, a lighting designer will be hired and the architectural spaces must be constructed, these and a myriad of other costs are involved in creating this work and sharing the experience with as many of you as possible!
As the work has been in developed, I had the pleasure of being 1 of 6 artists chosen for FLICfest 2015 at the Irondale Center in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. From FLICfest I received a residency to begin the exploration of this work and 2 fully produced performances to see how the work was developing. This was a transformative experience for me as well as many of the guests at the performances. I witnessed a physical transformation within audience members from uncertainty and trepidation in this new performance environment to trust and openness as well as a willingness to explore the new and unknown and were changed by the experience of proximity and intimacy as a collective group in a common world. This convinced me that this is my most important and innovative work to date and that it deserves to be experienced by a wider audience. 

Your Support is Vital in Creating and Sharing The Architecture of Proximity with the World. 

Thank you for your belief in us,
John, David & RawMovement

Zullo/RawMovement is a sponsored artist with Performance Zone Inc (dba The Field), a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community. Contributions to The Field earmarked for Zullo/RawMovement are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906 New York, NY 10038, phone: 212-691-6969 or fax: 212-255-2053 or for our national charities registration, see details. A copy of our latest financial report may be obtained from The Field or from the Office of Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

story:
Two city dwellers, Sabrina and Matteo, seek escape from the drudgery of urban living into the countryside. A search for a robin’s nest from Sabrina’s past leads them beyond beyond, where they hitch a ride on a dirigible helmed by a people on the verge of extinction: The Kioskers. 

Told through a haunting score performed by a troupe of strange players, The Kioskers mixes toy theater, shadow puppetry, projected stop animation, live music and performance to tell a wholly original and magical story about love, friendship, and loss.



Sara C. Walsh brings Adkins’ fantastical worlds to life first by opening a suitcase. Out of these suitcases come the puppets, the dirigible that the Kioskers travel in, props, clouds, and a motorcycle. Alaina Ferris composes haunting, lyrical music that sustains the flight of the dirigible over the seven seas. With director Mia Rovegno at the helm, the journey of Matteo and Sabrina is brought to life as we see them traveling across the world with the kiosk attendants in a dirigible that’s like a floating palace but rather wants to be something more like the Titanic.

Project History:

The Kioskers has been in continuous development with workshop performances at Dixon Place, Rabbit Hole Studio, Uncanny Valley, and the Prelude12 Closing Party.  The project is currently under development as part of the St. Ann’s Warehouse Puppet Lab 2015-2016. In September of 2015, the Kioskers will have a week long  Deep Space Performance Residency at NACL in upstate New York culminating in two performances to present the work achieved during the residency.

So Why do we need funding now:

We have received a great opportunity to have six days of uninterrupted time at the NACL Deep Space residency starting September 7th, 2015.  We are in need of funding to:

  • transport ten artists to NACL -  Highland Lake, NY
  • provide food for three meals a day for all ten artists
  • cover the cost of materials for creating the puppets
  • pay the artists a modest stipend of $250

NACL has generously helped us a by providing our project with a $400 stipend, housing, and exclusive use of their theater, but we need your help to get the rest of the way there. 


Our Budget for the DEEP Space Residency:


Every single dollar helps us get where we’re going.  Our initial fundraising is for our September residency however any dollars received over our budget will go toward the future of the project which will culminate in a full production in April 2016. 


Lend us a hand.

The Kioskers Club:

Do you want to be a part of our process?  Every person who donates becomes part of the Kioskers Club.  Every two weeks we will give you a sneak peak into our process and throw at you some surprise treats.


Other Ways You Can Help:

  • Tell you friends about our project!  Share our campaign.  Share our website.
  • Sign up for our newsletter so you can stay in the loop.
  • Like us on Facebook. 

The Kioskers is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas.

story:
A High School Musical!

Well, a bunch of adults putting on a play about high school. Dark Times at Grimesville High is a new musical by LA writer Conor Kyle. This dark comedy follows Olivia Hope, hard-hitting school journalist, all around great friend, and future valedictorian as she writes her magnum opus for the Grimesville Times--an expose about the darkest parts of high school. With Peyton Hillridge, the school's undisputed number one mean girl around to help, what could possibly go wrong? 

...everything.

The Capital Fringe Festival

This production is presented as a part of the 2016 Capital Fringe Festival, a program of the Washington, DC non-profit Capital Fringe. The show is being produced at the festival without the financial help of an existing theatre company, which is why we need your help to make it happen! Here's what you can help with:

  • Fringe participation fees
  • Artist stipends
  • Marketing materials
  • Script printing
  • Rehearsal space rental

You Can Make a Difference!

By helping us out, you become an essential part of the Dark Times at Grimesville High team. While this story is at surface a dark comedy, it also has an extremely honest heart. The cast and creative team is comprised entirely of young, up-and-coming artists who cannot wait to share both the story and their talents with the DC theatre community. 

Every Bit Counts

Can't contribute? We're all young, not quite starving artists, so we totally get it. But you can still help!

  • Buy tickets! Everyone who's anyone goes to Fringe!
  • Share this page! The more people find out about us, the better.
  • Like and share our Facebook page,  https://www.facebook.com/darktimesatgrimesvillehigh/, for all sorts of exciting updates!

...and it might just be the best legally mandated time of your life

story:
Rick Borutta - First Time Solo Writer/Performer

Hi. After several years in the theatre supporting other performers and creators such as Elaine Stritch (Elaine Stritch At Liberty) and Tommy Tune - and years of deep, personal inner growth work - I am prepared to present my first full-length solo show. I've spent years in a deep soul-searching journey using symbols, myths and ritual to awaken my inner creative self. After previous unsuccessful attempts to tell my biographical story through screenplays  and novels I now have a complete 90-minute script. 
Classes in writing and performing have helped me shape my script and for the debut performance I am working with director Abby Lorenz who studied with Ann Randolph (Squeeze Box, Loveland).
This performance represents a major achievement for me personally, as well as the threshold to a future of "taking this show on the road" with future bookings.
By contributing, you will ensure the successful support I need to be on that stage alone - allowing my creativity to be uninhibited by concerns for money, staff, and presentation.

$2,500 - Phase 1 

  • $800 for two-day hall rental. It allows us to set up lighting the day before and rehearse. The performance and strike are on day two.
  • $500 for lighting and sound rental. Every audience member remembers bad lighting and poor sound. This minimal rental fee will provide basic equipment to offer a smooth technical experience.
  • $400 for stage drapes and window coverings (duvytene) Fabrics that will cover windows in the space during the matinee, and a white backdrop so light can splash onto it artfully. 
  • $700 to pay people! I have a director who has already been working with me for several weeks. A photographer will be creating professional images for me (at a bargain price) to use for promotions. And, I need to hire a stage manager to pick up the equipment, set it up, run it during the show and return it to Salinas. 
  • Further funding will go to the website, entry fees to fringe festivals, travel for upcoming dates, etc....
  • PERKS! Some of you will be able to purchase a "Reserved" seat at The Big Sur Grange with your $20 donation. $50 comes with seating, and a signed copy of the script in a bound digitally printed paperback AND your name in the acknowledgements! $100 comes with the previous, plus a DVD or digital download of the performance. $150 - everything plus a 75-minute astrology reading by me.
  • If the $2,500 goal is not met, all funds will continue to go towards the above expenses. There will be donations at the door and any shortfall will be met by my personal funds.

Impact

As a former producer of videos and short films and as a stage manager to theatrical musicals and solo shows, I have an innate understanding of how to put on a presentation for an audience, with attention to detail, timing and moving pieces. A successful campaign for my solo show raises the bar - it challenges me to go beyond what I know and take a risk IN FRONT of my audience. I will be putting my deeply personal stories on the line. The growth for me - and I hope for my audience - will continue on from this show to future ones. 

Preparation

Abby Lorenz and I have been working on my script since June. Recently, I read the script for 30 people and their reactions and feedback will continue to support the editing and shaping of the final script to be staged. There is one more public reading before this first staged and memorized performance. All the pieces are coming together and with your help, the finished look for the show will have the feel of an intimate studio theater space. 

Social Media

As always, your support by sharing my campaign with your network will mean so much to the success of my show. Thank you!

story:
We are Submersive Productions

Submersive Productions is a collaborative artworks company that combines artistic disciplines to create memorable and profound audience experiences. We strive to activate unused, underused or unusual spaces in Baltimore, engage local talent, and compensate artists for their work.

We are passionate about our city and the amazing, creative humans that dwell in it. We believe in the power of immersive theater to connect people and ask bold questions, and we want to make Baltimore a center for such artworks.

With our exciting new project, H.T. Darling's Incredible Musaeum presents: The Treasures of New Galapagos, Astonishing Acquisitions from the Perisphere, we will create a truly unique world for visitors to explore, bring life to an architectural gem, and reach out to new audiences. Alongside our talented collaborators of performing artists, visual artists, designers and fabricators, this is the biggest, wildest project we have ever undertaken. Did we mention that there will be puppets?

We're Asking for Your Help

We need to raise $18,000 to help make this production a reality. We want to be clear - this is only about 30% of the budget needed for such a large show. The remaining monies will come from grants, ticket sales, and in-kind donations. Here's how we would spend the $18,000 that we are requesting here:

  • Paying our Cast, Crew and Creative Team for their contributions to the work. (50%)
  • Purchasing materials necessary for building the sets, props, costumes and puppets that will create the rich texture of this world. (30%)
  • Renting and/or purchasing lighting and audio equipment. (15%)
  • Covering the costs of marketing materials and programs, including printing. (5%)

Whatever your donation, we want to give you something in return. We've got a terrific array of perks, from personal thank-yous, to advance notice of ticket sales, to dinner with the Cast, Crew and Creative Team. And here's some really exciting news: if we exceed our goal by just $750, we can open up an additional floor of the building!

Any contribution you make is tax-deductible. Musaeum is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Musaeum must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only and are tax-­deductible to the extent permitted by law.

What's This All About, Really?

    H.T. Darling's Incredible Musaeum presents: The Treasures of New Galapagos, Astonishing Acquisitions from the Perisphere, immerses the audience inside a Belle Epoque-style cabinet of curiosities.  Within this magical yet familiar framework, a series of controversial stories unfolds. H. T. Darling is a high society explorer who has just returned from an expedition to an area of outer space, “The Perisphere,” where he has discovered a planet he calls New Galapagos. The Musaeum is presenting a grand exhibition of his findings. By interacting with the curious inhabitants of the museum, the building, and the exhibition itself, each audience member must choose their own path through the evening's strange events.

    This installation and performance will ask the audience to consider the stories we tell ourselves about authenticity and truth. Visitors will find themselves confronting the conflicting themes of western museum history: on the one hand an experience of wonder, exploration of new worlds, the beauty of the exotic; on the other hand exploitation, corruption, imperialism, and the questionable role of the patriarchy as historical authority. The current social and political climate requires artwork that prompts deep thinking, dialogue and direct interaction with others - performers and other audience members alike.

    In the last two years, we created The Mesmeric Revelations! of Edgar Allan Poe, the longest running immersive theater experience in Baltimore history, and the highly acclaimed one-woman show (Siobhan O'Loughlin) Broken Bone Bathtub. In both cases we activated historic spaces, collaborated with a diverse group of artists and performers, and brought in a wide variety of audience members, many of whom had little history of attending theatrical events. We learned so much from these productions. More importantly, these experiences helped us to hone our vision for the devising process and content of Musaeum.

    Your contribution to Musaeum, in any amount, will help us to create something wonderful and push into exciting new territory.
     
    Given the scope of this project, we know that there are challenges ahead. But, with your assistance, we feel confident - especially with such smart, creative collaborators by our side - that we will be able to bring this show to fruition.
     

    Where and When?

    The Peale Center (formerly The Peale Museum), Baltimore, Maryland

    • Test Audience Nights and Preview Nights: Late March, 2017
    • Opening Night: April 1, 2017
    • Runs Through April 30, 2017

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Excited? Want to see this show up on it's feet? Then please:

      • Share this campaign via social media or email
      • Like us on Facebook
      • Follow us on Tumblr
      • Come to the Show (Tickets on sale late January 2017)
      • Email us at info[at]SubmersiveProductions[dot]com to join our Mailing List

      From all us - Producers, Creative Team, Cast, Visual Artists, Fabricators and Crew - THANK YOU!
story_txt:
We are Submersive Productions
Submersive Productions is a collaborative artworks company that combines artistic disciplines to create memorable and profound audience experiences. We strive to activate unused, underused or unusual spaces in Baltimore, engage local talent, and compensate artists for their work.
We are passionate about our city and the amazing, creative humans that dwell in it. We believe in the power of immersive theater to connect people and ask bold questions, and we want to make Baltimore a center for such artworks.
With our exciting new project, H.T. Darling's Incredible Musaeum presents: The Treasures of New Galapagos, Astonishing Acquisitions from the Perisphere, we will create a truly unique world for visitors to explore, bring life to an architectural gem, and reach out to new audiences. Alongside our talented collaborators of performing artists, visual artists, designers and fabricators, this is the biggest, wildest project we have ever undertaken. Did we mention that there will be puppets?
We're Asking for Your Help
We need to raise $18,000 to help make this production a reality. We want to be clear - this is only about 30% of the budget needed for such a large show. The remaining monies will come from grants, ticket sales, and in-kind donations. Here's how we would spend the $18,000 that we are requesting here:

Paying our Cast, Crew and Creative Team for their contributions to the work. (50%)
Purchasing materials necessary for building the sets, props, costumes and puppets that will create the rich texture of this world. (30%)
Renting and/or purchasing lighting and audio equipment. (15%)
Covering the costs of marketing materials and programs, including printing. (5%)

Whatever your donation, we want to give you something in return. We've got a terrific array of perks, from personal thank-yous, to advance notice of ticket sales, to dinner with the Cast, Crew and Creative Team. And here's some really exciting news: if we exceed our goal by just $750, we can open up an additional floor of the building! 
Any contribution you make is tax-deductible. Musaeum is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Musaeum must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only and are tax-­deductible to the extent permitted by law.

What's This All About, Really?



H.T. Darling's Incredible Musaeum presents: The Treasures of New Galapagos, Astonishing Acquisitions from the Perisphere, immerses the audience inside a Belle Epoque-style cabinet of curiosities.  Within this magical yet familiar framework, a series of controversial stories unfolds. H. T. Darling is a high society explorer who has just returned from an expedition to an area of outer space, “The Perisphere,” where he has discovered a planet he calls New Galapagos. The Musaeum is presenting a grand exhibition of his findings. By interacting with the curious inhabitants of the museum, the building, and the exhibition itself, each audience member must choose their own path through the evening's strange events.
This installation and performance will ask the audience to consider the stories we tell ourselves about authenticity and truth. Visitors will find themselves confronting the conflicting themes of western museum history: on the one hand an experience of wonder, exploration of new worlds, the beauty of the exotic; on the other hand exploitation, corruption, imperialism, and the questionable role of the patriarchy as historical authority. The current social and political climate requires artwork that prompts deep thinking, dialogue and direct interaction with others - performers and other audience members alike.
In the last two years, we created The Mesmeric Revelations! of Edgar Allan Poe, the longest running immersive theater experience in Baltimore history, and the highly acclaimed one-woman show (Siobhan O'Loughlin) Broken Bone Bathtub. In both cases we activated historic spaces, collaborated with a diverse group of artists and performers, and brought in a wide variety of audience members, many of whom had little history of attending theatrical events. We learned so much from these productions. More importantly, these experiences helped us to hone our vision for the devising process and content of Musaeum.
Your contribution to Musaeum, in any amount, will help us to create something wonderful and push into exciting new territory.
 
Given the scope of this project, we know that there are challenges ahead. But, with your assistance, we feel confident - especially with such smart, creative collaborators by our side - that we will be able to bring this show to fruition.
 

Where and When?
The Peale Center (formerly The Peale Museum), Baltimore, Maryland

Test Audience Nights and Preview Nights: Late March, 2017
Opening Night: April 1, 2017
Runs Through April 30, 2017




Other Ways You Can Help
Excited? Want to see this show up on it's feet? Then please:

Share this campaign via social media or email
Like us on Facebook

Follow us on Tumblr

Come to the Show (Tickets on sale late January 2017)
Email us at info[at]SubmersiveProductions[dot]com to join our Mailing List

From all us - Producers, Creative Team, Cast, Visual Artists, Fabricators and Crew - THANK YOU!

story:
THE WITCH OF ST. ELMORA STREET 

A grotesque comedy by Joey Merlo 

Synopsis: 
"Blood, blood, blood!" is foretold to young Graziella by a fortune teller she seeks out in a time of romantic crises. She and her twin brother Micky have just been cheated on by their respective partners. Each seek comfort and redemption within the cacophony of their mutual heartbreak. However, rumors and their own superstitions provoke them further and further into taking revenge.  

About Joey: 
Joey Merlo is a poet, actor and playwright who has worked all over the world including Ghana, where he completed a documentary on the illegality of homosexuality called ‘Voices’ and Greece, where he took part in a collaborative residency that focused on creating public art installations and theater with both Athenian activists and students. He has worked with the Westport Country Playhouse, the Lark, Dixon Place and contributes to Out.com. Joey lives in Washington Heights and is the host of Siren Den, a monthly showcase for artists at Smalls Jazz Club in the West Village.

About This Project: 
THE WITCH OF ST. ELMORA STREET will be presented as a workshop production  at DIXON PLACE on JANUARY 8TH AT 7:30PM. Our goal is to further develop this piece through a rigorous rehearsal process that will focus on character development, script analysis and experimentation! We will utilize costumes, lighting and sound to showcase both the play and its actors to an audience as well as to theaters that may help us realize our ultimate goal: a fully-staged production! 

About Dixon Place: 
"Dixon Place is a theater organization located in New York City dedicated to the development of works-in-progess from a broad range of performers and artists. It exists to serve the creative needs of artists—emerging, mid-career and established—who are creating new work in theater, dance, music, literature, puppetry, performance, variety and visual arts." - "Dixon Place" NYC-ARTS

Website: 
http://dixonplace.org

Tickets: 
http://dixonplace.org/performances/the-witch-of...

BUDGET 
Rehearsal Space: 

33 hours of rehearsal x $20 an hour = $660

Costumes, Hair & Makeup: 

$50 per actor x 8 = $400 

Actor & Crew stipend: 

$50 per person x 8 

$360   

Printing: 

$80 

Performance Space: 

Free! (Thank you Dixon Place!) 

Total: $1,500 


Even a dollar will help us get closer to our goal!!!! Every penny counts! 

Any additional funds raised will be divided among the actors and crew as a stipend for their time and hard work! 

WHO'S INVOLVED (In order of appearance): 

CAITLIN ZOZ (Grazi) 

Caitlin Zoz is a New York based Actor.  She graduated with Honors from NYU Tisch’s Experimental Theatre Wing with a BFA in Acting.  Theatre: Broken City: Harlem (PopUp Theatrics), New York City Independent Theatre One-Minute Play Festival (New Ohio Theatre), Carnival Des Corbeaux (McKittrick Hotel), Hotel Project (Popup Theatrics) I Don’t Want to Hurt Your Feelings (Dir. Emma Koenig), Dance Dance Revolution (Ohio Theater Dir. Alex Timbers). Regional: Our Town (Long Wharf Theatre), The SevenYear Itch (Ivoryton Playhouse) Riding The Turnpike, Gross Domestic Product (Hartbeat Ensemble) Recent Film: Roommate Wanted, Meadow Brook, Dark Haul, Straight Outta Tompkins, Bloody Mary. www.caitlinzoz.com 


ROB BRINKMANN (Micky) 

Rob Brinkmann, graduate of NYU's Tisch School of the Arts, is a New York based stage and film actor.  Most recently seen this summer in the NYC Fringe Festival with Baby Hubris, the Thespis Festival in Lily Casually, Nylon Fusion's Hot Summer in the City, and Cygnus ISA Summer Con5t3ll4tion at the Paradise Factory. www.robbrinkmann.com

REBECCA ROBERTSON (Vicky)  
Miss Robertson is an actress & singer, aspiring poet & professional enthusiast. Currently she wanders the halls of Sleep No More. She is the Co-Artistic Director of mad/magic. She receives valentines & other inquiries with bated fervor: rebeccaquinnrobertson.com

JULIAN JOSEPH (Mimo) 
Julian is a New York native and a graduate of William Esper Studio. Most recently he starred in both the play "Bridesburg" and the film adaptation slated to be released next year. TV credits include "The Philanthropist" on NBC, "Law & Order" NBC and "Blue Bloods" CBS.

NATHANIEL PEART (Tommy) 
Theater: The Tank Edward II (Dir. Hunter Bird), La MaMa Umbria Tangled (Dir. Conor Abramsky), Dixon Place House & Variations (Dir. Will Detlefsen), Abe Burrows Dinner at Eight (Dir. Robert Moss). Film: NY84 (Dir. Cyril Morin), Jane Wants a Boyfriend (Dir. Will Sullivan), We The Economy (Dir. Morgan Spurlock), Breathe In (Dir. Drake Doremus), Lofty Dreams (Dir. Drew Moore). Nathaniel received a BFA from NYU’s Tisch where he studied at the Stella Adler Studio, the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art, and the Experimental Theater Wing. Thanks to the family, friends and artists that support this great work.

NICOLE PURSELL (Adona)  
Nicole is pleased as punch to be involved in this workshop with all of her friends. She is a graduate of NYU Tisch's  Experimental Theater Wing and can be seen in the new award winning film, 'That's Not Us' directed by Will Sullivan. She lives in Brooklyn with three dudes and a dog.

ENZO FERRANTE (Daddy in the tomato plant)  
Enzo was born in Corleone, Sicily. He has performed all over the world, including Germany,  France and Italy. He is a tri-lingual businessmen and a loving father of three beautiful children. He resides in Manalapan, New Jersey with his wonderful  wife Anna. 

THE GYPSY DI SICILIA (as herself) 
The Gypsy was found swaddled in a blanket made of hay inside of the St. Elmora Street Church's nativity scene on Christmas Eve. She was called the "miracle baby of Elmora Street" and was raised by the nuns and the priests. She emancipated herself from the care of the Church when she was eighteen years old and has been telling fortunes ever since. 

Assistant directed and staged managed by 
BRIAN POLLOCK 
Brian is an actor/director/playwright and a recent graduate of the NYU Tisch Drama program. Recently, he wrote and directed his play On the High Line, which he hopes to continue working on and remount soon. Brian is over the moon to be a part of the Elmora Street team, and would like to thank Rosemary Quinn of NYU's Experimental Theatre Wing for connecting him to the project, and Joey and the cast for welcoming him into this whacky show with such open arms.

Sound design by  
JORGE MORALES 
Jorge Morales is a Puerto Rican actor and musician currently based in New York City. Recent roles include: Max Estrella in Bohemian Lights, (HERE Arts Center), Ensemble in Macbeth (Park Avenue Armory),Cassio in Othello (No Stone Productions) andPrincipe in Reinar después de morir (Repertorio Español). Apart from acting, he has also realized the score and sound design for various short films and theatre productions, including Artaud Artaud (Theatre for the New City), mothertongue (dir. Trevor Salter), and The Burma Project (dir. Kate Whoriskey.) He is a graduate from NYU Tisch School of the Arts and has also trained at International Theatre Workshop in Amsterdam and at Augusto Boal’s Theatre of the Oppressed Workshop in Brazil.

story:
what the hell is this

tender of you too, by Anya Richkind, follows Allegra and Tara after they’re cast in their high school play as Frances Willard and Mary Bannister—two real-life late-19th Century leaders of the Women’s Christian Temperance Movement. Frances’ diary and her correspondence with Mary, the basis for the school play, describes a genuine, beautiful love between the two women. Through performing this love story, Allegra and Tara slowly realize their feelings for each other, and try, with varying degrees of success, to deal with how messy it has all become.

On Thursday, August 25, 2016, there will be a public staged reading of the play at Theatre 54 at Shetler Studios.

what the hell is hysteria

and who the hell are we

We're Hysteria.

Hysteria strives to close the gap between the development and production of new work, using collaborative dramaturgical development that leads to a guaranteed full production, demonstrating our commitment to the playwrights whose work we select. We are also committed to collaborating with a diverse group of playwrights, actors, directors, and dramaturgs who are able to bring their varied experiences to the work.

We admit that Hysteria is in its infancy, so full productions aren’t possible quite yet. This staged reading is our first hurdle, and will hopefully bring us into toddlercy. Our name refers to how, historically, any female emotion was medically diagnosed as “hysteria.” We are two angry feminist queer women who, although the company’s mission statement is deliberately broad, are personally committed to reclaiming “hysteria” in every sense of the word and representing it on stage.

Danielle Feder (Hysteria co-founder, Producer/Dramaturg) is a dramaturg, producer, and writer. By day, she works in marketing for an Off-Broadway theatre and is the copy editor for The Interval, a website dedicated to women in theatre. She's also worked for NYMF, the Vineyard Theatre, Atlantic Theater Company, TACT, and the Walnut Street Theatre in Philadelphia.

Dara Epstein (Hysteria co-founder, Director) is an actor, singer, director, and writer. She is a 2014 graduate of Hunter College, where she wrote and produced an original play based on the Greek myth of Persephone directed by Remy Leelike, the lighting designer for tender of you too. Although she has been a proud New Yorker for the last eight years, she is leaving the city in September to pursue an MA in Applied Theatre at Goldsmiths, University of London. 

Anya Richkind (Playwright) is a recent graduate of Yale University, and has studied under Donald Margulies, Deb Margolin and Sarah Ruhl. Anya’s latest play, tender of you too, was a finalist in the O’Neill Theater Center’s 2016 National Playwrights Conference. Anya’s first play, The Secret of Asteraceae, commissioned by Marin Country Day School, was produced by the American Conservatory Theater’s Young Conservatory in San Francisco.

where the hell is my money going

Great question!

First and foremost, we're paying for rehearsal and performance space.

Secondly, but not in any way less importantly, we're committed to paying the artists we're working with. This includes our cast of three, a lighting designer so you're not just staring at white light on a few folding chairs, and a stage manager to help us not lose our minds. We all have other full and part-time jobs in addition to this project, so it's important to us that no one is donating their already limited free time.

The rest of our budget will go towards all the tangible supplies we'll need, like copies of scripts and printing programs for our lovely audience! And, since this is theatre, we know unexpected costs may (will) arise, so we have a small amount of wiggle room for that possibility (eventuality).

other information

Hysteria presents 'tender of you too' is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Hysteria presents 'tender of you too' must be made payable to "Fractured Atlas" only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Help cover the costs of this one-of-a-kind presentation of all eight styles of classical Indian dance on one stage.

Who Are We?

Since 1978, World Arts West has presented the San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival, a month-long celebration of classical and contemporary world dance and music. Our region’s greatness lies in its diversity, and nowhere is our diversity better embodied than in the Bay Area's rich and varied dance traditions. The thousands of artists we work with are the heart and soul of the San Francisco Bay Area, and serve as both cultural ambassadors and catalysts for cross-cultural innovation. Hailed by critics as "Powerful," "Transcendent," and "Exploding perceptions of ethnic dance," the Festival helps Northern California artists sustain their cultural traditions while building bridges of cultural understanding.  

The mission of Sangam Arts is to help create and nurture strong intercultural connections between the Indian diaspora and the many vibrant cultures in the US through the use of visual and performing arts. We accomplish this by facilitating innovative collaborations between dancers, musicians, writers, and choreographers from diverse dance traditions ranging from kathak, bharatanatyam, to flamenco, jazz and folklórico, sponsoring workshops and lecture-demonstrations to help expand artistic horizons.




What Are We Doing? 

As part of the 36th annual San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival, we are presenting a rare, in-depth program showcasing all eight styles of classical Indian dance on one stage, June 14 and 15. Audiences will experience dance forms rarely seen in the Bay Area – such as kathakali, manipuri, and sattriya – presented by top artists in their fields.

This program features performances by Chitresh Das Dance Company (kathak), Guru Shradha (odissi), K.P Kunhiraman (kathakali), Kalanjali: Dances of India (bharatanatyam), Bhavajan Kumar (bharatanatyam), Sujata Mohapatra (odissi), Sunanda Nair (mohiniyattam and kathakali), Natyalaya (kuchipudi), Nava Dance Theatre (bharatanatyam), Sohini Ray (manipuri), and Sattriya Dance Company (sattriya)

This year’s Malonga Casquelourd Lifetime Achievement Award will be presented to K.P. and Katherine Kunhiraman, the founders of Kalanjali: Dances of India. This will likely be Kunhiraman’s final appearance on a U.S. stage before he returns to India after an illustrious 67-year career to live out his final years in his homeland.

Why Indiegogo?

Ticket sales cover just a fraction of the costs of producing San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival performances, and this year, because we are presenting artists from outside the Bay Area, we are incurring travel costs on top of our usual production costs. We need your help to cover these costs. Among the expenses this campaign will support are:

  • Stage crew and sound engineering expenses

  • Artist travel and hospitality expenses

  • Documentation of the performances

  • Marketing of Festival performances



Website:
World Arts West: www.worldartswest.org 
Sangam Arts: www.sangamarts.org

Facebook:
www.facebook.com/SanFranciscoEthnicDanceFestival
www.facebook.com/sangamartsorg

Arts West has
presented the San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival, a month-long celebration of classical and
contemporary world dance and music. Our region’s greatness lies in its
diversity, and nowhere is our diversity better embodied than in the Bay Area's
rich and varied dance traditions. The thousands of artists we work with are the
heart and soul of the San Francisco Bay Area, and serve as both cultural
ambassadors and catalysts for cross-cultural innovation. Hailed by critics as
"Powerful," "Transcendent," and "Exploding perceptions
of ethnic dance," the Festival helps Northern California artists sustain
their cultural traditions while building bridges of cultural understanding.
 
The mission of Sangam
Arts is to help
create and nurture strong intercultural connections between the Indian diaspora
and the many vibrant cultures in the US through the use of visual and
performing arts. We accomplish this by facilitating innovative collaborations
between dancers, musicians, writers, and choreographers from diverse dance
traditions ranging from kathak, bharatanatyam, to flamenco, jazz and folklórico,
sponsoring workshops and lecture-demonstrations to help expand artistic
horizons.
What Are We Doing?  
As part
of the 36th annual San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival, we are
presenting a rare, in-depth program
showcasing all eight styles of classical Indian dance on one stage, June 14 and
15. Audiences will experience dance forms rarely seen in the Bay Area – such as
kathakali, manipuri, and sattriya – presented by top artists in their fields.
This
program features performances by Chitresh Das Dance Company (kathak), Guru
Shradha (odissi), K.P Kunhiraman (kathakali), Kalanjali: Dances of India
(bharatanatyam), Bhavajan Kumar (bharatanatyam), Sujata Mohapatra (odissi),
Sunanda Nair (mohiniyattam and kathakali), Natyalaya (kuchipudi), Nava Dance
Theatre (bharatanatyam), Sohini Ray (manipuri), and Sattriya Dance Company
(sattriya)
This
year’s Malonga Casquelourd Lifetime Achievement Award will be presented to K.P.
and Katherine Kunhiraman, the founders of Kalanjali: Dances of India. This will
likely be Kunhiraman’s final appearance on a U.S. stage
before he returns to India after an illustrious 67-year career to live out his
final years in his homeland.
Why Indiegogo?
Ticket
sales cover just a fraction of the costs of producing San Francisco Ethnic
Dance Festival performances, and this year, because we are presenting artists
from outside the Bay Area, we are incurring travel costs on top of our usual
production costs. We need your help to cover these costs. Among the expenses this
campaign will support are:

Stage
     crew and sound engineering expenses
Artist
     travel and hospitality expenses
Documentation
     of the performances 
Marketing
     of Festival performances 

Website: World Arts West: www.worldartswest.org 
Sangam Arts: www.sangamarts.org
Facebook:
www.facebook.com/SanFranciscoEthnicDanceFestivalwww.facebook.com/sangamartsorg

story:
**UPDATE**

Welcome Back everyone!

We would like to announce what we have for the raffle prize!

Every 10$ you spend on our campaign, you get a raffle ticket! For example, if you get the My Fair Lady perk, then you will get 5 raffle tickets and so on.  We will at the end of the campaign, draw the ticket and we will notify you of your winnings.  

Here is what you can win in our gift basket!

4 tickets to the Chicago Shakespeare Theater's Summer Family Musical!


1  Gift Certificate to Broadway in Chicago for the show of your choice!

Assorted theater related candies, snacks, and goodies!

You do NOT want to miss out on this $280 value!  All you have to do is donate to our campaign!  It will be worth it!



OUR STORY:

Up and Coming Theatre, founded in 1992, was designed to bring both fun and edgy high-quality theatre productions to the community.  We are unique in that we focus on producing shows that exceed typical community theatre productions while offering an educational experience at the same time.  UAC gives opportunities to both cast and staff members that they may not have in other companies.  We pride ourselves on collaborating with, teaching, and mentoring  Up and Coming performers and staff members.  

Operating independently of a park district or large governing body has allowed Up and Coming the freedom to choose shows that the community is excited about and fit our company mission. We like being able to do the shows we WANT to do; unregulated and uncensored.  However, this means we are funded exclusively by ticket sales and private donations.  This is where you come in- we need your help!

Please help us continue to provide educational experiences while creating professional productions.

Support Theatre.

Support Mentorship.

Support UAC.


WHAT WE NEED:

We are seeking a minimum of $5,000 to help Up and Coming continue to produce high quality theatre experiences.  The funds will be exclusively used on sets, marketing, and costumes.  No donations will be used to pay staff or band members.  


UAC PROUDLY ANNOUNCES OUR SUMMER 2015 SHOW, SEUSSICAL!


Up and Coming Theatre is proud to announce our Summer 2015 musical, Seussical! Come join the Cat in the Hat, Horton, Jojo, Gertrude McFuzz, and many more familiar Seuss faces in a family-friendly extravaganza!

Auditions will take place in May. Performances will be in August 2015. For more information, visit our web site!


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

We know that not all people have the ability to donate monetarily.  However, that does not mean that you cannot help Up and Coming Theatre be successful in our campaign.  Please post the link to this Indigogo campaign on your social media sites like Facebook and Twitter, or send this to your entire email list.  Help us get the word out to as many people as possible!



OUR COMPANY:

Mission Statement

Our mission is to provide professional level performances with equal regard to music, voice, dancing, and acting. Our goal is to raise the bar on what community theatre has typically been in terms of output, and yet retain the communal aspects. We give opportunities to aspiring professionals so they can obtain practical experience, grow as people, and expand their artistry.  But most importantly, we are about challenging ourselves as artists through teamwork, cooperation, and constant support and encouragement.

story:
No Provenance is headed to FringeNYC

It's a brand-new drama by Kate Holland & Caroline Prugh. We have been in rehearsals for over a month, and we open August 10th at the Kraine Theater in New York, as part of the New York Fringe Festival. That's less than four weeks away!

I'd like to tell you about the show, to ask for your help, and to invite you to become a part of this very exciting production.

The Show

From our postcard:

The provisions of a will entice three estranged sisters to their great-grandmother's Paris apartment, untouched since 1945. Guided by Clotho, one of the Greek Fates, they search through the relics, as the past begins to unravel around them.

No Provenance takes place simultaneously in the pre-WWII era and in 2014, weaving together a scattered family's past and present. There is art history, a little bit of mystery, and a heartbreaking decision that echoes across the generations.

Performance Dates
We run this August at the Kraine Theater in New York (85 East 4th Street).
#1: Sunday, August 10th at 12:00pm
#2: Tuesday, August 12th at 6:00pm
#3: Thursday, August 14th at 7:00pm
#4: Thursday, August 21st at 2:30pm
#5: Saturday, August 23rd at 5:45pm
Tickets are $18 in advance, $24 at the door. But donors to No Provenance can get tickets as part of their perks, in a special deal.

How it all happened (mostly):
Early last year, Kate Holland had an idea for a story that she wanted to tell on stage. She had characters and a situation in mind, but only a rough idea of plot, and no dialogue. So in July 2013, she got together with playwright Caroline Prugh, seven actresses, choreographer Marine Sialelli, and producer Justin Cornell (that's me) for two weeks of workshops at Columbia University. Every day, Kate would describe a portion of the story, and the actresses would improvise scenes around it. Then at night, Caroline would write dialogue based on these improvisations and flesh out the scenes. At the end of two weeks, to our surprise, we had a full draft of a play.

There have been more readings and a lot more re-writing since then, and some of the participants have changed, but most of what you'll see in this year's FringeNYC Festival was born over a year ago in those workshops.

Who We Are

Writers: Caroline Prugh and Kate Holland
Director: Kate Holland
Producer: Justin Cornell

Projections Designer: Matt Suter
Sound Designer: Justin Cornell
Movement Director: Marine Sialelli
Stage Manager: Ashley Greiner

Cast:
Sarah Eismann as Marion
Renee Erikson as Marcelle
Carole Forman* as Clotho
Robyn Michele Frank as Ilana
Michelle Ramoni* as Suzanne
Libby Skala* as Josephine
Stephanie Taylor* as Orit
*member of AEA

How You Can Help

Even the fringiest of Fringe shows need money; our play has a budget of  $8000. Some of that is coming from private backers, and some from our own pockets, but we are hoping to raise $3000 online from people like you. That money is specifically going to paying stipends to our very talented actors: ($400 Equity Showcase minimum, times seven performers, plus $200 in processing & fundraising fees).

We know the power of a large number of small donors. So there are many 'levels' available, as you can see to the right. All donations up to a total of $2500 will be matched by an anonymous angel. So each donation will have double the impact! And all donors will be personally thanked on our social media & in our program.

Reaching that $3000 goal is very important to us, because it affects our fundraising platform fees. If we do not reach our goal, Indiegogo will charge us for 9% of the donations we receive. If we do reach our goal, they take only 4%. (So if we end with $2999, they take $270, but if we end with $3000, they take just $120!)

No Provenance is a project that we are all very passionate about. We've put a lot of our creative energy into making it, and we are grateful for this opportunity to present it in the NY Fringe. Even if you can't donate, we hope you'll join us at the show. Tickets will go on sale very soon!

Thank you very much for taking the time to consider this. Please give if you can; we hope to see you at Opening Night.

story:
"R&J: a techno ballet" is an immersive theatrical experience based on the play "Romeo and Juliet" by William Shakespeare. Loosely set around the current conflict between Israel and Palestine, we see how the journey of two star crossed lovers mirror our worldly consciousness today, and how our actions resonate on a much larger scale than our own personal awareness. Told through dance, neutral mask and fight choreography, "R&J: a techno ballet" will bring you face to face with the tragedies happening all around us, and the truths we must face to fix them.

The funds we raise from this campaign will go to the logistical and technical elements of the show including: Performance Space, Lighting Equipment, Compensation for Actors and Technicians, Large-scale Props and Masks.

Thank you for your donations and we hope to see you soon!

story:
MARTIAN CHRONICLES will be presented in two live concert performances with a cast and orchestra of fifteen on February 11th, 2015 at Ars Nova NYC. 

__________________________________________________

WHAT'S THE STORY?

In our musical re-imagining of Bradbury's story, Ally, a 13-year old refugee from the wars on Earth, arrives with her family on Mars, an empty planet.  When she learns that her parents have no intention of going back she sets off on an odyssey to find a way home, but discovers instead the secrets of the planet's past, as well as her own future identity. 

This music theater piece is adapted from Ray Bradbury's classic 1950's novel THE MARTIAN CHRONICLES. 

__________________________________________________

WHY WE NEED FUNDS TO MAKE IT HAPPEN

We’ve assembled a team of artists and designers to bring Ray’s work to the stage for the first time ever as immersive music theatre, through-composed and mostly sung, in the tradition of Next to Normal, Les Mis, Evita, Tommy, and Natasha & Pierre. Ultimately we want to stage Martian Chronicles in a 360˚ setting with live orchestra and extensive use of video projection, with the audience following Ally’s journey of discovery.  Before we do, we’re producing a reading, essentially a concert version to road-test the fully musicalized script - and for that we need your help. 

We would love for you to become a part of this theatrical experience by generously helping to support the following:

  • Rehearsal and presentation space rentals
  • Technical equipment rental
  • Stipends for our creative artists (actors, musicians)
  • Insurance costs
  • Publicity and outreach to the community

__________________________________________________

WHAT YOU CAN DO TO HELP

Our goal is to raise $8,560 by the time we start rehearsals. Please give whatever you can, anything and everything will help us on this journey! Your contribution will be tax-deductible. Check out all of the perks to see how you can be involved in the process with sneak-peeks along the way!

Claim one of our perk levels for unique Martian items. Note: No actual Martians were harmed during the creation of these rewards.

__________________________________________________

RISKS, CHALLENGES & POTENTIALS

So many of the issues human beings face today, conflicts ranging from geo-political to local (ISIS, Ebola, immigration, indigenous populations, Ferguson MO) have their roots in the way we define those not like ourselves as "the other". The work approaches these questions in a deeply human way, engages our hearts and minds by drawing us into the lives of dozens of complex characters, both Human and Martian. What makes us human?  Can we let go of our fears and prejudices to begin anew in a new place? Are we doomed to repeat the evils of our own history?  Can we evolve? 

Daniel Levy and Elizabeth Margid have spent almost ten years developing this piece, including 
  • 2006 reading at Orlando Shakespeare Festival
  • 2008 workshop at Fordham University Lincoln Center
  • 2013 studio recordings and YouTube videos
  • 2014 project website, Facebook Page, and Cornelia St. performances
People who have heard the music tell us that it sounds unique and compelling, and they want to hear more - and we'd like everyone to hear more! The piece is finally ready to be shared and fully produced. With the intention of reaching potential presenters and producers, concert-style performances are the next step. Your support will make a difference for the immediate and long term success of MARTIAN CHRONICLES.

 OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Just because you may not be able to contribute doesn’t mean you lose your chance to help make this project happen!

  • Please help us get the word out and make some noise about this campaign!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to make it super easy.
  • Post this campaign link to your Facebook profile or Twitter feed
  • Tell people how much you want to see this show come to New York and pass this onto your fancy friends with deep pockets!
__________________________________________________

For all artist bios and other fun information, please check out www.martianchroniclesmusictheater.com

story:
Who are you gals?

Insomnium Theatre Company is the brainchild of the two of us: Lauren Harris and Felicia Lobo. We are both recent graduates of New York University, Tisch School of the Arts and found each other at The Atlantic Acting School. We have been collaborating on projects there and around NYU over the past year. Since graduation from Tisch, Lauren has worked as a freelance casting assistant at Telsey + Company. Felicia has been working with Pipeline Theatre Company, Joust Theatre Company, and on workshops at NYTW's 4th Street Theatre and Ars Nova. We were brought together by our love of horror, united in our feeling that the theatre needed to explore this genre further. So, we set out to create dark, mystical, sometimes horrific theatre that would keep audiences up at night, searching for answers. Our theatre encourages audiences to lean forward and participate in the collaborative, adrenaline-pumping art form you cannot get from your laptops or TV screens.

Okay, what are you doing?


Our first full-length production will be The Love of the Nightingale by Timberlake Wertenbaker. This is a feminist modern greek play that we have infused with original music and choreography. The story refocuses the original Tereus myth to look at the two sisters, Philomele and Procne. At the beginning of the play, Procne is married off to Tereus, the King of Thrace, as a political move for the sisters’ home of Athens. Procne has trouble adjusting in this new land, so she asks Tereus to bring her sister to Thrace. Tereus travels back to Athens to fulfill his wife’s wishes. On the trip back to Thrace, Tereus falls in love with Philomele. Things spiral out of control when Philomele refuses his advances.

….How much do you need?

  • A whopping $4500!

  • All funding will go towards rehearsal space rental, theatre rental, props, costumes, and lighting equipment.

Why are you doing this play?

Although there has been progress, gender inequality is still an issue all around the world. This play looks at the violence that erupts out of enforced silence. In order to incite change, women need their voices and opinions to be heard. This play is important to us artistically and morally. Theatre is an incredibly useful platform to spark conversation, which can then lead to change. We are hoping our production will do just that.

What’s so hard about it?

We have assembled a team of 16 actors and a crew of 11. This is an incredibly ambitious piece for us to tackle, especially as Insomnium’s inaugural play. The audience will only be around 40 people, creating an intimacy that we feel is essential for this play. Due to the small size of the audience and the affordable ticket prices, we will need to fundraise almost the entire budget. We are thrilled by the challenge of taking an epic play and producing it with such a small amount of resources. Actors will not only play roles, but embody scenery and props, using elemental theatricality to create a heightened reality. In the true spirit of Insomnium, we will rely on the imagination of the audience as our actors and creative team use theatre magic to transform our white box space into the world of The Love of the Nightingale.

How can we help?

  • Please donate. No amount is too small! 

  • Please share this video on Facebook and Twitter. Email it to anyone willing to support young artists trying to make work.

  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Special thanks to Maya Swaminathan and Billy Soistmann who filmed and edited our video!

At the beginning of the play, Procne is married off to Tereus, the King of Thrace, as a political move for the sisters’ home of Athens. Procne has trouble adjusting in this new land, so she asks Tereus to bring her sister to Thrace. Tereus travels back to Athens to fulfill his wife’s wishes. On the trip back to Thrace, Tereus falls in love with Philomele. Things spiral out of control when Philomele refuses his advances. ….How much do you need?
A whopping $4500!
All funding will go towards rehearsal space rental, theatre rental, props, costumes, and lighting equipment. 
Why are you doing this play?Although there has been progress, gender inequality is still an issue all around the world. This play looks at the violence that erupts out of enforced silence. In order to incite change, women need their voices and opinions to be heard. This play is important to us artistically and morally. Theatre is an incredibly useful platform to spark conversation, which can then lead to change. We are hoping our production will do just that.What’s so hard about it?We have assembled a team of 16 actors and a crew of 11. This is an incredibly ambitious piece for us to tackle, especially as Insomnium’s inaugural play. The audience will only be around 40 people, creating an intimacy that we feel is essential for this play. Due to the small size of the audience and the affordable ticket prices, we will need to fundraise almost the entire budget. We are thrilled by the challenge of taking an epic play and producing it with such a small amount of resources. Actors will not only play roles, but embody scenery and props, using elemental theatricality to create a heightened reality. In the true spirit of Insomnium, we will rely on the imagination of the audience as our actors and creative team use theatre magic to transform our white box space into the world of The Love of the Nightingale. How can we help?
Please donate. No amount is too small! 
Please share this video on Facebook and Twitter. Email it to anyone willing to support young artists trying to make work.
Use the Indiegogo share tools!
Special thanks to Maya Swaminathan and Billy Soistmann who filmed and edited our video!

story:
WHO ARE WE
Gin and Tonic Productions brings together artists from across the UK to produce
great shows that tell stories without the need of fancy sets or effects. After our
debut production of Hamlet received rave reviews and sold out numerous
performances, our ‘vivacious ensemble’ return to Edinburgh Fringe with A
Midsummer Night’s Dream in a production that once again ‘breathlessly energises
Shakespeare’s masterpiece’.


SPONSOR US
As a 16 month old company with no funding behind us, we need to raise £3000, of which this campaign is the first part, purely from ticket sales and our own fundraising efforts to cover the cost of bringing our show to Edinburgh Fringe. This all goes directly to the show, covering everything from venue hire to make up costs. 


AND IN RETURN…
As well as giving you our eternal devotion and heartfelt thanks, there is also a list of exciting benefits we can offer for certain donations at the side. 

If you want to donate on behalf of a company, we can offer even better things. During and well before Fringe, our team of 20 will be out and around the streets of Edinburgh publicising the show at every possible moment. Our T-Shirts, flyers and posters will be seen every day by the thousands of people who visit the Edinburgh Festival, providing a vast platform through which we may promote your your company. 


OTHER WAYS TO HELP

Any publicity you can give us is helpful, so share our Facebook updates, promote us on Twitter, or if you don’t feel positively about the internet, please do tell everyone about us, and our shows. We’ll be eternally grateful!


If you want any more details about who we are, what we've done, and what they said about us when we did it, please do visit our website. Or you could also contact us via the details below and on the website.

Any contribution from you will be a huge help in bringing A Midsummer Night’s Dream to Edinburgh Fringe in August. 

We are extremely grateful for your support!
