story:
what's the show?

​The nation has never been healthier. Crime is down. Streets are clean. Civility reigns. But out of the corner of your eye, you might catch a glimpse of the men keeping things orderly. In a series of brief, enigmatic scenes, two women take us into the heart of a nation that has been disciplined by violence. A daughter leaves her mother to join the revolution. Two government officials issue increasingly sinister public ordinances. A smuggler helps one last refugee over the border. As the nightmarish reality of this world grows disturbingly clear, the potential for hope is found in the smallest acts of resistance.

who are we?

Lila Rachel Becker is a DC native who directs and develops incendiary new work about power. She's worked with theaters across the US, including Woolly Mammoth Theater Company, Actors Theatre of Louisville, Portland Stage Company, and Williamstown Theatre Festival. 

Courtney Gaston is a lighting designer from northwest Louisiana studying design at the University of Iowa. Her work was last seen in University productions of new works bad things happen here and Found, but her designs have been a part of many Louisiana productions with companies such as the Shreveport Opera, River City Repertory Theatre, and Centenary College.

Adam Koob is currently a Stage Manager/Actor at the University of Iowa. He hopes to continue to pursue a career in theatre as well as event planning as he finishes up his college career next year!

Eric Marlin is a playwright, producer and MFA candidate at the Iowa Playwrights Workshop. Recently, he was a winner of the Samuel French OOB Festival (Breakfast Scene) and a finalist for the 2017 O'Neill National Playwrights Conference (bad things happen here).

Molly Winstead is a  professional dramaturg and a current MFA candidate at the University of Iowa.

We're bringing this production to Edinburgh with the help of the Healthy Oyster Collective. The Healthy Oysters are a NYC-based group that makes socially conscious works in theatrically playful forms. They've done work at Dixon Place, PTP/NYC, Metro Arts Initiative & Manhattan Repertory Theatre, to name a few. This will be their fourth major project.

what do we want to do?

We want to bring our production of bad things happen here to the Edinburgh Fringe. Edinburgh Festival Fringe is a major arts festival that takes over the whole city for the month of August. Theatre artists of all stripes, from famous actors to street performers, bring their work to the Fringe. It's a chance to present our production to a whole new audience at one of the most well-respected theatre festivals in the world. It's also a chance to bring producers and artistic staff of theaters from all over the world to the show and present our work for them. 

Plus we think British people will like this play.

what do we need?

We need $18,000 to go to Edinburgh. We have already secured $10,000 from other grants and funds, which has allowed us to move ahead with this production. We just need to raise the remaining funds from folks like you! Here's how our money will be spent:

  • $6000 for Travel: We've gotta get our team of six (two actors, a playwright, a director, a designer and a stage manager) over to Scotland.
  • $6000 for Lodging: We are renting two AirBnBs to house all six of us while we're there.
  • $3000 for Venue: This covers all of our expenses for renting the theater we've been programmed at, The Vault at Paradise Green.
  • $3000 for Miscellaneous: This includes artist stipends, marketing materials, SIM cards and a contingency for unanticipated expenses.

the impact

We believe that this production has something important to bring to the global stage in this moment. The messages coming out of the US these days are full of hate, small-mindedness, jingoism, and chauvinism. bad things happen here is the opposite of these trends: it is complicated, globally-minded in style and content. It places the stories of women, people of color, and queer folk front and center. It warns of the dangers of surveillance and cautions us to be aware of the linguistic changes that come with oppressive regimes. It focuses not on those fighting a violent government, but on those just trying to get through the day, and the compromises and changes that they must make in order to survive. This is a different angle than many stories that are created in troubled political times, and one that we feel is crucial to bring to the debate.

We are a group of theater artists from DC, California, Louisiana, North Carolina, and Iowa, who all met in a small city in the center of the country. We’re very excited to show the world that there is groundbreaking, forward-thinking art being made far from New York, LA, and Chicago; in parts of America that most people abroad never hear about. In doing so, we hope to advocate for the importance of the arts across American communities.

risks & challenges

Of course there's always risks to making theatre. Risk is intrinsic to live performance. And, while the risks of theatermaking are not new to us, we've never mounted a production of this scale on our own, and we've never produced outside the US before.

Thankfully, we've got a great group of friends with Edinburgh experience guiding our way through this process. And we have a lot of support from the University of Iowa in bringing this show abroad. We're also confident in the skills and experience that our team brings.

other ways to help

If you can't donate, spread the word! We're always looking to reach more people with this campaign.

 And if you're in Iowa City, come talk to Eric or Lila. There are other ways to help if you're local.

don't want to make the donation through Indiegogo?

The Healthy Oysters are a fiscally-sponsored project. You can make direct donations through our umbrella organization Fractured Atlas page. You'll be eligible for the same perks as any you might receive here.

story:
Who we are

We are simply a group of actors who want to put on a fantastic show, for a good cause.

That's it.

A week before Thanksgiving 2015, Diane Machin brought together a group of actors to see if they could put together a show for charity.

And here we are.

The script is phenomenal. Pygmalion goes awry in this contemporary comedy of manners which explores sexual harassment, misplaced amour, and the possibility of a four sided love triangle. The combatants are a sexy, volatile young woman and three Back Bay types a writer, a lawyer and a fiancee in sensible shoes. The setting is Boston, the ending is happy and laughter abounds. 

And the heels... are high.

Originally produced off-Broadway in 1992 at Second Stage featuring Kevin Bacon as Edward, Tony Goldwyn as Andrew, Saundra Santiago as Georgie, and Julie White as Lydia, we are excited to bring it back to New York.

The Cast with original cast member Julie White.


We need your help to mount this outstanding production slated for March 2016.


What We Need & What You Get

Starting from scratch requires a lot. But one thing that makes our project great... our cast and crew are doing this for NOTHING. Yep. That's right. Nothing. Just love of the art.

But just because we aren't paying them for all their hard work... doesn't mean we don't have other costs.

Please consider donating for:

  • Our Theatre space 
  • Rights to Theresa Rebeck's play
  • Rehearsal space
  • Set design and construction 
  • Publicity
  • And various props and set dressings


Risks & Challenges

We are not an organization. We are simply some theatre artists putting on a show to benefit others. But not being associated with any group is a challenge. We are starting from nothing. 
You are providing the backing to create an incredible experience for our audience and to help a charity in need of funding.
But whatever you donate to us... regardless of how much we make, we are determine to go through with our plans.
So join us on this road.
Lucas Atkins our "Andrew"

 Amy Louise Dixon as "Lydia"

Steven Russo our "Edward"

Aura Smith as "Georgie"

Other Ways You Can Help

So you can only donate a few dollars or can't donate at this time?
No worries! You help us just as much by sharing our efforts through:
  • Facebook
  • Twitter
  • Instagram
  • And Indiegogo
Simply by telling people about what we are trying to accomplish goes a long way. 
And that's all there is to it.

story:
eventually – a duet between Courtney Mazeika and Marlie Couto

eventually is a part of the ongoing research that is specific to the relationship between us, Courtney Mazeika and Marlie Couto.  We have developed a movement partnership over the last five (going on 6) years: from conservatory students to friends, co-workers, collaborators, and roommates. Our practice and work together is based on what happens when communication moves beyond paying attention and nears mutual instinct.  This duet is fueled by the depth of our history and our shared interest in the rigor of movement research – we challenge each other in our vigor, tenderness, and detailed physicality.  Together we attempt to examine and organize our sense of care, effort, and levity.  The music is an original composition by the incomparable bassist and composer, Max Judelson. 

 

What’s Happening:

Recently, this duet was accepted into the Rotterdam International Duet Choreography Competition!  Sweet!  This will take place in Rotterdam (the Netherlands) June 21-23 this summer. 

This is a thrilling opportunity – and with short notice – so we need some support to help us get there. 

 

Your support is mainly (basically only) for our flights.

  • Two round-trip flights from the Bay Area to Rotterdam = $2, 200
  • Anything more will go toward per diem during the trip for food, local transportation, housing, etc. 
  • Anything more than that will go toward future dance projects that Marlie and Courtney plan to collaborate on together. (We are also gearing up for a new creation that will premiere in September!)

 

This will be the first time we present our work outside of the USA.  We are so honored and excited at the prospect of sharing our research and expanding our community to Europe.  There are some amazing prizes that are awarded at the end of the competition – some money, some commissions, some further opportunities to present work.  Most importantly, we are pumped to get to participate and meet all the incredible dancers and choreographers who will also be attending RIDCC – it feels like an important step in our creative partnership.

We are so grateful to everyone who has been supportive of our research and adventures.  If you can’t contribute, we completely understand!  Other things that can help:

  • Share this campaign with anyone who you think might be interested.
  • Send us good, grooving vibes.

 

A special thank you to our families, Summer Lee Rhatigan and Lanny Berenson, the SF Conservatory of Dance, and our whole tribe of friends  – we love you.

story:
WHY?

These days young people have so much choice as to what to do with their lives, which is brilliant, but let’s face it, there is so much pressure in society to live a certain way that it is easy to get swallowed up into the majority flow having never discovered and pursued your true talent.

Beauty’s Legacy is saying “try everything and don’t settle for anything until you discover your true correlation of passion and ability.  That’s what you should be giving to the world.  You only have one life – don’t waste it.”  It’s not always easy but it’s achievable. 

Beauty’s Legacy is not art for art’s sake.  Beauty’s Legacy carries a vital social message and we want to help change people’s lives.


THE SHOW

Beauty’s Legacy is a sci-fi comedy/drama about revered geneticist Victor, who, using his maladjusted lab assistant as a guinea pig, creates the most beautiful, stylish and vain monster the world has ever seen.  This sets off a whirlwind of events that threaten to tear apart his career, his marriage and all known society.

Utilizing a strong visual style and an electronic soundtrack Beauty’s Legacy rips through media culture, tears open financially obsessed societies and examines the value of the legacy we leave behind.

We will be touring East Anglia and performing at Brighton Fringe.


MONEY

We are looking to work from an equity fringe agreement.  This means the four practitioners on tour with the show get paid at least minimum wage.  It sounds obvious but most fringe shows struggle to achieve this. 

We're very lucky to have attracted an amazing cast who really believe in the show’s message, and have been supported through development by Eastern Angles Theatre Company.

Much of the set and lighting we already have but we wish to raise production values with amazing costumes and brilliant music, courtesy of Skint Records and the band Mirrors.  These will add to the aesthetic of the sci-fi world we wish to create on stage.

We already have some great in kind support from Diss Corn Hall, who provide rehearsal space but this is a project with big ambitions and we need financial assistance.


YOUNG PEOPLE (and not quite so young people)

Young People:

We know great theatre can inspire young minds.  We’ve seen it in action with our previous shows.  With Beauty’s Legacy we aim to inspire as many young people toward creativity as we can.  Our Spring tour is only the first step.  We want to take the show nationwide and beyond.  In order to do this we need to attract investors and tour promoters to come watch our show in May.

Not so Young People:

Beauty’s Legacy is scripted by Mark Finbow, who wrote the number 1 iTunes short film A Thousand Empty Glasses, which was also nominated for best UK short at Raindance. Co-creator Simon Anthony Rhoden, graduated from the classical drama school LAMDA, works as an actor in new writing and as a brilliant waiter in a number of fine establishments.  Joining the company for the first time is actress Eloise Secker. Eloise is from Norfolk, has toured all over the world and has known the lads for years.

We also have a brilliant behind the scenes company including Gemma Russo-Walsh (Costume Design/Social Media), Emma Martin (Co-Producer/Marketing), Alice Mottram (Publicity and Set Design) and Frances Lamb (Administrator).

The show itself has been selected by a panel of experts at Brighton Fringe as one of the shows in their industry WINDOW week, highlighting shows that are ready to tour. 


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

There is a real buzz around Beauty's Legacy.  It's not just about donating money though.  If you can't afford to donate please consider sending out a tweet or facebook pitch for this site.  We need to get the word out.

Young People: 
We know great theatre can inspire young minds.  We’ve seen it in
action with our previous shows.  With Beauty’s
Legacy we aim to inspire as many young people toward creativity as we
can.  Our Spring tour is only the first step.  We want to take the
show nationwide and beyond.  In order to do this we need to attract
investors and tour promoters to come watch our show in May.

Not so Young
People:
Beauty’s Legacy is scripted by Mark Finbow,
who wrote the number 1 iTunes short film A Thousand Empty Glasses, which
was also nominated for best UK short at Raindance. Co-creator Simon Anthony
Rhoden, graduated from the classical drama school LAMDA, works as an actor in
new writing and as a brilliant waiter in a number of fine establishments. 
Joining the company for the first time is actress Eloise Secker. Eloise is
from Norfolk, has toured all over the world and has known the lads for years.
We also have a brilliant behind the scenes company including Gemma
Russo-Walsh (Costume Design/Social Media), Emma Martin (Co-Producer/Marketing),
Alice Mottram (Publicity and Set Design) and Frances Lamb (Administrator).
The show itself has been selected by a panel of experts at Brighton Fringe
as one of the shows in their industry WINDOW week, highlighting shows that are
ready to tour.  

OTHER WAYS YOU
CAN HELP
There is a real buzz around Beauty's
Legacy.  It's not just about donating money though.  If you can't
afford to donate please consider sending out a tweet or facebook pitch for this
site.  We need to get the word out.

story:
Gunnar Montana was born and raised in Montana and currently resides in Philadelphia, PA. He attended The University of the Arts, graduating in 2011 with a BFA in Modern Dance Performance and a profound interest in choreography and creative movement. Before branching off on his own, he danced and collaborated with Brian Sanders‘ JUNK, including the recent works of “Sanctuary”, “Dancing Dead”, and “The Gate Reopened”. 


Infusing movement and visual arts, Montana’s work refuses to be defined. His artistry as a whole is an array of visual art installations, prop-based choreography, set design, costume design, transformation of atmosphere, and innovative movement, concepts, and ideas.  He is most interested in conceiving original work, his past productions including RUB, BASEMENT, Drag Me to Hell, and HYBERNATE. For more info on his past works click here.


RESURRECTION ROOM (Philadelphia FringeArts 2014) is an escape from reality, an underground sanctuary forged with industrial stalactites and hidden from the human race. As an audience member you will follow a young woman as she stumbles upon a world with no rules, no life, no death. A room riddled with resurrected characters from the mind of Gunnar Montana. Get lost with her as she encounters everything from hot pink hostels to demon geishas, igniting a world dead set on eating her alive. With no escape in an unexplained world, our heroine must find a way to overcome stone cold medusas, lost love, hysterical bodysnatchers, and a room that has no intention of ever letting her go. 


What do we need money for?

1.) FringeArts Registration 

2.) Insurance 

3.) Venue Rental 

4.) Rehearsal Space 

5.) Lighting/Sound Rental 

6.) Set Design/Art Installation

7.) Costuming 

8.) Props 

9.) Photo Shoots/Posters/Advertising 


As you can see, a show this this takes a great amount of time, work, energy, and money. The Philadelphia community has been so supportive of our work thusfar and we are so greatful to have such an amazing following behind it. So if you’ve liked what you’ve read or you've enjoyed our work in the past, please consider making a contribution to this show. Anything helps and we are just immensely excited to be able to present this work to you. Thanks again for your support, we will see you in September. Happy Fringe!


Photos from HYBERNATE (March 2014):


Photography Credit: Garret Mathews 

Design Credit: Benjamin Brown

story:
The Project

Dragon Productions has launched a second stage series, where invited artists are empowered to produce their passion project. Take Me Out has been a bucket list show of mine for years and I am thrilled to be part of this first year of artists.

If you not familiar with the show, it is an extraordinarily meaningful show about homophobia, racism and (of course) baseball! The role of Mason has been a life time dream of mine. Finally, I am doing it.

I have assembled an extraordinary group of artists to accompany me on this dream project and we are gamely moving forward to opening this show in a few short weeks, July 11.

As many of you know, I have been an active producer, actor and director in the Bay Area for years. An unexpected development has caught me off guard and money that had been earmarked for this production has been lost.

The show is not in jeopardy. Come hell or high water this will happen. It is simply a question of what financial situation I will be in when it is over. This is where I need your help.

The nature of this project is that Dragon supplies some money toward the production and they keep all of the ticket revenue. Just in case that sounds strange, its actually completely fair to cover their costs of this production. In other words, the money I am putting in this project will come out of my pocket without any chance of reimbursement.

What We Need

The money in this campaign is going directly to pay the OTHER artists in this project. I will not personally keep a dime of it. There are 11 actors, an extraordinary director, an incredible tech and design team all working hard to make this dream a reality.

The amount of this campaign is slightly more than I am looking for to cover this unexpected shortfall, but it is my hope to be able to give Dragon all additional funds so that they can better support next year's Second Stage program. No theatre in the Bay Area is doing a project like this that I am aware of. It's a fantastic thing.

What will you get if you contribute? That's a good question. What do you want? Let me know. I'll try to make it happen.


Risks & Challenges

Because of the limitations of this fundraising site, this is an incredibly quick and ambitious last minute fundraising effort. This isn't something that you can look at and come back to next week. I truly need your support now.

story:
Let's work together to make 2014 the BEST competition yet!



The New England Chapter of the International Society of Arboriculture (ISA) has hosted an annual Tree Climbing Championship all over New England for over 30 years. This competition provides the region's best arborists (tree-care professionals) with a venue to showcase safe tree-care skills and practices,  (http://newenglandisa.org/tree_climbing_championship.html), and a chance to be sponsored at the International Tree Climbing Championship (http://www.itcc-isa.com/). 

This Year's New England Championship will be held at the Lakeview Cemetery in Burlington, Vermont on May 31, 2014 (Gear inspection: May 30th; Rain date: June 1)

This year we are asking YOU to help us make the New England Competition better than ever!



  • The event is 100% volunteer-run and can not operate without the time, supplies and monetary contributions made by our volunteers, sponsors and donors. 
  • Our annual event budget is often covered by generous sponsor donations, and volunteer contributions. The event itself is made possible with gear donations without which the Championship would not happen.
  • This year we want to raise $6,000 or more to buy the supplies we often borrow, which will help us bring this event up to international standards.
  • Your support would allow us to make the competition safer, more fun, and more rewarding for everyone involved.
  • Your contribution will also improve the event in years to come by allowing us to purchased long-lasting, safe, international-standard event equipment. 



Here's what your money will go toward:

Gear (for this year and beyond..)

  • $1,000 for a Rescue Dummy.
  • $3,200 for a GRCS (lifting and lowering device) and battery-powered drill to hoist the Rescue Dummy into the tree.
  • $800 for (2) full-body footlock harnesses
  • $150 for (2) fiberglass poles and (1) pole saw head
  • $350 for (2) Petzel RIG Compact self-braking descender
  • $300 for (2) ISC aluminum rigging block
  • $150 for (2) DMM Pinto Rig pulley w/spacer


If we exceed our fundraising goal, your money will go toward:

Uniforms

  • $1,100 Competitor and volunteer T-shirts

Food

  • $600 for a "Thank You" Volunteer Dinner
  • $500 for quality breakfast, snacks, and lunch items for climbers and volunteers.

Outreach

  • $500 for event program design and printing

General Supplies

  • $100 Duct tape and flagging
  • $100 Cow bells! (can't have enough)
  • $50 General supplies

PRIZES! PRIZES! PRIZES!

  • $1,000 in new ropes, helmets, harnesses, and gear for competitor prizes
  • $500 in airfare to send our winner to Internationals!


What You Get!


Acorn Level ($25)
  • You or your company's name in our Event Program
  • A 2014 Competition T-shirt
  • A personalized thank you card

Seedling Level ($100)
  • Your or your company's name in our Event Program
  • You or your company's name in our Summer New England Chapter-ISA Newsletter (http://newenglandisa.org/newsletters/2013_WinterNewsletter.pdf)
  • A 2014 Competition T-shirt
  • A personalized thank you card

Sapling Level ($200)
  • Your or your company's name in our Event Program
  • Your or your company's name in our Summer New England Chapter-ISA Newsletter (http://newenglandisa.org/newsletters/2013_WinterNewsletter.pdf)
  • Your or your company's name on the New England Chapter-ISA Website (http://newenglandisa.org/)
  • “Thank you” at the ISA Annual Conference (http://www.isa-arbor.com/events/conference/index.aspx)
  • A 2014 Competition T-shirt
  • A personalized thank you card

Tree Level ($500 or more)
  • Your or your company's name in our Event Program
  • Your or your company's name in our Summer & Fall New England Chapter-ISA Newsletters (http://newenglandisa.org/newsletters/2013_WinterNewsletter.pdf)
  • Your or your company's name and website link on the New England Chapter-ISA Website (http://newenglandisa.org/)
  • “Thank you” at the ISA Annual Conference (http://www.isa-arbor.com/events/conference/index.aspx)
  • Booth space under the event-tent during the May 31st Competition
  • Your name or your company’s logo printed on the back of our competition event T-shirts (sponsorship must be pledged and logo provided by April 4th)
  • A 2014 Competition T-shirt
  • A personalized thank you card


If we don't meet our goals this year, we will use every penny we raise to purchase all the necessary items we can for 2014 event. 


Why Support This Event? 

Your donation will provide essential funding to improve the safety and quality of this special regional event plus support the areas most talented tree climbers.



  • We compete to improve our field! This competition promotes safe tree care practices and promotes safe/high-quality arboriculture standards throughout the region. The event is not only only fun, but it also helps to develop the skills of tree care professionals, who provide an essential service in our communities.
  • This competition has been held since 1983 in New England and has been made possible each year by volunteer and donor support.  Your support will help us provide our volunteers, competitors, and spectators with a better experience this year and beyond.


Other Ways You Can Help

You don't have to donate money to make a difference! Consider joining our amazing team of volunteers who help orchestrate this fun an exciting event. We are always looking for volunteer judges, technicians, timers, administrators, photographers, and videographers. For more information about volunteering, please contact Melissa LeVangie (mlevangie@newenglandisa.org) For more information about donations and sponsorship, please contact Heather Leaf (978-844-0441).



PASS IT ON! 

  • We need your help spreading the word, so please share this campaign far and wide with anyone who loves trees and tree care professionals!
  • And now you can share even faster with indiegogo's sharing tools that connect directly to Facebook, Twitter and Google+

story:
Sound Moves by Chrissy Martin

I am a dancer, singer, and movement educator whose creative home for the last five years has been in Chicago, IL. Sound Moves will be my last performance in this fair city before moving to Northampton, MA to pursue an MFA in choreography and performance at Smith College. I want to give back to this community by featuring the amazing performers in this piece, performing at my favorite venue, Links Hall, and by sharing my creative process with the audience, allowing them to be a part of my work.

 

Dance as an art form is historically poorly funded, and much of what it takes to produce a work is expected to be donated in-kind by performers and choreographers. The level of expertise we have in our field can be valued at $50/hour or more, but more often than not we are left to produce work by paying for it rather than getting paid or breaking even. In an effort to offset the endemic underpayment of our art form, I am drawing on the support of my community (that's you!) to help me make this model of respecting performers for their time possible.

 

It seems small, but this type of a crowdfunding campaign does so much good. It allows my performers to feel valued and appreciated, it keeps my rent paid, it gives me and other young, independent artists hope that creating art is worth doing; that we can put ourselves out there and get back what we give.

 

What We Need & What You Get

This money will help me do a few things:

1. The majority of this fundraising money will pay my artists. Performing artists regularly do unpaid labor, even in larger, more financially stable companies. I want to change this model one show at a time. Pay me so I can pay them!

2. I will pay myself back for rehearsal space, my biggest expense for this project.

3. I will be able to pay a professional videographer to record this show so it can live on my website and for future promotional material.

4. I will give myself a small budget for costumes and programs.

 

You get a chance to support some artists that you know and care about, as well as some fun perks for your donations, including social media shoutouts, an original "Sound Moves" zine, and private voice/movement sessions from yours truly.

 

What else do you get? A chance to see this amazing show! Ticket and event links below!

 

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/sound-moves-tickets-58018288262

https://www.facebook.com/events/422696288496134/

story:
KISS ME CAKE is a full sensory exploration of the female psyche told through dance and cake, to be performed at Cafe Nordo August 9 - 13, 2018. From a young girl’s dream of being a ballerina to her sensual awakening and beyond, each dance is paired with Dillard’s own confections and scored with live music. Cake recipes become arias, and the voice of Julia Child provides the backdrop for an unforgettable union of bodies and buttercream. The evening includes light, savory fare in the style of a French royal banquet before launching into the main event, cake after cake after cake.
 

Help us pay the artists

This campaign will help to build the lavish cake sets and costumes of our dreams, and towards compensating the performing and creative artists, who each are receiving small stipends, but whose worth and value equal a great deal more - and we want to pay them accordingly.

$1,500 to pay for set materials and costumes

$1,800 to pay each the 12 creative and performing artists $150

Our stretch goal of $5,000 will enable us pay the artists more fully for their time and expertise. Even if we don't reach the entire goal, donations will cover those costs as far as they go--every little bit helps!

To thank you for your contribution, we are offering exclusive perks including: cast resin flowers from the set, a pair of signed toe shoes, a custom cake, seats at the private preview, a chance to attend the micro-kitchen preview, a private buttercream party, and business sponsorships. All donations will be tax deductible through the non-profit umbrella of Cafe Nordo.
 

Behind the cake

Kristina Dillard comes from a culture of cake.  As a little girl, she sat at the kitchen counter and watched as her grandmother made birthday and wedding cakes for people in her community. The craft was passed down to her mother who made hundreds of wedding cakes as Kristina grew up in their family restaurant.  Now, Dillard makes her own custom art cakes, gluten free and allergen friendly, styling herself herself as Kiss Me Cake Kristina.

Kristina has been performing, creating, and producing work in Seattle since 1993. She is the artistic director of the Big Red Dance Company, receiving grants from the Seattle Arts Commission, the Washington State Arts Commission, and the Allied Arts Foundation. Her choreography for Big Red Dance has been presented by Velocity, On the Boards, Seattle Center, and 10 Tiny Dances in Seattle and Portland. 
 

Pass the word

If you can't help financially, we deeply appreciate if you pass this campaign to your friends to help get the word out. We hope to see you at the show!

Her choreography for Big Red Dance has been presented by Velocity, On the Boards, Seattle Center, and 10 Tiny Dances in Seattle and Portland.

If you can't help financially, we deeply appreciate if you pass this campaign to your friends to help get the word out. We hope to see you at the show!

story:
Help send A Brief History of Beer on tour!

Who are we and what are we doing?

Hello, we are Wish Experience, a London based theatre company founded by US natives William Glenn and Trish Parry.  We have been working together for seven years, and over the past year we have researched, written and devised our baby - our show about the history of beer.  We have performed the show in Edinburgh and London with success, and have even been accepted in the British Guild of Beer Writers!  We are about to take our company to the international level, because we feel that our subject - has been a cornerstone of society across the planet for thousands of years, so we want to spread the beer love - and we need your help!


So far our audiences have been incredibly varied, from casual drinkers to brewers, from beer enthusiasts to beer historians.  Due to the nature of our audiences, which was particularly enthusiastic from the Scotland, the US, Canada, Australia, and Czech Republic, we realize that our show can be at home anywhere in the world.  Now we are returning to the US after a three year hiatus, where we will perform at brewpubs and fringes.

We already have initial dates.  On our way to North America we will pause in Australia to be a part of the Adelaide Fringe, where we will perform at The Wheatsheaf Hotel, as well as at Barossa Valley Brewing, in the heart of wine country.  When we reach the US, we will begin our tour at the Orlando Fringe, at The Venue, in May 2014.  From there we will trek north, through Cincinnati then across to travel New England.  And then the rest of North America!

What we need:

Crossing the globe and then returning to the US to immediately tour there is costly, which is why we want to raise $7000 (approx £4300 or 7700 AUD).  While in the UK we have been able to work on the show part time over the past two years, through the writing and creation of the show, and finance everything from our own pockets.  Now that we want to seriously go on tour, we need start up funds to book travel and accommodation, as we already have interest from venues as far out as June 2014.

We have a variety of donation choices, and we are also interested in any beer sponsorship, if anyone would like to get in touch.  For the donations, while of course the most important thing we can give you is love and gratitude, we have some great prizes!  We have mp3s of the original music from the show, special thanks', cool vintage beer pieces, company logos on our posters and flyers, and for a special price - we will come to you and do the show!  Preferably at a venue, but your living room will do!

And finally - a trip to OKTOBERFEST in Munich!!!  Wish went to Oktoberfest for research in 2013 - and so Trish is planning an epic trip for all of us!  The hotel and table are already booked! There are different donation levels for this based on where you are flying from, so check with Wish if you aren't sure which one to take.


Why a BEER show??

Before we moved to the UK, all we drank was Bud Light.  No lie.  But then we started getting into all of the beer styles here - real ale, craft brews, continental beers from Belgium, and Germany.  And we got curious.  We went to the British Library and began reading.  Soon we realized how rich the history of beer is - how it has influenced mankind spiritually, economically, scientifically.  And we found that beer was originally brewed by women.  And that the industrialization era had a big hand in shaping the attitudes towards beer today.  And that the craft beer movement today is fighting against all of this.  And so much more.  So we decided to do it - combine our great loves - theatre and beer - and set the record straight with a fun theatrical drinking game lecture.

Our show is silly, it's drink-a-long fun, but it also seeks to bring awareness about the rich history of beer and community.  It also imparts that it is the community, and the individual, that should influence what is being brewed in their town, not the mega corporations who aren't putting the love into the beer they should be. 

So - If you love beer as much as we do, please help us spread the beerjucation!  Anything will help, donate on here - $1 to $1000 - and spread the word on your facebook, twitter, blogs, newsletters.  Thanks!

Will & Trish

story:
IMPORTANT UPDATE! With Pictures!

Hey friends, check out our fancy new digs in the Updates section!!


WHO WE ARE
 
   We are a group of young, enthusiastic artists attempting to take our craft to the next level by breaking the mold of conventional theater and giving Waterville strength to unify. In Maine, we will explore themes of adventure, of hardship, of the strong Maine spirit that laughs in the face of chiseling a vehicle out of a block of ice every morning.
   Creating the performance will involve a rigorous training regimen and multi-faceted creative process. We plan to use physical theater in conjunction with SITI Company’s Viewpoints vocabulary to create an engaging piece of theater and cultivate an empowered audience.
   Our aesthetic is rural and worn. Carhart pants and flannel shirts, weathered posts leaning into the wind. Cracked and curled birch bark next to a shed snake skin. Rolling fields of wheat and blooms of broccoli, loose soil falling through soft hands. Hard work that leaves muscles sore and eyes bleary, coming home to rest in a scratchy horsehair armchair.
 
WHAT WE NEED
 
   An important aspect of our undertaking is the belief that artists do not have to starve for their work. Creating art can and should be a full time job that pays its players more than nothing. Part of this project is to pay the artists a small stipend for their stay in Maine. We will also provide food and housing so that their main concern is the work at hand.
   In order for the Strike Team to live, eat, and travel within Waterville for our stay, we need to raise $8,000.00 (That is not including the funds we need for  costumes, set design, production, etc.) By donating $10, you will be feeding one artist for one day. By donating $70, you will be feeding an artist for a week. It may not seem like a lot, but it is absolutely essential to the success of this project.
 
WHAT YOU GET
 
   By donating to Horsehair Strike Team, you will be promoting young artists who need (especially at this stage) support in order to create the work they dream about. You will also directly contribute to the strengthening of communities. Our goal isn’t just to make art but to make art that empowers, and celebrates the bond that is a group of people working together to make life a little better - for everyone. And we haven't even begun to mention the perks that come with your donation. Check them out!
   The success or failure of the project will determines it's future and whether other communities around the nation will benefit from what we are so eager to offer; Our time, our energy, our art, and the belief that when people work together - anything is possible.
 
WHAT WATERVILLE GETS
 
  Our hope is to descend on Waterville and inspire the community through "theater happenings" and by creating an internet buzz, generating some publicity for Waterville as a hip, artist-friendly town. That's from the outside-in. Day to day, we meet with local folks and exchange stories. This is in addition to training and composing, and running public workshops on various theater topics in various public places. The workshops we lead range from the general "what is theater/what is life like for a young person in theater" to actual physical workshops where we teach members of the community some of the principles that we are using in our daily work. Of course, we'll be doing small scenes a-la "Improv Everywhere" (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xRKfZ0mGLaY) while we try to polish our material before show time.
 
Other Ways You Can Help
 
If you're not able to contribute to our cause - don’t worry. ‘Like’ our facebook page and share our videos! It really does make a difference!
 
www.facebook.com/HorsehairStrikeTeam
 
Youtube - Horsehair Strike Team
 
Twitter - HorsehairStrike
 
Thank you to the Eugene O’Neill Theater Center, The Dragon’s Egg Studio, The Waterville Opera House, and our friends and family for supporting us. And thank YOU for helping to Make. This. Happen. We are incredibly grateful.
 
-Ian & Savvy, Horsehair Strike Team

story:
An Update from the Phantasmagoria Collective:

We are so exited to announce that we have reached our fundraising goal! Thanks to the overwhelming support of our donors, we've hit this milestone ahead of schedule. Thank you, thank you, thank you! 

To any would-be donors out there who may be thinking: "Oh well, they've done it; why would they need my help?", please know that any contributions in excess of our goal will only enhance our production. Your donations will be especially helpful for: 1) covering costs associated with this campaign (both PayPal and Inidegogo charge a fee to use their services which is deducted from the funds raised); 2) set design and construction; 3) advertising; and 4) providing an honorarium for the incredible artists who are donating their time and talent to this project. Also, we've got a fridge full of brownies, folks, and we want YOU to have them! We made a bunch of brownies to encourage further donations when we were still $200 from our goal, see, and then we hit our goal, and now the brownies are sitting in the fridge when they should be in your mouth! (This video will explain everything: https://vimeo.com/69841678 ) 

There are still 5 days left to conribute to the Canadian premiere of Tender Napalm at SummerWorks; please support this exciting project!

Thank you for taking the time to visit our page, watch our videos, and read this update. For more information about the project, please continue to read below. We hope you will consider donating to our campaign, and if you can't make a contribution now, please tell your friends about this initiative!

Thanks for your support!  

Who We Are & What We're Doing 

Hi!

Our names are Kyle Purcell and Amelia Sargisson, and we're Toronto-based theatre-makers.  We first read Philip Ridley's play, Tender Napalm, in our backyard last summer, and instantly knew we wanted to share this staggeringly beautiful piece with Canadian audiences.  We applied to the prestigious SummerWorks Festival, Canada's largest juried theatre festival, which is now entering its 23rd year, and found out in April that we were accepted!  Wahoo!  Since then, we've worked tirelessly to assemble an amazing team of artists to help us realize our dream, and we've also invested our own money to cover performance rights and the SummerWorks participation fee.  We've started this IndieGogo campaign to help us raise the rest of the funds we need to produce the Canadian premiere of Tender Napalm, the internationally acclaimed smash-hit by Philip Ridley.

In this 'unmissable' play, Man and Woman weave fantastical yarns in order to overcome their pain and carve out a brave new world in which they can love again.  The latter-day Adam and Eve navigate a phantasmagoric deluge of sea monsters, monkey soldiers, and flying saucers, while revealing glimpses of their fragile, real life selves.  This explosive two-hander, with its violent lyricism and pulsating sexuality, has seared itself into the minds of audiences the world over.  It's at once uniquely imaginative and universally transcendent, speaking to such themes as how love survives tragedy and how the stories we tell make up our realities. 

Tender Napalm premiered in 2011 in London, England, at Southwark Playhouse.  It was nominated for a London Award for Art and Performance in the category of Best Play.  It subsequently embarked on a smash-hit UK tour and has since been produced to great critical and popular acclaim around the world, from Ireland to Australia to Off-Broadway.  It has been described as 'a visionary work' by one of England's most celebrated living playwrights, himself heralded by Time Out magazine as 'probably a genius.'

Producing Tender Napalm within the context of a festival such as SummerWorks gives us access to an amazing venue, the storied Theatre Passe Muraille BackSpace, and allows us to reach a wide and diverse audience that would be inaccessible to us if we were producing this play independently.  We have also assembled an amazing team of theatre professionals who are very generously donating their time to this project.  As soon as we read the script, we knew we wanted to mine it with director Cynthia Ashperger; Cynthia is the head of acting at the Ryerson Theatre School and a former teacher of both of ours.  She is an accomplished performer, writer, and director, and her passion, fire, and expertise made her an obvious choice for this densely lyrical play.  We have also rallied assistant director Brittney Francis and a wildly talented design team consisting of Simon Rossiter (Lighting), David Mesiha (Music Compostion/Sound), Mariuxi Zambrano (Set/Costume), and Chloe Purcell (Graphic Design).  Rounding out the collective is stage manager Sonia Vaillant.  We are so humbled to be working with such incredibly gifted people, and are so excited to have them all on board.  

Now that we are about to embark on rehearsals, we need your help.  

What We Need & What You Get

Any donation you make, no matter how big or small, will help us achieve our dream of putting on this play.  Some of our costs include: set pieces, props, costumes, rehearsal space, publicity (like printing posters and postcards), advertising, our web presence, fundraising fees, photocopying, and the list goes on.  It is also important to note that Phantasmagoria Collective is operating under a profit-share model.  Any profit that the production makes, whether through fund-raising or ticket sales, will be divided evenly among the Collective members as an honorarium for the time and talent they have donated to this project.  

We will, of course, be judicious in our budgeting and inventive in our problem-solving, stretching every cent you donate.  Rest assured that any money you donate will go directly to funding the success of this production.

BUT, we don't want you to donate your hard-earned money just for the warm, fuzzy feeling you'll get from supporting the arts; we also have a ton of great perks to thank you for your generosity.  We're so grateful that you would donate to our project and help this production come to life that we're going to thank you with personal and meaningful rewards at every donation level. For out of town or overseas donors who won't be in Toronto anytime soon and can't redeem their perk, we can substitute perks from other donation levels; please get in touch and we'll hook you up! Please check out the side bar for more details; we're confident you'll find something there you'll love.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Thanks for checking out our Indiegogo page and thinking of making a donation to fund the Canadian premiere of Tender Naplam.  If you can't make a donation now but are excited about our project, there are still lots of ways you can help us out.  Please share our Indiegogo campaign with your friends and family, spread the word through Facebook, twitter, tumbler, pinterest, email, even take a photo and post it on instagram; anything you can do to get the word out is greatly appreciated!  

And of course, if you are in Toronto from August 8-18th, please come see us perform the Canadian premiere of Philip Ridley's Tender Napalm at the Theatre Passe Muraille Backspace.

For more information about Tender Napalm and the wonderful team behind it, Phantasmagoria Collective, please check out our website at www.phantasmagoriacollective.com and be sure to like us on Facebook to stay up-to-date on all our exciting production news! See you at SummerWorks!

Thanks so much for your support!

-Kyle and Amelia

Producers/Actors 

Phantasmagoria Collective 

www.phantasmagoriacollective.com

www.summerworks.ca

-Kyle and Amelia
Producers/Actors 
Phantasmagoria Collective 
www.phantasmagoriacollective.com
www.summerworks.ca

story:
Help support our fourth production, William Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet. Driven by both passion and pragmatism, Juliet embarks upon her journey from adolescence through womanhood to death in the span of only four summer days. Tempers are short, emotions are extreme, and time melts like an ice cube in the heat.  

Performed in our fast-paced, ensemble driven style, Shakespeare's classic tale of young love takes on added urgency. Victoria Reinsel and Charlene V. Smith previously teamed up to explore Juliet’s story in a one-woman play, What, Lamb! What, Ladybird! that debut at the 2011 Capital Fringe Festival. What, Lamb! What, Ladybird!, performed by Charlene V. Smith and directed by Victoria Reinsel, received five stars from MD Theatre Guide and was hailed as “dynamic” with “abundant wit and charm.”  

Your donation will help offset the cost of space rental, marketing, costumes, props, and set. All profits from the production are then split among the artists.  

June 12 - June 22, 2013

Wednesdays @8pm
Thursdays @8pm
Fridays @8pm
Saturdays @2pm
Saturdays @8pm

PWYC preview on June 11 @8pm.

$15 adults
$10 students and seniors

Atlas Performing Arts Center

Directed by Victoria Reinsel

With Jessica Aimone, Danny Cackley, Brandon Cater, Luke Cieslewicz, Nello DeBlasio, Connor J. Hogan, Mark McCarver, Emily Morrison, Carlos Saldana, Charlene V. Smith, and Shelby Sours.

Fight direction by Casey Kaleba. Movement coaching by Rachel Hynes. Choreography by Mark McCarver.
story_txt:
Help support our fourth production, William Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet. Driven by both passion and pragmatism, Juliet embarks upon her journey from adolescence through womanhood to death in the span of only four summer days. Tempers are short, emotions are extreme, and time melts like an ice cube in the heat.  
Performed in our fast-paced, ensemble driven style, Shakespeare's classic tale of young love takes on added urgency. Victoria Reinsel and Charlene V. Smith previously teamed up to explore Juliet’s story in a one-woman play, What, Lamb! What, Ladybird! that debut at the 2011 Capital Fringe Festival. What, Lamb! What, Ladybird!, performed by Charlene V. Smith and directed by Victoria Reinsel, received five stars from MD Theatre Guide and was hailed as “dynamic” with “abundant wit and charm.”  
Your donation will help offset the cost of space rental, marketing, costumes, props, and set. All profits from the production are then split among the artists.  
June 12 - June 22, 2013
Wednesdays @8pmThursdays @8pmFridays @8pmSaturdays @2pmSaturdays @8pm
PWYC preview on June 11 @8pm.
$15 adults$10 students and seniors
Atlas Performing Arts Center
Directed by Victoria Reinsel
With Jessica Aimone, Danny Cackley, Brandon Cater, Luke Cieslewicz, Nello DeBlasio, Connor J. Hogan, Mark McCarver, Emily Morrison, Carlos Saldana, Charlene V. Smith, and Shelby Sours.
Fight direction by Casey Kaleba. Movement coaching by Rachel Hynes. Choreography by Mark McCarver.

story:
The Story

By now we have all seen the macabre photos taken by G.H. Farnum of the Nelson's hanging from a bridge across the North Canadian River. I have written to keep the legacy of the Nelsons alive. I do not want them remembered simply hanging dead from a piece of rope. They were individuals who existed on this earth and tried to make it just like everyone else when harm befell them--when life happened.


So many of us have questions about who they were, where they were from, and how things got to the point that they were imprisoned and then consequently murdered. The play--this campaign--called Laura, on High serves to bring these three individuals to life--to resurrect them so we do not forget these tragic events of American history that occurred because people were full of hate and spite; so that we might learn from ourselves.


<object width="400" height="224" ><param name="allowfullscreen" value="true" /><param name="movie" value="http://www.facebook.com/v/10150237697480326" /><embed src="http://www.facebook.com/v/10150237697480326" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" allowfullscreen="true" width="400" height="224"></embed></object>

The Impact

Contributing to this project gives voice to the hard truths of our past and can liberate a generation of youths who have grown up uneducated, protected from reality, and otherwise secluded from our sometimes gruesome past. With the telling of Laura, on High we risk sticking up for ourselves again, we risk taking everyone's position into account, we risk living for humanity again.


Laura, on High, a riveting new drama by Andrew Hardaway, is the fictional account of the events leading up to the real-life 1911 lynching of Laura and LD Nelson. Laura falls prey to Oeishi, a local white Peace Officer, after the recent death of her baby girl and the loss of her bread-winning job that has helped sustain the family since their removal from Texas. With the intermittent presence of her husband, Austin, Laura finds herself in a void of hurt and loneliness in a society of repression and racial controls. So, that when lines are crossed, guns are fired, bonds are tightened, necks are stretched beneath the North Canadian River Bridge. The play will begin the grueling rehearsal and technical processes in August 2011 and premiere the week of the lynching's 101st Anniversary (May 25) in San Antonio (The Carver Center for Performing Arts) and Austin, Texas (venue TBA).


Laura, on High endeavors to touch on three black lives lost to injustice and circumstance. It fuels a deeper appreciation for the ghastly photos of the real-life Laura and LD Nelson as it provides a story and circumstance that begs to touch the tenderness and pathos of human existence.


What We Need & What You Get

The staged production of Laura, on high is an ambition one. It will take the paying of a Stage Manager, the creation of sets and props and the creation and construction of costumes and the project's media advertisement. If the entire campaign goal of $10,000 is not reached, the money raised will go toward a staged reading with Hornsby Entertainment Theatre Company and Great Deluge Media as well as a granite memorial plaque to be placed in the Greenleaf Cemetery in Okemah, Oklahoma honoring the final resting site of Laura and LD Nelson. Each donor will be given tickets to all theatrical showings and his/her name featured on the color playbill. The premiere is being scheduled for sometime in the Summer of 2012 in San Antonio and Austin, Texas.


The Breakdown

$1, 500.00 - Portable Set; materials and construction (Lumber, paint, finishing)
$3, 700.00 - Theatrical Space Rental (Carver Center @ San Antonio & Venue in Austin, TX)
$2, 500.00 - Costumes & Props (Sam's Taylor Company; San Antonio, Texas)
$1, 500.00 - Publicity Campaign (Tickets, Posters, Advertisements, Newspaper Announcements)
$800.00 - Stage Manager

story:
Help send 3 dancers from Kolkata, India fly to London, England to perform at Sadler's Wells Theater!

Blossomy.org is Helping Kolkata Sanved's "Transforming Steps: Stand with Survivors of Sex Trafficking, Stand Against Exploitation" Program Get to London!

Kolkata Sanved, an NGO from India has launched an international creative initiative called  "Transforming Steps: Stand with Survivors of Sex Trafficking, Stand Against Exploitationâ€™â€™ in collaboration with Living Lens (UK), Sadlers Wells (UK) and Thou Art Yoga Production (Trinidad and Tobago). 

The Impact

Transforming Steps seeks to draw public attention to the increase in sex trafficking during major international sporting events. The program is linked to Anti-Slavery Internationalâ€™s campaign on Trafficking and the Olympics. It is a unique attempt to enable the young women participating in the project to explore their innermost self and communicate with a wider international audience through dance and video. 


What We Need 

We need roundtrip airfare for 3 dancers (survivors) from Kolkata to London so that they can perform onstage at Sadler Wells just prior to the London 2012 Olympics as part of an initiative to educate the public about human trafficking.


More Information about the Initiative and Partners


Mafalda Deville from the Jasmin Vardimon Dance Company is working with dancers from Kolkata Sanved to develop two specially choreographed dances based on real life stories of survivors of violence. Further, a video made during a weeklong workshop conducted by Elspeth Duncan from Trinidad and Rose McCausland from Living Lens U.K with young girls from vulnerable communities will be screened during the dance performance at Sadlers Wells Theatre in London leading up to the 2012 Olympics. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Tell your friends!
Share this campaign on Facebook and Twitter!

Visit Kolkata Sanved website to learn more about Transforming Steps 

www.kolkatasanved.org

Follow their blog:

http://transformingsteps.blogspot.com/


You can also make a donation on 

www.blossomy.org

please note that the donation is for Transforming Steps

story:
Help send Monkeywood to !


Monkeywood Theatre are a Manchester-based Theatre Company who have been producing successful, engaging and ambitious high-quality theatre since 2003. Our current production is Once in a House on Fire by Sarah McDonald Hughes, a play based on the characters, themes and places in the bestselling memoir of the same name by Andrea Ashworth. Following sell out performances at The Lowry, Salford Quays, with 5 star reviews, we will be performing at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, at The Zoo Venue’s Monkey House, from Friday 5 - Monday 29 August 2011.

“I read this book over 5 years ago and it still lingers. If any story should have life beyond the page, this is it. A raw, sometimes bleak but uplifting and inspiring true story….” Maxine Peake (Silk, BBC 1)


Who are Monkeywood?

Monkeywood are Martin Gibbons, Sarah McDonald Hughes and Francesca Waite. Our previous work includes the 2010 Arts Council funded tour of Maine Road which was highly acclaimed (including unanimous 4* reviews and sell out audiences) for its authentic voice, excellent writing and superb performances; Last Orders, which was commissioned by the Royal Exchange for their sell-out PUB season in December 2009 and subsequently selected for The Library Theatre’s Re:Play season (staged at The Contact in January 2011); and A Song for the Lovers, which was produced at The Lowry in 2008 gaining 5* reviews and named as one of What’s On Stage’s top productions of 2008.

Why Once in a House on Fire?


“A new start tomorrow, a whole new life it’ll be.”

In a rainy world of poverty, violence, packing up and moving on, Andy and her sisters escape through stories, games and dreams of a ‘happy family’. But with each new start ending faster than the last, their hopes are stubbed out with their mum’s cigarettes. As a life beyond ’s grey sky beckons, Andy knows her escape will come at a cost. Following a sell-out run at The Lowry, Once in a House on Fire, based on the best-selling memoirs of Andrea Ashworth, is an extraordinary story about ordinary people.

One of our key aims as a company is to make theatre with a northern voice, rooted in the community where we live and work. We were in the midst of rehearsals for another project, , when mention of the book Once in a House on Fire kept cropping up. We were struck by how vivid, heartbreakingly truthful and deeply affecting this Manchester-based story is and how close it is to many people’s hearts, so we became excited at its theatrical potential.


“I’m thrilled that Once in a House on Fire is being brought to life on the stage through the fabulous Monkeywood Theatre, and immensely proud that they’re devoting their unique talents and passion to sharing this story.  I can’t wait to see what they do…” Andrea Ashworth



Andrea grew up in Moss Side, where Martin and Sarah now live, and went to the same sixth form college as Sarah and Francesca. Her story immediately felt like one which had real meaning for us and, more importantly, for our community and audience. Hers is a recognisable family – a unit of strong women who support each other in the face of poverty, discrimination, violence and constant disruption. What really stands out in the writing is the sheer strength of these women, their loyalty and love for each other, their bravery and their ability to carry on against the odds.

“Once in a House on Fire is a realistic picture of a dysfunctional family, but not a bleak one. The affection between the sisters, which is a key factor in their survival, is reflected in the vivid performances.…It is a tribute to the skill of the company that we care as much for those left behind as we do about the central character.” Public Reviews ****



The preliminary research for the script and spring 2011 tour of Once in a House on Fire was developed with support from The Lowry Studio and Arts Council England and funded through grants for the arts.



The Impact


We believe in the power of theatre as a valuable tool to help explore and understand the world we live in and we feel that theatre at its best can transform lives. We strongly believe that this very important story, and the piece of theatre we have created, will resonate with audiences across the country and have a real impact on those who come to see it.



Having already established a core audience in the north of , we are really keen to develop an audience nationally and the Edinburgh Festival will be the first time that our work has been seen outside of the north. As a company we aim to engage with a non-traditional theatre-going audience and feel that performing Once in a House on Fire at the Edinburgh Festival will enable this. This true story is universal and compelling, offering an accessible way for non-theatregoers to see inspiring and thought-provoking drama that resonates with them.

“If the theatre company are looking to draw people from a working class background, who wouldn't normally attend such shows, then from my experience yesterday, you are doing a superb job.” Once in a House on Fire audience member


What We Need and What You Get
During these difficult economic times arts funding has been severely reduced nationwide, so support from corporate sponsors is the only way to make our visit to possible. By we aim to raise a total of £20,000, but would very much appreciate any contribution that you can make.


The budget of £20,000 for the month in is estimated to include:
£3,000 - 2 weeks rehearsal fees for 5 actors, director, writer and stage manager plus rehearsal space

£11,000 - 3 weeks performance fees for 5 actors, stage manager and technician at The Monkey House

£4,000 - 3 weeks of travel, accommodation and subsistence for 5 actors, stage manager and technician in

£2,000 - Administration and marketing costs for festival, plus publicity material



Monkeywood will be endlessly fundraising from now until the summer with all kinds of activities from quiz nights and auctions to workshops and sponsored runs. Keep an eye on www.monkeywoodtheatre.co.uk for updates on fundraising events.


In acknowledgement and appreciation of your support we can offer:

·                      Advertising space in the production’s programme

·                      A logo on all of the Once in a House on Fire publicity material which will have extensive distribution across

·                      Acknowledgement and logo on the Monkeywood Theatre website

·                      Social media exposure, including Facebook, Twitter, Email signature, etc

·                      Complimentary tickets for the production in


“Andrea Ashworth’s award-winning memoir is a breathtakingly honest account of her experiences of domestic violence and financial hardship when growing up in inner city Manchester in the 1970s and 80s and locally-based Monkeywood Theatre (in development with The Lowry) has done a commendable job of transferring it to the stage….This a gripping story which is well told by a local theatre company.” Whatsonstage ***



We are happy to offer bespoke sponsorship packages, or please see Perks opposite for a guideline. (Currency conversion rates are as they were today).



Other Ways You Can Help

Please tell anyone you know about this campaign. Follow Monkeywood on Twitter @monkeywood, or become a fan of Monkeywood Theatre on Facebook. Please email us directly at info@monkeywoodtheatre.co.uk

story:
WHAT IS THE PLAY ABOUT?

What happens when our art doesn't provide the catharsis we so deeply crave?

At the heart of the play is The Couple, known only as Him and Her, two playwrights dealing with unimaginable loss the only way they know how- by building a fortress of words impregnable to grief. But emotions have a way of emerging through cracks in the walls, and gradually the truth slips past their defenses to uncover their very real tragedies.

WHY PRODUCE IT?

The play will showcase one of the most original voices in theatre, while harvesting the careers of a new crop of theatre professionals. Ross Mueller, a terrifically accomplished Australian playwright with a prolific oeuvre, curiously has had little work produced in New York, and we are thrilled to bring his beautiful one-act to the NY stage. This is an incredibly exciting avenue for our team. A young director will shape his artistic voice because outside of the given circumstances of the story, there are endless possibilities as to how he can treat this completely inventive play. While the producer's responsibilities are large, her tasks are manageable on a project of this scale. And for our marketing director, the chance to bring big name commerical theatre experience to the NY independent scene is invaluable. As producing in New York City can be quite expensive, we have drafted a very modest budget that will ensure an affordable production without inhibiting the integrity of the play and our vision. 

WHY FUND IT?

Unfortunately, we didn’t win the MegaMillions, though we tried. If you were the one to win, we’d deeply appreciate a percentage of your winnings. However, your donation, regardless of size, goes straight to making the US Premiere of Construction of the Human Heart a possibility.  We need funding to pay for rehearsal space, performance space, rights, publicity, costumes, a set, lights, projections, and actors. This can all be made possible through your generous support.  While $15,000 would help us immensely, it is a fraction of the total costs of making this experience possible.
Also, haven’t you always thought about that trip to Australia? And haven’t you said to yourself, “I would LOVE to go to that Opening Night party!”?  Help us to construct our play and check out all the other perks of giving on the right side of this page.  It would mean the world to us.

WHO ARE WE?

We are five twenty-something's living in New York trying to stake our claim in the theatre world.  Though we each come from different sectors of the industry, we share a common passion for creating theatre that is original, vital and inherently theatrical.  Three of us met during our undergraduate education at Syracuse Univeristy and have since strengthened our commitment to the craft through our love for Ross Mueller's play.  Our team is small but mighty and we are hard at work looking for valuable additions to our team.  Support us and you're supporting the future of theatre.

Becky Leifman, Producer

Brendan Naylor, Director

Jon Backus, Marketing Director

Chelsea Alexander, Communications Director

Katie Lupica, Dramaturg

Becky Leifman, Producer
Brendan Naylor, Director
Jon Backus, Marketing Director
Chelsea Alexander, Communications Director
Katie Lupica, Dramaturg

story:
Our Story

Theatre Daedalus is headed to The Edinburgh Fringe Festival to present the World Premiere of Unanswered, We Ride, an original play by Jaclyn Villano.  After workshops at The Last Frontier Theatre Conference in Valdez, Alaska, and the National Comedy Theater in New York, Unanswered, We Ride will take flight at the Edinburgh Fringe, the largest theater festival in the world.


We need your help getting across the pond!  As you may imagine, taking a show to an international festival is tremendously expensive. Many people have been generous already, but we still have a lot of money to raise.  With your generosity, Theatre Daedalus will proudly debut Unanswered, We Ride at this major theatrical event.


About Unanswered, We Ride

When her nine-year old daughter takes a fall from the monkey bars at school, Reese O'Leary's well-crafted life changes forever. Her paradigm shattered, Reese does what any devoted wife and mother would do — runs away from home. Unanswered, We Ride takes us on a journey from a quiet Ohio town to the lush hills of Ireland, from the sleepless streets of Manhattan to the teacup ride at Disney World. Against a backdrop of loss and longing, playwright Jaclyn Villano challenges us to explore the people and places that make up who we are, and define for ourselves what home really means. Directed by Elena Araoz†, the production features Joy Barrett*, Joe Tippett*, and Martha Wollner*.


This is a play about life and how even at our darkest points we have the capacity to move forward.  Some who have donated to this production have done so in memory of loved ones; if you would like to dedicate your contribution, please let us know and we will be sure to include your loved one's name in our program. 


† Member SDC
* Member Actors' Equity Association

The Impact

The Edinburgh Fringe is the largest arts festival on earth: in 2010, more than 21,000 performers brought more than 2,400 shows to life at the Fringe. This is an unparalleled opportunity for artists to come together to perform and network with producers, promoters, journalists, directors and media professionals. Many productions have been successfully developed here, and many performers have had their careers transformed by a successful run at the Fringe.

Our goal is to gain international recognition and exposure for Unanswered, We Ride, and to catapult this exposure into production runs both in the United States and abroad. 


Where The Money Goes

 How does each donation help? Funds raised for Unanswered, We Ride will go toward:

•Room and board for cast and crew for 4 weeks
•Actor/director salaries
•Cost of designers
•Airfare for the cast and crew
•Insurance
•Venue rental fee
•Hiring a publicity team
•Press and marketing materials, online and in print
•Production costs (lighting, set design, set construction, costumes, etc.)
•Rehearsal time/space
•Operational costs (printing/faxing/etc.)


Theatre Daedalus is a 501(c)3 organization, and all donations to this project are tax-deductible. 


For more information, please see www.theatredaedalus.com


Other Ways You Can Help

Please let us know if you'd like to attend one of our preview performances to be held in New York at 59E59

story:
The Alchemist Theatre is reaching out to you for a bit of help producing 2013's KING LEAR.

Is your money going to be used wisely??

For six years The Alchemist Theatre has operated as a "for profit" entity.  This, of course, does not mean that there are many "profits" but it does mean that The Alchemist Theatre has remained afloat with very few donations, no grants, and all taxes paid.

Because of strict and careful budgets, The Alchemist has not only been able to sustain for the past 6 years, but it has also been able to contribute significantly to the art community by sponsoring events such as the Bay View Gallery Night, offering free box-office services to other fledgling theatre companies,  setting aside rent-free space in the season for up-and-coming artists and raising significant funds for local artists in need as well as non-profit groups such as The Aids Resource Center of Milwaukee.
All while most times paying a respectable stipend to the artists involved.

BUDGETS are are always strictly adhered to and a great deal of "BANG" has been squeezed out of every buck received through moderate to low-priced ticket sales.

On tiny Alchemist budgets:

  • You've witnessed long, dark, detailed Whitechapel alleyways.
  • You've experienced wild lighting, ghostly video projections, and surround-sound music and effects.
  • You've wandered through an entire "neighborhood" environment of custom built, "Streets of Old Milwaukee" style sets for the throughout-the-building production of FAUST.
  • AND you've seen some truly, truly amazing local talent blossom on that little stage.

HOWEVER, The Alchemist is now in new waters.
With this summer's production of KING LEAR, The Alchemist Theatre brings in the talents of professional directors, designers, and actors, to the extent we've never seen before, taking The Alchemist Theatre to a new level of professionalism

We've pinched our pennies.
We've kicked in some personal money.
We've agreed to work for a few drinks at the bar (hopefully with you!)
Now we're hoping that you can join us on this adventure and contribute a bit to fill in a few gaps in the remaining budget.

There are a lot of talented, amazing people involved in this production and we'd like you to be one of them!


ANYTHING raised over and above budget goals will go directly to the people working on this show.

     Speaking of the people involved with this production,
you should take a moment to meet these folks!  
(Or at least look at their photos and read a bit about them online:  http://www.thealchemisttheatre.com/king-lear )

As part of our THANK YOU for your contribution The Alchemist Theatre has assembled a few "perks" that we are offering at different levels of contribution.

Also, we KNOW that there are sixteen gazillion requests just like this floating around your inbox and Facebook page.
We get it.
And we know that most of the people who will recieve this are also artists - many of who are trying to raise their own funds.
How can you help other than donating some funds?

  • Let others know about the show!
  • If you're planning on seeing the production, buy your tickets early - early bird specials on tickets save you money too!
  • Reserve your tickets for early in the run.  Opening weekend is always the last to go and closing weekend people are stuck in the lobby without tickets.  Selling opening weekend first helps A LOT!

 

WHATEVER YOU CAN DO... THANK YOU SO VERY, VERY MUCH!
IF THIS MESSAGE HAS REACHED YOU THEN CHANCES ARE YOU'VE ALREADY DONE A GREAT DEAL FOR THE ALCHEMIST THEATRE, SOMEONE INVOLVED, OR THE ARTS COMMUNITY IN GENERAL!

THANK YOU!   HOPE TO SEE YOU SOON AND TRULY HOPE THAT YOU ARE ABLE TO JOIN US IN BRINGING THIS PRODUCTION TO THE STAGE.

       WE'RE SO EXCITED!!!  (There have already been tears to prove it.)

story:
Short Summary

•                The Bolinas-Stinson School is a small K-8 school with an enrollment of 107 students, located in the beautiful beach communities of Bolinas and Stinson Beach, California.

•                The 11 students in the eighth grade have been reading and analyzing A Midsummer Night’s Dream over the past few months with high hopes of performing scenes from the play in the Middle School Talent Show, which is the fundraiser for the annual year-end trip to Ashland, Oregon.

•                Your contribution will help defray the costs of our trip!

 
What We Need & What You Get

•                The total cost of the trip is $7,772, with contributions coming from eighth grade families, the Bolinas-Stinson School Foundation, and proceeds from the Talent Show, held May 4th.

 
The Impact

After reading A Midsummer Night’s Dream the eighth grade got much more enthusiastic about the themes and characters. The challenges of language were faced, and students feel more confident with Shakespeare’s text. Seeing the plays would be a fun and creative way to gather more information from the time period, as well as to learn about other Shakespeare plays.

“From hearing stories from previous classes, I can’t help but be excited to go. But we need your support if we want to make it happen. Please ask families and friends to help us and donate money towards this wonderful field trip. Thank you.”

-an eighth grade student

story:
Emerging dance artist, Johanna Dalgleish (Vancouver) and choreographer Meagan O'Shea of Stand Up Dance (Toronto)

...present...

'as yet unknown' 

The details of the break up are so boring, universal, mundane... even cliche... yet they are utterly all-consuming.  'as yet unknown' chronicles the dissolution of a relationship and the navigation of loneliness, longing and picking up the pieces that follows.

For the past two years dancer Johanna Dalgleish and mid-career dancer and choreographer Meagan O'Shea have researched and collaborated out-of-pocket to create a new 25 minute solo about the process of finding oneself out of the wreckage of a break up.  Now we're coming together to present our new work for the first time.

...help us get there...

 

WHEN & WHERE:

August 23, 24 & 25th 2012 at 7:30pm at the Ottawa Dance Directive


'as yet unknown' has been picked up by SÉRIE DANSE 10 / SERIES DANCE 10 a program of the Ottawa Dance Directive to be performed at the end of August 2012 in Ottawa, Ontario.

...but we need your help...

 

HOW YOU CAN HELP:

Your contribution (in any denomination) will help recover some of the development and travel costs incurred throughout our unfunded choreographic process and ultimately get us to Ottawa!!!

The Breakdown:

Sound $250

Costume $200

Airfare $500

Performance Fees $450

Artist Fees $800

Your donation will go directly to help make this first theatre performance of our work happen!  If our entire goal is not reached, the donated funds will go towards production costs, making this performance a reality.

 

WHAT YOU GET FOR YOUR HELP:

 

In addition to the joy of promoting Canadian art, your donations will receive recognition in our program and other such swag!  Check it out in the box to the right...

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

If you're unable to contribute, you can still help by spreading the word!  Please feel free to share with your friends and post this link on your facebook and twitter!

 http://www.indiegogo.com/as-yet-unknown

 

Many thanks!

Johanna Dalgleish
