story:
Hi! We’re Jessica Grace Smith and Barbara K. Begley, friends, former roommates, long time collaborators, donut enthusiasts, and co-creators of new theater piece MARYSHELLEYSHOW.

 

(pictured, Mary and Emily demonstrate Regency Dancing)

 

(pictured: Mary and Emily demonstrate Regency nutrition)

 

MARYSHELLEYSHOW is a variety show presented by dirtbag teenage geniuses  Mary Shelley and Emily Dickinson, as they struggle with friendship, loneliness, the slipperiness of fame and historical importance, and the desire to host one damned party without Lord Byron messing it all up.

 

(pictured: Lord Byron messing it all up)

 

It has musical performances and dance numbers and poetry readings, and it's acerbic and dirty and absurd with a big pained mushy heart.

(Pictured, a big messy mushy heart)

MARYSHELLEYSHOW got its start at renowned underground Brooklyn art incubator Undiscovered Countries, where it played to a sold out bar in 2014, and then again by popular request for the festival’s third birthday show in 2015.

 

This year, MARYSHELLEYSHOW has been offered two very exciting engagements: a 10 day residency workshopping the show in August at the Denmark Arts Center in beautiful Denmark Maine, and also a 3-performance slot at the Chicago Fringe Festival in September.

 

(THIS IS MAINE)

 

This is thrilling for us, and comes with unprecedented opportunities: the chance to dig our teeth in and fully produce what has up until now been a DIY, shoestring, seat of our pants workshop experience, and then take the show out of town and present it to brand new audiences who have no prior context for us and our work. To say we are honored to take this on is an understatement, and we couldn’t be more psyched to present MARYSHELLEYSHOW in particular as Undiscovered Countries’ first out of town production.

What We Need & What You Get

The two highlights of these plans - focused time and space to build a production in Denmark, and traveling for Chicago Fringe - are also the two main factors in our needing unexpected funds. We are fundraising production costs to pay for travel, set, costumes, and other production costs, and to pay our artists who are doing incredible work on this show, and taking significant time off their survival jobs in ways that a New York based show does not require.

 

Our expenses include:

  • Paying stipends for our 7 artists workshopping the piece in Maine: $525
  • Stipends for our 7 artists performing the piece at Chicago Fringe: $525
  • Fringe Festival Fee: $250
  • Equity Rehearsal Rate and Fee: $350
  • Properties/Costumes/Scenic: $200
  • Artist Transportation(Brooklyn, Maine, Chicago): $1,830
  • Housing: $900
  • Marketing/Perks (posters, postcards, programs, perks from this Campaign): $230

Subtotal: $4,810

  • Emergency Funds: $480
  • Crowdfunding Fee: $471

-----------------------------

GRAND TOTAL: $5,761

If you can help us make this dream a reality, you’ll be helping us bring a piece of queer, DIY art to a brand new level and brand new audiences! But that’s not all! In addition to being an important part of the story of this piece and Undiscovered countries, you get fabulous perks! Check out the side of this campaign page for details!

 

Risks & Challenges

Live theater is always an unpredictable medium, and producing a show from multiple different states is a challenging process. We’ve assembled a crackerjack team to put this show together; together we’ve done everything from youth theater productions assembled from creation myths to interdimensional graphic novels, to humorous filmed PSAs about coping with premature ejaculation. Barbara has helped to produce over 40 nights of new live performance with Undiscovered Countries, and Jessica is doing great work on the ground in Chicago and Maine to ensure that this project is the best it can be. We’re committed to rolling with punches and using adversity to make the art better, and we have the track record to prove we can.

Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate everyone who wants this show to succeed, and we entirely understand that not everyone will be able to contribute monetarily to this campaign - as struggling young artists we understand what it is to be broke and unable to support your own work, let alone others’. But not being able to donate doesn’t mean you can’t help! Here are some other ways to get involved.

 

We are gratefully accepting in-kind donations, of everything from airline miles and gas cards to art supplies and printing services. Have you got a bunch of gold mylar laying around from an art project? Frequent flier miles you don’t plan to use? Access to sweet deals at Chicago businesses that could provide flyer printing, drink tickets for audience members, or pizza for the cast at a discounted rate in exchange for endorsement? A bunch of Jell-O that you bought the last time you had a tooth pulled? A really badass copy of Frankenstein? ANY AND ALL OF THIS HELPS. Perks apply, message us for details.

 

Help Spread the Word! The success of both funding and and presenting this show will depend on how well we can build grassroots support. That’s why we would so appreciate you sharing this page with friends, families, and larger networks! You can use the Indiegogo sharing buttons to share the link directly to social media, and also feel free to use our very official MARYSHELLEYSHOW hashtags

#MARYSHELLEYSHOW

#lordbyronisnotinvited

#FrankensteinortheModernPrometheus

 

Come to the Show! We’d love more than anything to see your faces at these performances! Tickets for the Denmark, Maine engagement are already on sale here: http://www.denmarkarts.org/ai1ec_event/maryshel...

Tickets for Chicago Fringe will go on sale August 1st!

We’re really excited about this project, and hope you are, too. Thanks for checking it out!

(THIS IS HOW YOU MAKE US FEEL WITH YOUR SUPPORT)

story:
Why Daddy Long Legs?

Jean Webster’s original novel Daddy Long Legs has inspired many creative works, such as the 1955 film adaptation with Fred Astaire, animated shorts and even a sequel, but nothing captures the heart of the story quite so well as the musical.

With music & lyrics by Paul Gordon (Jane Eyre, Emma) and book by John Caird (Les Misérables, Jane Eyre), we are transported back to 1908 to the dreary life of Jerusha Abbott, just before her world turns upside down. The show is so intimate, with only Jerusha and Jervis onstage, and one cannot help but connect with these two characters as they lay their hearts out for all to see.

Because the rights to the show have just become available, this will be the first production of Daddy Long Legs in Los Angeles in several years. It is a new show to many, but one whose message will resonate with all. In a time when it is easy to insulate oneself with people who share the same opinions and life experiences, Daddy Long Legs shows us the value of going out of your comfort zone and the impact generosity can have on another person's life. And we can’t wait to share it with you.

Details

THE TEAM

Director: Anna Miles

Anna Miles is a director, performer and playwright with a passion for stories that celebrate women of all kinds. Anna holds an MFA from the Brown University/Trinity Repertory Company MFA Programs in Acting and Directing and a BA in theater from Northwestern University. Past directing credits include: Sisterplay by Griffin Sharps (Brown/Trinity), Brown/Trinity's annual "First Look Festival," and both the workshop and full production of her self-written play, It Was the Nightingale: Persephone's Play (Northwestern University). Anna is currently playing the roles of Young Anna and Young Elsa in Frozen: Live at the Hyperion at the Disneyland Resort.

Musical Director: Cassandra Murphy

International Theatre: Ellen, Miss Saigon in Macau, China’s International Music Festival. Regional Theatres: Eva Peron, Evita (Eddon Award Best Lead Performance); Fantine, Les Misérables (LA Premier, Ovation Nomination for Best Musical); Ellen, Miss Saigon (Ovation Nomination for Best Musical, Broadway World Nomination for Best Actress). Cassandra is also the Outreach Director for Cabrillo Theater.

Stage Manager/Dramaturg: Anna Timm

Lighting Designer: Ryan Peck

Costumer: Sarah Timm

Piano: David Galvan

Cello: Max Mueller

THE CAST

Jerusha Abbott: Melissa Dunham

Recent theater credits include: Antonia in Man of La Mancha, Anne in The Diary of Anne Frank, Laurey in Oklahoma! and Jasmine in Disney's Aladdin: A Musical Spectacular. Melissa is currently a member of the ensemble of Frozen: Live at the Hyperion. UCI BFA (Zot zot!)

Jervis Pendleton: John Shartzer

Recent theater credits include: Max in Lend Me A Tenor and Paul the Human in the workshop of Darling Grenadine. This year, John was Ryan in season three of Hulu's Casual, Frankie in Subway's Italian hero campaign, Andrew in the feature film The Book Club with Candice Bergen, and he looks forward to make his network debut, this fall, in the pilot episode of Ghosted on Fox.

TIME & PLACE

Thursday September 21st @ 8pm

Friday September 22nd @8pm

Saturday September 23rd @8pm

Sunday September 24th @2pm

Two Roads Theater

4348 Tujunga Ave., Studio City, CA, 91604

http://www.tworoadstheater.com/index.html

Where are donations going?

 We've carefully planned the budget that we need to make this show happen. Here is a chart showing the breakdown of where donations will go:

If we do raise funds exceeding $9200, it will enable us to enhance the audience experience through additional design elements. Any extra funds raised beyond that will be donated to our main cause, Shriners Hospitals for Children.

The Shriners Mission

In the spirit of the show, we've decided to donate all general admission ticket sales to Shriners Hospitals for Children. Shriners is an incredible organization that provides cleft palette, burn and orthopedic care as well as other services to children in need regardless of a family's ability to pay. This organization changed the life of our Jerusha, Melissa Dunham, by correcting her clubfoot and providing follow-up care until she was nine-years-old. Through Indiegogo, half of our tickets will be given to donors as pre-sale rewards but the other half will not be a part of the Indiegogo campaign, their proceeds will go directly to Shriners following our closing.

For more information on Shriners, visit:

https://www.shrinershospitalsforchildren.org/care

 

Perks!

So, what's in it for you? Well, other than supporting local independent theater AND helping us raise money for Shriners, we have some awesome perks available to donors including:

  • A 4-week acting course at the Lifebook Academy (http://lifebookplayhouse.com/)
  • Original 1914 copies of Daddy Long Legs by Jean Webster
  • VIP tickets to donor-only performances of the show
  • A chance to add your voice to our set dressing

and more!

 

Can't donate?

Thank you for taking the time to read about our campaign and watch our video. We are so excited to bring Daddy Long Legs to the Two Roads Theater in September. If you feel compelled to donate, any amount is appreciated. If you cannot donate at this time, but would still like to support this project, please share this campaign with friends and family. We will keep this campaign updated about the release of general admission tickets.

For more information, contact daddylonglegsla@gmail.com.

Thank you.

--Daddy Long Legs Team

story:
FLYCATCHER - synopsis

“Needy.  Spiteful.  Ruthless.  And these are a few of her good points.”

Flycatcher is a darkly comic thriller which follows a web-woven world, where no one is seen for who they really are:

Madelaine is an awkward waitress with a buried past.

Mae is a forgotten grandmother, who only wants some attention.

Bing is a happy-go-lucky salesman, wanting to spread the American dream.

Olive is a successful but emotionally distant art gallery owner.

These lives will come together when Madelaine tries to pull Bing into her world. However, when Bing sets his sights on Olive, no one and nothing will stop Madelaine from luring any unsuspecting victims into her own psychological traps.

And so unfolds a complex and extraordinary series of events, all cunningly orchestrated by Madelaine and geared to - bit by bit - draw them all under the same roof. 

Her schemes are at once hilarious and heart-breaking, but the closer they all become, the more each of their secrets emerge to cause the inevitable and catastrophic clash of identity.

All About Me

Thank god it's not all about me!  But if you wanna know, professionally I'm a writer-director, producer and author with a whole lot of experience, creativity and passion (check out www.masuak.com )  I've had an incredible and eclectic journey creating videos for performers like Take That (I completed "New Day", only 3 months ago), Kylie and Spice Girls; directed actresses like Penelope Cruz and Courtney Cox;  am the author of the irreverent spiritual self-help book The Spiritual Slob and have several TV and film projects being pitched around the planet.  My focus is always first and foremost on creating powerful and inspiring entertainment, so as well as all that I'm also at the moment working part time in the 6th Floor kitchen and Bar of the Tate Modern while I continue to hone the creativity that I absolutely live for and to keep things real (you can't get any realer than that!)  While some people think it's a bad move to admit that, I'm proud of whatever it is I do and give my all - whether it's pushing my theatre, film and TV projects out there in the world (FLYCATCHER expects to be two of them), or keeping the guts of the Tate kitchen going and having a laugh and real connection with people I'd have never met had I not taken that mission on.  My take on life is you gotta do what you do with your heart and soul and being and sometimes the curve balls take you to exactly where you never realized you really needed to go, and that's the fun of it.  

A few years back I had the opportunity to see a very rough rendition of FLYCATCHER on a small stage at Theatre 503 and saw how powerful a piece it is. It's funny and it's dark and it speaks of those secret places we hide within ourselves, which is very much a recurring theme in all my long form work.

When just over 5 weeks ago Matthew Parker (artistic director of The Hope) invited me to put FLYCATCHER on stage there, it was a dream come true.  While it came at the worst possible financial moment  I felt that while outer circumstances looked a little hairy-scary, my inner world was screaming a rather undeniable "yes" .  And so here I am in a nerve-wracking but exciting moment that I'm now involving others in - including you - who I hope can help us reach our goal!

The Others

Luckily with all this short notice, "I" am now "We", and "We" includes the most awesome Assistant Director, actors, technicians and creatives in the industry - check them out here!  http://pigseverywhere.wixsite.com/flycatcher-theplay/about3

And our amazing cast, yes!  Hit this link to check them out, we're so excited to have such an awesome talented ensemble!   http://pigseverywhere.wixsite.com/flycatcher-theplay/cast--characters

Our indigogo campaign takes us from the moment, right here right now, up to first night on stage at The Hope.  Beyond that we will continue with Phase Two Funding that will see us throughout our run - but for now, your contributions go immediately to getting a rehearsal space for the next month, paying the actors, pulling together props, sets, wardrobe, printing posters and brochures and flyers and marketing materials - and everything needed to shapeshift this creative whirlpool into solid reality.  What you are contributing to is making sure our creatives in this industry get paid for their incredible hard work, which sadly isn’t very common in theatre.

Throughout the campaign we will be keeping you up to speed what your money is helping build, in and out of the rehearsal room! and we can't thank you enough in advance for supporting this!

Goals!

WEEK ONE (Now!):  Our rehearsals start TODAY!  In order to snare rehearsal space for the month and start paying the actors (happily a requirement to be at The Hope) we need a minimum of £2,000 so thank you in advance for getting the show truly up and running!  

WEEK TWO:  Paying the actors continues, getting the sets designed and construction starting, pulling in the sound design, composing, animation and design/graphics, marketing and everything needed to start building the play - we will need an additional minimum amount of £2,000

WEEKS THREE & FOUR:  Our rehearsals intensify, requiring more time and more actors being actually together.  Props, wardrobe, and our continuing set building, technical tests and everything running up to our Premiere - £3,000, bringing us up to our "to First Night" goal of £6,000

If We Exceed This Goal

This is Phase One of our fund raising campaign - we then have a month of performance, so any additional finance will roll over into our 4-week run.  Thank you for being so generous! 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you have any ideas let us know!  We are lovers of collaboration as well as welcomers of patronage, so give us a shout!

Bing is a happy-go-lucky salesman, wanting to spread the American dream.
Olive is a successful but emotionally distant art gallery owner.
These lives will come together when Madelaine tries to pull Bing into her world. However, when Bing sets his sights on Olive, no one and nothing will stop Madelaine from luring any unsuspecting victims into her own psychological traps.
And so unfolds a complex and extraordinary series of events, all cunningly orchestrated by Madelaine and geared to - bit by bit - draw them all under the same roof. 
Her schemes are at once hilarious and heart-breaking, but the closer they all become, the more each of their secrets emerge to cause the inevitable and catastrophic clash of identity.
All About Me
Thank god it's not all about me!  But if you wanna know, professionally I'm a writer-director, producer and author with a whole lot of experience, creativity and passion (check out www.masuak.com )  I've had an incredible and eclectic journey creating videos for performers like Take That (I completed "New Day", only 3 months ago), Kylie and Spice Girls; directed actresses like Penelope Cruz and Courtney Cox;  am the author of the irreverent spiritual self-help book The Spiritual Slob and have several TV and film projects being pitched around the planet.  My focus is always first and foremost on creating powerful and inspiring entertainment, so as well as all that I'm also at the moment working part time in the 6th Floor kitchen and Bar of the Tate Modern while I continue to hone the creativity that I absolutely live for and to keep things real (you can't get any realer than that!)  While some people think it's a bad move to admit that, I'm proud of whatever it is I do and give my all - whether it's pushing my theatre, film and TV projects out there in the world (FLYCATCHER expects to be two of them), or keeping the guts of the Tate kitchen going and having a laugh and real connection with people I'd have never met had I not taken that mission on.  My take on life is you gotta do what you do with your heart and soul and being and sometimes the curve balls take you to exactly where you never realized you really needed to go, and that's the fun of it.  
A few years back I had the opportunity to see a very rough rendition of FLYCATCHER on a small stage at Theatre 503 and saw how powerful a piece it is. It's funny and it's dark and it speaks of those secret places we hide within ourselves, which is very much a recurring theme in all my long form work.
When just over 5 weeks ago Matthew Parker (artistic director of The Hope) invited me to put FLYCATCHER on stage there, it was a dream come true.  While it came at the worst possible financial moment  I felt that while outer circumstances looked a little hairy-scary, my inner world was screaming a rather undeniable "yes" .  And so here I am in a nerve-wracking but exciting moment that I'm now involving others in - including you - who I hope can help us reach our goal!

The Others
Luckily with all this short notice, "I" am now "We", and "We" includes the most awesome Assistant Director, actors, technicians and creatives in the industry - check them out here!  http://pigseverywhere.wixsite.com/flycatcher-theplay/about3
And our amazing cast, yes!  Hit this link to check them out, we're so excited to have such an awesome talented ensemble!   http://pigseverywhere.wixsite.com/flycatcher-theplay/cast--characters
Our indigogo campaign takes us from the moment, right here right now, up to first night on stage at The Hope.  Beyond that we will continue with Phase Two Funding that will see us throughout our run - but for now, your contributions go immediately to getting a rehearsal space for the next month, paying the actors, pulling together props, sets, wardrobe, printing posters and brochures and flyers and marketing materials - and everything needed to shapeshift this creative whirlpool into solid reality.  What you are contributing to is making sure our creatives in this industry get paid for their incredible hard work, which sadly isn’t very common in theatre.
Throughout the campaign we will be keeping you up to speed what your money is helping build, in and out of the rehearsal room! and we can't thank you enough in advance for supporting this!
Goals!
WEEK ONE (Now!):  Our rehearsals start TODAY!  In order to snare rehearsal space for the month and start paying the actors (happily a requirement to be at The Hope) we need a minimum of £2,000 so thank you in advance for getting the show truly up and running!  
WEEK TWO:  Paying the actors continues, getting the sets designed and construction starting, pulling in the sound design, composing, animation and design/graphics, marketing and everything needed to start building the play - we will need an additional minimum amount of £2,000
WEEKS THREE & FOUR:  Our rehearsals intensify, requiring more time and more actors being actually together.  Props, wardrobe, and our continuing set building, technical tests and everything running up to our Premiere - £3,000, bringing us up to our "to First Night" goal of £6,000
If We Exceed This Goal
This is Phase One of our fund raising campaign - we then have a month of performance, so any additional finance will roll over into our 4-week run.  Thank you for being so generous! 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you have any ideas let us know!  We are lovers of collaboration as well as welcomers of patronage, so give us a shout!

story:
NOTE: An extremely generous donation in the amount of $5,000 was given to this production outside of the IndieGogo setup, so we are much closer to reaching our goal than it may seem!  We still have a little ways to go and further "After Dark" productions to fund, so please consider donating!

DISCLAIMER: This production does not represent the political views of the Lubbock Community Theatre.

So What’s All This About?

The Lubbock Community Theatre (LCT) has long been interested in establishing an “LCT After Dark” season that would showcase edgier, more experimental fare than its regular season, and with Ubu Roy: An American Tale, it is finally taking the plunge.  Under the direction of Jared Strange, award-winning playwright and Texas Tech grad, an ensemble of fine actors will work together from a simple text to create a fast-paced, funny, and searing take on Alfred Jarry’s seminal play Ubu Roi, putting the play’s ludicrous story and craven characters smack in the middle of this year’s equally ludicrous and craven election.

In keeping with its goal to explore new kinds of plays, LCT will be exploring a new kind of fundraising.  As community theatre audiences change and new entertainment platforms emerge, crowdfunding seems to be an ideal way to make sure institutions like LCT – and art forms like theatre – stay current.  As a collaboratively-made project based on current events, Ubu Roy is a particularly appropriate project for crowdfunding.  So instead of throwing your money so some super-rich bigwig can waltz into the White House while spamming your email account, try throwing it at us instead!  We guarantee minimal spam and even less waltzing.

 

You Have Money, We Have Stuff – The Best Stuff

The Ask
The budget goal is $3,000 clams (standard currency).  This does not include the 5% platform fee charged by IndieGogo or the 3%+30c fee charged for every credit card transaction; any bonus cash will go toward those fees first. 

Roughly $2000 of the money will be used to pay the people involved, including the writer/director, the cast, the stage manager, the board operators, the set-builders, and so on.  Theatre folk typically aren’t in it for money (and those who are don't stay in it for long), but like most jobs, it’s all about investing in the right people.  Trust us when we say we'll be getting the best people - the best!

Another $1000 or so will go toward the polish: set pieces, props, makeup, wigs (lots and lots of ridiculous wigs).  Ubu Roy’s story shifts from scene to scene very quickly and depends on laughs both cheap and super-cheap, so the aesthetic is hardly high-end.  Nevertheless, we may end up needing enough wigs and makeup to run a small circus.

The rest of the money will go toward printing and marketing costs.  We want this play and this new LCT After Dark initiative to be yuge - yuge, I say! - and good marketing makes projects like this go a long way.

Important Note: our goal is a flexible one, meaning we keep whatever money we get, whether over the stated goal or under it.  If it’s under, we stagger on to the finish line (fitting, considering how this election is unfolding); if it’s over, that extra goes to our fees and the next LCT After Dark production!

The Pay-Off
Of course, seeing top-notch theatre isn’t the only thing you’ll get for contributing to our campaign!  Take a look at the perks on the right.  These perks ensure our top investors get a little extra access to what they're funding - and they'll make for a unique theatrical experience!

Please note that all investors – whether they give $1 or back the whole project – will be thanked in our program.  It's an old adage, but true: every little bit helps!

 

The Impact (Which Will Be Yuuuge!)

While this kind of funding model is new for LCT, a track record of success is not.  For over 25 years, LCT has been bringing quality theatre to Lubbock, producing plays and musicals, classic standards and contemporary hits, comedies and dramas, and everything in between.  Jared Strange, meanwhile, has seen his plays produced and read across the country and even in Europe, and already has a strong relationship with LCT thanks to their collaboration on the original Christmas play Christmas in Terminal B.  LCT and its associates are worth investing in, and if this model proves successful, it could help ensure that community theatre in this city – even beyond – stays alive and relevant for decades to come.

Of course, that’s not to say there isn’t some risk involve.  Crowdfunding in theatre has had plenty of success, but it’s hardly the norm.  And sure, every new play, especially one this political, runs the risk of playing to empty seats as many of us respond best to content with which we are already familiar, which is why golden age musicals and classic farces continue to rake in the money.

Ubu Roy: An American Tale may not be a classic of the golden age, and it may not be familiar, old though its original text is.  But it is unique to the Lubbock community theatre scene: it’s a piece built by a tight unit, a unit that will shape its work according to what happens with this pivotal election day-by-day.  Even the ending will change depending on the results of Nov 8th, a date which falls right in the middle of the run.  This kind of immediacy is rare in the theatre scene at large, and we are confident that this and its other distinctive qualities - not to mention it's laugh-a-minute guarantee - will make Ubu Roy a hot ticket for theatregoers looking for a little something new.  If nothing else, it’s a lot better than watching wall-to-wall CNN coverage of the election and crying into your Whataburger!

 

Other Ways to Make Yourself Useful

If you’re unable to contribute monetarily but still want to contribute to the project as a whole, there are a number of ways to get involved.

Share!  IndieGogo has a number of sharing tools that make it easy to pass the campaign on to other interested parties.  Please feel free to share it via social media, email, word of mouth, billboard, smoke signal – whatever works!

Audition!  Auditions for the play are September 12th and 13th.  Consult the Lubbock Community Theatre Facebook page or contact writer/director Jared Strange (jaredstrangeofficial@gmail.com) for more details.

Usher!  LCT is always looking for volunteers to serve as ushers, an easy enough gig that also guarantees a free ticket!

Come See the Show!  No cast likes to look out at a barren house, so please, if nothing else, come on down and see what we've been cooking up!

 

A Personal Thanks from the Director

Big props to Jay Brown (Artistic Director), Pam Brown (Managing Director), Robin Stephenson (Business Manager), Randal Ramirez and Erin Castle (LCT After Dark Co-Chairs), and the Lubbock Community Theatre Board of Directors for taking a chance on this kind of work.  Now let's pay back their faith!

story:
A-Squared's Holiday Fundraiser will be the starting point of our "10X Challenge" for our Capital Campaign.  For every dollar raised, our Capital Campaign Committee will set a target of 10X to fund our programming into 2016 and beyond.

Mission
As an Asian American theatre company, A-Squared Theatre Workshop provides opportunities for Asian American theatre artists to develop and showcase their work and talent by staging stories that accurately depict the Asian American cultural identity and experience. A-Squared’s productions and readings also educate the general public on issues relevant to the Asian American community, such as family, immigration, assimilation, social justice, sexuality, mental health, and other pertinent themes. By addressing these important issues, A-Squared creates theatre that reflects the diversity of Asian cultures present in the Chicago area. 

History

A-Squared Theatre Workshop was founded in December 2006 by a collective of Asian American theatre artists based in Chicago. Noting that many important Asian and Asian American plays, both new and old, have never been produced in Chicago, these artists united for the common goal of bringing these stories to the Chicago stage. In doing so, the founders pledged to showcase the talents of Asian American directors, designers, writers, and actors who they believe were underutilized, underrepresented, and misrepresented in Chicago theatre.

story:
JULIE-Tragédie canine est le premier spectacle de notre compagnie de théâtre, le Collectif du vestiaire. Nous le créons en co-production avec Nuages en pantalon-compagnie de création.

Julie a disparu. Guillaume en est responsable. Il regardait le baseball au lieu de la surveiller. Laurence, sa copine, ne le lui pardonne pas. Il a perdu leur bébé : Julie, leur chienne adorée. Laurence met Guillaume à la porte ainsi que leurs dix années de vie commune et leur projet d'acheter une maison. Elle se promet de retrouver Julie coûte que coûte. Guillaume trouve refuge chez des amis, un couple pour qui cette rupture représente une menace à son propre avenir. Ils se promettent de rétablir la situation peu importe le prix.

Le Collectif du vestiaire cherche, à travers la création, à explorer les possibilités du réalisme et à ouvrir le théâtre à des publics nombreux et variés. 

Les fonds amassés serviront à boucler le budget de notre production. 

Merci de croire en l'importance de la relève artistique ! Merci de nous aider à faire notre place !

-Pascale Renaud-Hébert et Samuel Corbeil.

Présenté à Premier Acte du 24 février au 14 mars

Venez-nous voir !

story:
'OMG', the opera, is a story of a single mother's lifelong struggle to raise her only child, born of rape, as she searches for happiness, strength, and relief from the trauma that is forever intertwined with the identity of her son.
My name is Stephanie Leotsakos and I am an aspiring opera singer, composer, conductor and artistic producer. I wrote this one-act opera for my senior thesis at Princeton, in an effort to explore timeless concepts such as filial love, the strengths of women, the potential for change after existential crises, and universal ideas which have carried religions such as Christianity through millennia. The many faces of the phrase “Oh my God” are explored in different contexts while framed in different historical time periods spanning from 550 AD Ravenna, Italy to the U.S. today. Please help me bring new life to this opera by contributing!

I wrote this one-act opera for my senior thesis at Princeton, in an effort to explore timeless concepts such as filial love, the strengths of women, the potential for change after existential crises, and universal ideas which have carried religions such as Christianity through millennia. Please help me bring new life to this opera by contributing!

story:
The Short and Sweet

Music is beautiful. Dancing is wonderful. This is the rhythm of joy…and it sets us free! That's why Sugar Swing Dance Club is building a home for jazz, dancing, and music in Edmonton. It will be Edmonton’s only dedicated home for social swing dancing, and a hoppin’ venue for plenty of live jazz to keep us moving. Plus, our studio will provide affordable rehearsal and classroom space for artists, dancers, and musicians of all kinds!

We’re a humble arts community giving it all we got – and it’s gonna take a lot. As a contributor, you not only get sweet perks, but you will also be joining with us to renovate a two-floor facility with the features we all love: spacious rooms, sprung hardwood floors, good acoustics, air conditioning, sound and lighting, and much, much more.

Our goal is to raise $20,000 to help build out this space and make it beautiful by January 2017.

You can build this house of music and dance by purchasing dance passes, rehearsal time, original artwork, and other fun stuff! Keep reading to learn more about what we're building together.

A Little Background

Sugar Swing is a local, family-owned dance club that was established in 2005 by swing dancer Birkley Wisniewski. It is much more than a business: it has grown into a community of amazing people who all love live music and dancing. We offer dance classes in swing (Lindy Hop), jazz, and tap, and host weekly dance socials. We’ve been hired to perform for many notable organizations, including Fort Edmonton Park, the City of Edmonton, the Winspear Centre, and the Alberta Legislature. Ultimately, Sugar Swing encourages a social atmosphere, welcomes beginners, and is open to anyone: no partners required, no dance experience necessary, and no age limits!

In February 2015, we leased the former Old Strathcona Presbyterian Church on Whyte Avenue in Edmonton and turned it into a ballroom. It was a temporary lease as the owner had plans for redevelopment. But the opportunity was too good to pass up: it was a large space in a great location for the right price, so we forged ahead. In August 2016 we were sad to learn that the ballroom's fate arrived: the owner was ready to move ahead with development, and that we had to move out by November 30, 2016.

The good news is that we found a fantastic new space! It is a gorgeous, air-conditioned new building with parking in a great location. And that is what this campaign is all about! It will provide a permanent home for Sugar Swing. Here is where our club will take root and our amazing community will continue to grow! Our dancers can rest assured they will always have a place to enjoy swing music and dancing.

How to Get There

Our new building is located just off Whyte Avenue, on 100th Street. Still close to the action, and very accessible to transit. The building itself has two floors and is brand new. It's so new that it needs quite a lot of work to become functional! Your contributions will go to finishing the build and adding amenities. This includes:

  • Sprung, hardwood dance floors both upstairs and down
  • Electrical, plumbing, and HVAC systems
  • Washrooms
  • Kitchenettes and bars
  • Interior walls and partitions to create all the rooms, including an office, staff room, and powder room
  • Lighting and sound equipment

We're a hands-on community, and much of the work will be done by the owners, their friends and family, and our amazing volunteers. However there are parts of the job that require skilled tradespeople with permits in order to get the work done properly and safely. Funds will be prioritized to projects that are most essential to the operation of the building -- so walls, floors, HVAC, electrical, plumbing. As those get taken care of, we'll move toward things like equipment and aesthetics.

*Update* Push Goals

When we reach these campaign milestones, we'll commit to providing some awesome experiences for our contributors and community! Spread the word to help us get there, and enjoy these sweet benefits:

$15,000: Contributors and Volunteers Hot Tub Dance Party

We'll throw a sweet hot tub dance party with free food and drink for everyone who contributed to the campaign, as well as those who've volunteered their time to the space. Share to help make it happen!

$20,000: Live Music Every Friday for THREE MONTHS

We'll arrange for a live jazz trio to play at every Friday social dance for three months! Admission will be very reasonable. Tell your friends to help secure three months of live music for your dancing pleasure!

The Perks

We're offering a wide variety of perks that are fun, unique and practical! If you love dancing, why not become part of the legacy and have your name engraved on the ballroom floor? Or if you are an artist, secure some sweet rehearsal space for when we're ready to go? You can also indulge in a bit of original artwork, or get a limited-edition, contributors-only t-shirt! Stay tuned as we roll out more fun perks over the course of the campaign.

The Impact

Dancing and music brings people together. Our vision is to see a beautiful ballroom filled with people dancing, socializing, and having fun to amazing live music. Contributing to this project helps to create this vision for yourself, your friends, and people who need joy in their lives! We're not kidding when we say that dance brings people together: this past year, three couples who met through Sugar Swing got married!

Sugar Swing has successfully renovated two former spaces within the last five years, all on its own dime, with the help of both skilled hired labour and volunteers. The owner is a former engineer involved in the building industry, and the community has generously contributed their time towards the build out of those spaces.

We were able to grow substantially under those prior projects, but unfortunately not enough time has lapsed to replenish Sugar Swing’s financial resources. Both of our former leases required less renovation work than the one now, and while they were meant to be temporary, they both ended much earlier than anticipated. Now we finally have a place that we’ll have for a minimum of 10 to 20 years, or more! This project will be permanent, and is significantly larger in scope.

What to Expect

Renovations often take longer and cost more than expected, but we are determined to be partially operational by mid December 2016 and fully completed with renovations by February 2017. As we undertake this journey, we ask for your patience regarding project delays or changes to the plan. We'll do our best to keep you informed about what we're working on! The good news is that we have considerable experience with renovating spaces, especially after turning a big ol' Presbyterian church into a ballroom. And Birkley, the director, has built no less than two sprung dance floors.

Other Ways You Can Help

Buying perks isn't the only way you can support our vision for music and dancing! You can:

  • Attend Sugar Swing dances and classes. Supporting our business is a very practical way to help us through an extremely challenging transition phase!
  • Spread the word. If you know friends, dancers, artists, or even businesses that might want help sponsor or help build a vibrant dance space, tell them about us!
  • Volunteer your time. You can help us move, complete certain reno tasks, or get involved with the building process in a variety of ways. Email dance@sugarswing.com for information on this.

Meet the Team

The guy behind this wild ride is Birkley Wisniewski, Director of Sugar Swing. Birkley has been dancing for 14 years and is dedicated to spreading his love of dance through Lindy Hop, jazz, tap, West African, and more! Through dance, he has gained a passion for music. Not only is he a world-class swing dance deejay, but he hires jazz bands whenever possible to play at Sugar Swing. He and his wife Jenna are pouring their hearts (and just about everything else) into creating a living, joy-filled home for music and dance in Edmonton.

We rely on several amazing people to help build out this vision:

  • Jenna O'Flaherty, his loving wife, is a professional graphic designer. She helps with creative, marketing, and much feedback on this project
  • Elyse Szabo, our office manager, helping keep Sugar Swing running smoothly as we embark on this project
  • Krystal Moss, instructor and video editor, is a multi-talented artist helping us with this campaign in several ways, including the video!
  • Our Staff Instructors, who are collectively helping to provide project feedback, the perks, and volunteering time towards renovations
  • Our Community of dancers, numbering in the dozens if not hundreds who contribute their volunteer labour on the project, and finances! This includes are dedicated organizers, deejays, performance team members (Mad Cat, Mad Kittens, Big Time Groove), members, and long-time regulars.
  • Contractor Friends such as Kevin Marshall, Thomas Siegel, and Valley Floors Inc. and their valuable construction trades expertise!
story_txt:
The Short and Sweet
Music is beautiful. Dancing is wonderful. This is the rhythm of joy…and it sets us free! That's why Sugar Swing Dance Club is building a home for jazz, dancing, and music in Edmonton. It will be Edmonton’s only dedicated home for social swing dancing, and a hoppin’ venue for plenty of live jazz to keep us moving. Plus, our studio will provide affordable rehearsal and classroom space for artists, dancers, and musicians of all kinds!
We’re a humble arts community giving it all we got – and it’s gonna take a lot. As a contributor, you not only get sweet perks, but you will also be joining with us to renovate a two-floor facility with the features we all love: spacious rooms, sprung hardwood floors, good acoustics, air conditioning, sound and lighting, and much, much more.
Our goal is to raise $20,000 to help build out this space and make it beautiful by January 2017.
You can build this house of music and dance by purchasing dance passes, rehearsal time, original artwork, and other fun stuff! Keep reading to learn more about what we're building together.
A Little Background

Sugar Swing is a local, family-owned dance club that was established in 2005 by swing dancer Birkley Wisniewski. It is much more than a business: it has grown into a community of amazing people who all love live music and dancing. We offer dance classes in swing (Lindy Hop), jazz, and tap, and host weekly dance socials. We’ve been hired to perform for many notable organizations, including Fort Edmonton Park, the City of Edmonton, the Winspear Centre, and the Alberta Legislature. Ultimately, Sugar Swing encourages a social atmosphere, welcomes beginners, and is open to anyone: no partners required, no dance experience necessary, and no age limits!
In February 2015, we leased the former Old Strathcona Presbyterian Church on Whyte Avenue in Edmonton and turned it into a ballroom. It was a temporary lease as the owner had plans for redevelopment. But the opportunity was too good to pass up: it was a large space in a great location for the right price, so we forged ahead. In August 2016 we were sad to learn that the ballroom's fate arrived: the owner was ready to move ahead with development, and that we had to move out by November 30, 2016.
The good news is that we found a fantastic new space! It is a gorgeous, air-conditioned new building with parking in a great location. And that is what this campaign is all about! It will provide a permanent home for Sugar Swing. Here is where our club will take root and our amazing community will continue to grow! Our dancers can rest assured they will always have a place to enjoy swing music and dancing.
How to Get There
Our new building is located just off Whyte Avenue, on 100th Street. Still close to the action, and very accessible to transit. The building itself has two floors and is brand new. It's so new that it needs quite a lot of work to become functional! Your contributions will go to finishing the build and adding amenities. This includes:

Sprung, hardwood dance floors both upstairs and down
Electrical, plumbing, and HVAC systems
Washrooms
Kitchenettes and bars
Interior walls and partitions to create all the rooms, including an office, staff room, and powder room
Lighting and sound equipment

We're a hands-on community, and much of the work will be done by the owners, their friends and family, and our amazing volunteers. However there are parts of the job that require skilled tradespeople with permits in order to get the work done properly and safely. Funds will be prioritized to projects that are most essential to the operation of the building -- so walls, floors, HVAC, electrical, plumbing. As those get taken care of, we'll move toward things like equipment and aesthetics.
*Update* Push Goals
When we reach these campaign milestones, we'll commit to providing some awesome experiences for our contributors and community! Spread the word to help us get there, and enjoy these sweet benefits:
$15,000: Contributors and Volunteers Hot Tub Dance Party
We'll throw a sweet hot tub dance party with free food and drink for everyone who contributed to the campaign, as well as those who've volunteered their time to the space. Share to help make it happen!
$20,000: Live Music Every Friday for THREE MONTHS
We'll arrange for a live jazz trio to play at every Friday social dance for three months! Admission will be very reasonable. Tell your friends to help secure three months of live music for your dancing pleasure!
The Perks
We're offering a wide variety of perks that are fun, unique and practical! If you love dancing, why not become part of the legacy and have your name engraved on the ballroom floor? Or if you are an artist, secure some sweet rehearsal space for when we're ready to go? You can also indulge in a bit of original artwork, or get a limited-edition, contributors-only t-shirt! Stay tuned as we roll out more fun perks over the course of the campaign.

The Impact
Dancing and music brings people together. Our vision is to see a beautiful ballroom filled with people dancing, socializing, and having fun to amazing live music. Contributing to this project helps to create this vision for yourself, your friends, and people who need joy in their lives! We're not kidding when we say that dance brings people together: this past year, three couples who met through Sugar Swing got married!
Sugar Swing has successfully renovated two former spaces within the last five years, all on its own dime, with the help of both skilled hired labour and volunteers. The owner is a former engineer involved in the building industry, and the community has generously contributed their time towards the build out of those spaces.
We were able to grow substantially under those prior projects, but unfortunately not enough time has lapsed to replenish Sugar Swing’s financial resources. Both of our former leases required less renovation work than the one now, and while they were meant to be temporary, they both ended much earlier than anticipated. Now we finally have a place that we’ll have for a minimum of 10 to 20 years, or more! This project will be permanent, and is significantly larger in scope.

What to Expect
Renovations often take longer and cost more than expected, but we are determined to be partially operational by mid December 2016 and fully completed with renovations by February 2017. As we undertake this journey, we ask for your patience regarding project delays or changes to the plan. We'll do our best to keep you informed about what we're working on! The good news is that we have considerable experience with renovating spaces, especially after turning a big ol' Presbyterian church into a ballroom. And Birkley, the director, has built no less than two sprung dance floors.

Other Ways You Can Help

Buying perks isn't the only way you can support our vision for music and dancing! You can:


Attend Sugar Swing dances and classes. Supporting our business is a very practical way to help us through an extremely challenging transition phase!

Spread the word. If you know friends, dancers, artists, or even businesses that might want help sponsor or help build a vibrant dance space, tell them about us!

Volunteer your time. You can help us move, complete certain reno tasks, or get involved with the building process in a variety of ways. Email dance@sugarswing.com for information on this.

Meet the Team
The guy behind this wild ride is Birkley Wisniewski, Director of Sugar Swing. Birkley has been dancing for 14 years and is dedicated to spreading his love of dance through Lindy Hop, jazz, tap, West African, and more! Through dance, he has gained a passion for music. Not only is he a world-class swing dance deejay, but he hires jazz bands whenever possible to play at Sugar Swing. He and his wife Jenna are pouring their hearts (and just about everything else) into creating a living, joy-filled home for music and dance in Edmonton.
We rely on several amazing people to help build out this vision:


Jenna O'Flaherty, his loving wife, is a professional graphic designer. She helps with creative, marketing, and much feedback on this project

Elyse Szabo, our office manager, helping keep Sugar Swing running smoothly as we embark on this project

Krystal Moss, instructor and video editor, is a multi-talented artist helping us with this campaign in several ways, including the video!

Our Staff Instructors, who are collectively helping to provide project feedback, the perks, and volunteering time towards renovations

Our Community of dancers, numbering in the dozens if not hundreds who contribute their volunteer labour on the project, and finances! This includes are dedicated organizers, deejays, performance team members (Mad Cat, Mad Kittens, Big Time Groove), members, and long-time regulars.

Contractor Friends such as Kevin Marshall, Thomas Siegel, and Valley Floors Inc. and their valuable construction trades expertise!

story:
Short Summary

Solomon and Marion is the story of the unlikely friendship between Marion Banning, a white South African Woman of English decent and Solomon Xaba, a young Xhosa boy. It was staged at the Edinburgh fringe festival in 2014, and will be produced as part of the Anacostia Playhouses summer festival in August 2015

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $2000 and that money will all go towards, paying the wonderful Lara Foot Newton for use of her delightful script, as well as hiring set designers, lighting crew and paying the director and the actors. Plus publicity and stage managers.

The Impact

Whilst this story is set in South Africa, we feel it's impact can be felt in many other communities in which  racial and generational divides and prejudices tear at the seams of society. it explores violence and ways that hope and trust and healing can emerge from dark times.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please don't think that if you can't donate that you can't help, there are lots of ways you can help us. Spread the word. Give us a high five or a hug when you see us! And if possible come to see the show.

story:
Old World Theater Isn't Dead, It's Just Been Hiding On An Island.

Tasmania tends to breed the weird and wonderful, Side Show Cabaret is all this and more. Born from a lust for vintage vaudeville, SSC features a live band, comedy, burlesque, circus, freak show, tap, parody, insanity and sheer dumb luck.

Founded in 2012 as an experimental cabaret troupe, SSC has gone on to be a cornerstone in Tasmanian theater.
With everything from burlesque, pole arts, singers, tap-dancing, gender illusion, B grade comedy, live music and so much more.

The Side Show performs regularly in Hobart around the state.
The cast is always growing and new routines and skills are constantly being added to the shows, and in 2016 we have the opportunity to escape the island and be part of the Adelaide Fringe Festival. For may Tasmanian performers working out side of the state is not an option due to the costs of travel.

By jumping on board and helping us raise funds to get the show to Adelaide you will not only be helping many of the cast achieve their goals but also helping showcase what amazing talent Tasmania has to offer.

If funding is successful we will be bringing Miss Burlesque Tasmania 2015, Miss Burlesque Hobart 2015, Mr Boylesque 2014, 2015 Burlesque Idol Melb. & many, many more for a showcase like no other. 


The Penny Drop:

By Air -  We need to fly three Tasmanian performers and one Victorian performer to South Australia and home.

By Road - We need two Tasmanian performers and a van full of props to South Australia and home. (this includes petrol and boat tickets)

By Gosh! - Marketing costs. we need to be able to afford to advertise the gig appropriately through both print and radio. These funds will help us support the Adelaide community by taking out advertising with their community radio stations and outlets.


The Who's Who:

The Acts:

Le Fay - Tasmania

Betty Bronx - Tasmania

Gemini - Tasmania

Ainslie Adams - Victoria

LeopardLass - South Australia

Tapper Jack - Tasmania

The MC:

Chris Soulidis - South Australia

The Band:

Jason Mallia - South Australia

Barry Gibson "aka Mr Horn" - South Australia

Pete Poropat - South Australia

Francis Macri - South Australia

Dean Barcello - South Australia

Brett "Bert" Pitfield - Tasmania


We Want To Thank You

You work hard for your money so we don't expect you to give it away for nothing. have a look at our great perks and pick out some fun stuff!

Every Bit Counts

Even if we don't reach our goal of $7000.00 any contribution to this cost is going to help us get to the Fringe Festival in 2016


Other Ways You Can Help

Being a troupe of starving artists we know not everyone can contribute with funds to our campaign. Don't feel band just give the page a share and help us connect with those who can!


Thank You <3 Side Show Cabaret

story:
WHO WE ARE & WHAT WE'RE DOING

Clear Theater Collective is a theater company in Williamsburg, Virginia, made up entirely of friends and former/current students of Naomi Marrow & Backstage Productions, a staple of Williamsburg theater and arts education since 1999. 

Last year, CTC produced its first show, The Odd Couple, and thanks to a successful Indiegogo campaign and dozens of generous donations after both performances, we were able to bring theater free of charge to Williamsburg at absolutely NO COST.

In 2017, Clear Theater Collective wants to do it again.

For our second production, we are producing David Mamet's controversial landmark play, Oleanna; produced, directed, designed, and performed by members of the Collective.

CTC's Oleanna Indiegogo campaign is about one thing: Putting on a great show that is completely free to our audiences!

We believe that free local theater is a necessity, not a luxury. Your donations make it possible for up to 500+ audience members from across the Peninsula to see live theater for free!  All members of the cast and crew are volunteers, so 100% of your donations go towards paying for the expenses of producing Oleanna. 

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

Our Phase 1 fundraising goal of $400 covers the following: Performance rights ($200), and venue costs ($200). In July, we'll launch Phase 2 to help cover our set, prop, and costume costs. 

Some of the perks of donating: You can get your name in the show program, reserved seating, shout outs before each performance and on social media, and even an Executive Producer credit! 

If you've ever wanted to be a producer, or even just a valued patron of the arts, now's your chance! 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

1) Come see the show! September 15th @ 6pm, and September 16th @ 2pm at the Williamsburg Regional Library in Williamsburg, VA. Even if you can't donate, we still want you there!

2) Bring your friends and family! 

3) Spread the word about the show and our Indiegogo campaign! Share this link and help us get the word out.

4) Visit us online at cleartheaterco.com and on social media @ClearTheaterCo!
